PETITION.TITLE: Jarosite Dumping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned respectfully call upon the Federal Government to (a) reverse the decision to extend the time allowed Pasminco EZ to dump jarosite at sea, and (b) endorse and comply with the December 1995 deadline established by the London Dumping Convention.

PETITION.TITLE: Logging and Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: We are dismayed at the continuing destruction of old growth and wilderness forests around Australia, despite the National Forest Policy Statement jointly signed by the Commonwealth and all States except Tasmania.

Intensive logging, most often to feed a voracious woodchip industry is underway or planned for many high conservation value forests. These forests should be protected by the commitments of the Commonwealth and State Governments under the NFPS.
These forests include:

PETITION.PARA: Coolangubra Wilderness and other areas of the S.E. Forests of NSW along with rainforest and other N.E. areas of NSW including Wingham, Mistake, Richmond Range, Chaelundi, North Washpool, Barrington and Dorrigo.
The Southern Highlands, Great Western Tiers and Tarkine Wilderness of Tasmania.
The Karri and Jarrah forests of S.W. Western Australia.
The Errinundra Plateau and other areas of the East Gippsland forests of Victoria.
The rainforests of the Proserpine region of Queensland.

PARA.TAB: We request that the Government act urgently to protect our precious forests by utilising the Commonwealth's legal and constitutional powers, including:

PETITION.PARA: Refusal of export woodchip licences
Powers to control corporations
Protection of areas listed on the register of the National Estate
Protection and effective funding of areas identified for their World Heritage values.

PARA.TAB: Genuine and effective action by the Government to protect these and other old growth and wilderness forests is critical. A comprehensive plantation strategy rather than exploiting native forests is the way forward for a truly environmentally responsible timber industry. We further request that the Government take effective action without further delay.

PETITION.TITLE: UHF Transmission in Tasmania
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows that:

PETITION.PARA: 1.The UHF line-of-sight transmission is not suited to Tasmania's mountainous terrain.
2.It is unjust that compulsory UHF has resulted in poorer reception for many Tasmanians and that those living in weak "pockets" have outlaid of up to $450 in order to receive the signal.
3.It is unjust that many low-income Tasmanians and pensioners do not have the means to outlay hundreds of dollars so they can view their own television sets.
4.Compulsory UHF has resulted in some Tasmanians being denied a signal.

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners ask that the Senate, in Parliament assembled:
Call on the Government to:

PETITION.PARA: (a)honour its commitment to ensure that first class television reception is delivered to all the residents of Tasmania by providing additional funding for the urgent implementation of the necessary number of transmitters.
(b)provide all Tasmanians with access to their own national broadcasters, the ABC and the SBS.

PETITION.TITLE: Landmines
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned urges the Government to press for a total ban internationally on the production, stockpiling, trade and use of anti-personnel devices.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate urge the Government to provide financial aid for the demining of countries such as Cambodia.

PETITION.TITLE: Census Forms
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:

PARA.TAB: That the current practice of destroying the census is denying future generations an invaluable and irreplaceable resource of data on medical, historical, social, scientific and demographic factors.
Your petitioners request that the Senate should:

Request the Government to review its current policy of destroying the census; and support a proposal to retain the census forms for release for specific research purposes in either 70 or 100 years time.

PETITION.TITLE: Trade Unions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows that:

PETITION.PARA: 1.We are concerned that unions have the power to intrude into every small business in Australia even if the employer and employees don't want them.
2.We believe that employees should have the right to voluntary unionism where they so choose.

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners ask that the Senate should:
Call on the Government to:
(a) support the Federal Coalition's legislation soon to be introduced to bring in voluntary unionism in Australia;
(b) recognise that by providing both employers and employees with a real about wage bargaining, businesses can prosper and therefore provide more jobs; and
(c) show a greater commitment to the need for creating growth and providing jobs.

SPEECH.PARA: HEALTH AND OTHER SERVICES (COMPENSATION) BILL 1994
Under current legislation, people who receive compensation for an injury should reimburse the Commonwealth for medicare and nursing home benefits which they have received in respect of that injury.

However, the review of the relationship between compensation and health and community services programs found that many people receiving compensation designed to meet the full cost of injury-related medical and other care needs do not reimburse the Commonwealth. They `double dip' by receiving free or heavily subsidised services funded by the Commonwealth, as well as compensation for the full costs of these services.
Double dipping can never be acceptable, because it means that the community pays twice for a service—once through insurance and again through Commonwealth funding.
The current policy to prevent double dipping is not able to be implemented properly because of flaws in the legislation. According to the work of the review, it appears to be widely circumvented.

This main compensation bill and its cognate Bills seek to address the problems with the existing legislation and ensure that the Commonwealth is reimbursed the equivalent of benefits that have been paid, as current policy requires. It is important to stop double dipping because it diverts limited resources away from injured people who have no alternative source of assistance apart from Commonwealth programs.

The amendments will improve systems to identify compensation claimants and recipients, and to recover benefits paid prior to an award of compensation. The benefits covered by the Bills are medicare benefits, provided under the Health Insurance Act 1973, and nursing home benefits, provided under the National Health Act 1953.

The new provisions will ensure that compensation claimants and recipients, insurers, and compensation payers are aware of their liabilities to the Commonwealth, where medicare benefits and/or nursing home benefits have been paid to claimants before their compensation is payable.
The bills are particularly targeted at lump sum compensation payments. Double dipping is generally not a problem under periodic payment schemes because expenses are reimbursed as they are incurred.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Identification of people who receive compensation

SPEECH.PARA: It is estimated that approximately 73,000 compensation cases are finalised each year, with many more than that number ongoing at any one time. To improve the identification of these cases, the main bill requires insurers and compensation payers to notify the Health Insurance Commission of details of claims lodged for compensation. They must also notify the Commission of key events in their progress and of their finalisation.
While seeking to improve identification of compensation claimants and recipients, the new arrangements protect individuals' private information relating to their treatment histories.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Benefits Paid Prior to Compensation Becoming Payable

SPEECH.PARA: Medicare and nursing home benefits paid to or in respect of a person because of their compensable injury up until compensation is payable will be recovered from the compensation payment. Where the amount of compensation is reduced because of contributory negligence, the amount of benefits to be recovered will be determined on the basis of the reduced compensation award.

Compensation claimants will be required to identify all services received in respect of the compensable injury prior to the compensation case being finalised. Insurers and compensation payers will then be notified by the Health Insurance Commission of the amount to be reimbursed to the Commonwealth. This will be done prior to the compensation amount being determined.

Although the debt will be the compensable person's, insurers or compensation payers will be liable to the Commonwealth for payment of the amount claimed from the compensation. Payment will be made by the insurer or compensation payer at the time compensation becomes payable. Given these arrangements, no appeals process against recoveries for past benefits is necessary because the claimant identifies the services in respect of the compensable injury and for which benefits have been paid. Claimants can then ensure that the amount to be paid to the Commonwealth is reflected in the terms of the compensation payment.
The Health and Other Services (Compensation) Administration Fee Bill 1994 is being introduced with this bill.

The Administration Fee Bill introduces a fee which will be charged to insurers or compensation payers where an amount of compensation has become payable.The fee will cover ongoing running costs of the new provisions, making the recovery process self-funding.

There is a two-tiered fee system. A $150 fee will apply to cases which are finalised within five years or less of the date of the accident and a $300 fee will apply to cases finalised more than five years after that date. The higher fee for older cases reflects the higher cost associated with information storage and retrieval. It is envisaged that the higher fee for these cases may also encourage quicker resolution of compensation cases which would generally be to the advantage of the compensation claimant.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Amendments to the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973, the Health Insurance Act 1973 and the National Health Act 1953

SPEECH.PARA: Some consequential amendments are required to the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973. For example, an amendment is required to include administration of these bills as a function of the Health Insurance Commission.

Amendments are also required to the current provisions aimed at preventing double dipping in medicare and nursing home benefits; that is, to section 18 of the Health Insurance Act 1973 and section 59 of the National Health Act 1953, respectively, to reflect the new provisions.

Savings each year from these measures are estimated to be around $40 million. Costs will be approximately $9.4m in 1994-95 and subsequent years. Running costs will be fully offset by the administration fee.

Legislative changes to prevent double dipping in relation to the cost of medical services are of great importance to the Government. There can be no doubt that double dipping adds to the cost of Medicare and nursing home benefits. It also creates inequities between people with acquired disabilities who receive compensation and those who do not. The Government is committed to establishing a simple, fair system to ensure that people with disabilities who receive compensation contribute towards the cost of care which they have already received.
I commend this bill to the Senate.
HEALTH AND OTHER SERVICES (COMPENSATION) CARE CHARGES BILL 1994

This bill accompanies the Health and Other Services (Compensation) Bill 1994. In effect, it duplicates those provisions of the Health and Other Services (Compensation) Bill 1994 which relate to the recovery of medicare and nursing home benefits which have been paid to a compensable person prior to compensation becoming payable.

The need for this duplication arises from the fact that in some circumstances the recovery provisions in the main compensation bill could be construed to be a form of taxation. In case of this interpretation, the provisions must also appear in a separate bill.
I commend this bill to the Senate.
HEALTH AND OTHER SERVICES (COMPENSATION) ADMINISTRATION FEE BILL 1994
This bill accompanies the Health and Other Services (Compensation) Bill 1994.

It provides for an administration fee to be paid by insurers and compensation payers when an amount becomes payable to the Commonwealth to recover benefits paid to or in respect of a compensable person.

The fee will fund the running costs of administering the package of measures to improve the identification of compensation claimants and recipients, and the recovery of medicare and nursing home benefits paid to or in respect of a compensable person, and which were paid prior to the compensation becoming payable.
I commend this bill to the Senate.
HEALTH AND OTHER SERVICES (COMPENSATION) (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1994

This bill is an integral part of the package to improve the identification of compensation claimants and recipients and the recovery of medicare and nursing home benefits paid to or in respect of compensable people.

The bill includes amendments that are required to the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973 arising from the new provisions. For example, administration of the other three bills in this package must be included as a function of the Health Insurance Commission. The commission will act as the Commonwealth's agent for the Department of Human Services and Health in relation to recoveries of nursing home benefits in compensation cases.
Amendments are also required to section 18 of the Health Insurance Act 1973 and section 59 of the National Health Act 1953, to reflect the new provisions.

These sections will continue to operate after the commencement of the new provisions, if a person seeks medicare or nursing home benefits in respect of the injury for which they have been awarded compensation.
I commend this bill to the Senate.

The Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 contains the amendments announced by the Assistant Treasurer on 6 April 1994. These amendments inject much needed flexibility into the administration of the Scheme and close an emerging loophole where some people were avoiding their child support obligations, again placing responsibility for the financial support of their children onto the Commonwealth.

SPEECH.PARA: These twin objectives have been achieved by increasing the administrative role of the CSA in some areas, extending the rights of parents to enter into private payment arrangements, ensuring private child support agreements entered into by DSS clients provide adequate levels of child support, and aligning the child support presumptions of parentage with those in the Family Law Act 1975.
1.Presumptions of parentage

The bill brings the presumptions of parentage in the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 into line with the presumptions used in the Family Law Act 1975. Currently, the child support presumptions are limited to those where some documentary evidence exists as a basis for the presumption (for example a child born during marriage). This bill also allows the Registrar to be satisfied that a man is a parent of a child where:
that child was born to a woman married to that man within 10 months after their marriage has been annulled;

that child was born to a woman who was married to that man, separated from him, resumed cohabitation for not more than 3 months and separated again, and that child was born within 10 months after cohabitation ended and after the dissolution of their marriage; or
that child was born to a woman who cohabited with that man for a period of at least 6 months and this period included the time 10 months before the birth.

Aligning the child support presumptions of parentage with those of the Family Law Act will streamline the administrative arrangements in place between the Child Support Agency and the Department of Social Security. Currently, many custodial parents who apply for child support are required to obtain a birth certificate or a statutory declaration from the father. This can take months, and causes needless hardship to children and custodial parents deprived of support during this period. It can also create substantial arrears of child support for the non-custodial parent when the necessary proof is obtained, causing his or her liability to be back-dated to the time the application was made.
The administrative delays associated with obtaining this paperwork have contributed to significant criticism of the Scheme. This amendment will largely remove this problem.
2.Child Support Agreements

Mr President, a study conducted by the Department of Social Security has indicated that 80 per cent of agreements registered with the Child Support Agency are for amounts less than formula assessment. On average, these agreements are for 50 per cent less than formula assessment. This has the effect of transferring responsibility for the financial support of the children to the Commonwealth.

To remedy this emerging loophole in the interaction between child support and social security legislation, the bill requires the Registrar to accept child support agreements for custodial parents receiving an income tested pension, benefit or allowance when these agreements meet the Department of Social Security's requirement that the custodial parent take reasonable action to obtain maintenance.

Parents will remain free to negotiate agreements that contain a mixture of periodic, non-periodic and capitalised maintenance. However, if the custodial parent is receiving an income tested pension, benefit or allowance the combined value of cash and non-cash components in the agreement must provide adequate levels of child support.
3.Non-enforcement of certain Stage 1 cases
The bill provides for the non enforcement of amounts of maintenance payable under a Stage 1 court order or court registered agreement in two circumstances:

firstly, when a non-custodial parent's income from all sources is not more than the maximum rate of single pension and they are in receipt of an income tested pension, benefit or allowance—in practice this will usually be when the non-custodial parent is unemployed or unable to be employed through, for example a serious illness; and
secondly, when a child has left the ongoing care of the custodial parent.

In the case of a non-custodial parent's income falling below the threshold amount, he or she may apply to the Registrar to not enforce the terms of a court order or court registered agreement. Checks will be undertaken with the Department of Social Security to ensure the non-custodian's income is below this threshold and, if verified, the amounts specified in the order will no longer be collected by the Child Support Agency.

The non-enforcement period will generally be from the date of the non-custodian's application although the Registrar will have a discretion to back-date the start of this non-enforcement period to the date the person first qualified under this income test. However, the non-enforcement period will not commence earlier than the day on which child support was last collected. This will prevent overpayments of child support being made to custodial parents and the subsequent hardship to children and custodial parents that could occur through recovery of this overpayment.

Similarly, if a child leaves the ongoing care of a person named in a Stage 1 court order or court registered agreement the Registrar will, where both parents elect, no longer enforce the terms of the order or agreement as they apply to that child. Temporary absences, including normal access time and temporary short term changes to access arrangements will be ignored. Further, a child at boarding school will not be deemed to have left the care of the custodial parent. It is not the intention of this amendment to allow non-custodial parents to obtain `credits' against their liability for each and every day they care for their children. The parents must agree in writing that a substantive change in care has occurred and that it is likely to be ongoing.

It is important to note that the court order or court registered agreement will not be changed as a result of this amendment. This amendment merely gives the Registrar the ability to not enforce certain amounts for the periods involved.No debt accrues to the Commonwealth during these periods. It will always remain open to either party to have the order varied or for the custodial parent to enforce amounts in his or her own right. This amendment simply gives the Registrar the ability to not enforce a registered liability for the period involved.
4.Private collection
The bill extends the rights of custodial parents in receipt of an income tested pension, benefit or allowance to collect child support privately.

Newly registered clients receiving an income tested pension, benefit or allowance may, under the current law, elect at the outset to receive child support payments privately. Large numbers make that election and the Agency only becomes involved in collection for these clients when private arrangements fail. However, once the Agency does become involved in collection for these clients, they are not able to subsequently elect for private collection.

The amendment will introduce greater freedom for parents to make private arrangements for payment. The choice will be available to custodial parents where the non-custodial parent has a good payment record—that is, when there are no arrears outstanding at the date of election and all payments have been made on time for the six month period before the election.

If a private arrangement fails, the custodial parent will be able to elect once again to have the liability enforced by the Child Support Agency. The Registrar will be able to collect three months of arrears upon application for CSA enforcement. In exceptional circumstances the Registrar will be able to collect up to nine months of arrears.
The Explanatory Memorandum which has been circulated contains a more detailed explanation of the provisions of the bill.
Mr President, I commend the bill to the Senate.
