TALK.START.PARA: —The appropriation bills that we are now debating—Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2), Appropriation Bill (No. 3), and Appropriation Bill (No. 4)—are the three appropriation bills that constitute what are known as the additional estimates of the government. These bills provide authority for the additional appropriation moneys sought for this financial year.

PARA.TAB: The opposition will not be opposing these bills. It is not in our nature to oppose appropriation bills, of course, as has been made clear time and time again by the opposition, including the shadow Treasurer, Mr Costello, who made that point very firmly and forcibly yesterday, despite the cant of both the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Treasurer (Mr Willis). Whilst not opposing these bills, I will be moving a second reading amendment on behalf of the coalition, and that will be circulated in the course of this debate.

It is an amendment condemning the government for its failure to pursue responsible economic policies, which failure has led to a massive increase in interest rates, harming all Australian businesses, families and home buyers; continuing levels of unacceptably high unemployment; the certainty now of savage tax increases in the May 1995 budget; and a huge deterioration in Australia's balance of payments which has increased Australia's foreign debt to record levels. As a result of that, it has threatened increasingly our national independence and a continuation of the boom-bust cycles which have been the hallmark of the Labor government's disastrous performance since it came to power in 1983.

Before going into some of the details of the matters that I wish to raise in relation to the state of the economy and the government's handling of it, I want to raise an important matter so far as the remaining conduct of the debate over these appropriation bills is concerned. This year we are experiencing a new process in terms of the conduct and processing of additional estimates. I hope the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley), who is at the table, is listening to this because I am putting the government on very serious notice. Perhaps when Senator Crowley can get around to listening to this, I will continue. I am saying to the government that the opposition will not allow the passage of these appropriation bills until the proper processes laid out for this parliament to follow have been pursued.

We have struck enormous difficulty on our side of the chamber in getting from government ministers the answers to questions that were posed to them during the Senate additional estimates committee hearings in November last year. The supplementary additional estimates hearings due to take place in the next couple of weeks rely very importantly on getting answers to those questions that were asked before Christmas. There are several departments that have not yet done the Senate the courtesy of providing answers to those questions. Until those questions are answered and the answers provided, it is not possible for the Senate to formulate the necessary follow-up questions that will be undertaken in the supplementary additional estimates hearings about to take place and therefore the process cannot be properly conducted.

So I say to the government that the coalition will not allow these appropriation bills to pass unless and until the government has followed the processes that have been laid down for the proper conduct of this matter. I am staggered that the minister at the table has not had the courtesy even to listen to what I am putting to her. I would have thought that this is a matter of extreme importance for the government in terms of the pursuit of its timetable.

These appropriation bills are being debated at a time of great crisis for the Australian economy and for the government. We have a situation where yesterday the Prime Minister hit the airwaves. He had a major tantrum on air because he was questioned by a radio interviewer who had allowed the opposition to have a view on the state of the economy. The Prime Minister, when questioned, really went off his trolley because he had deigned to give an interview and then the details and his interpretation of events were questioned.

The Treasurer yesterday indicated in the strongest possible terms that he, too, has become a deficit dalek—an accusation which the Prime Minister made against those of us who had been constantly drawing attention to the need for firm fiscal policy and particularly expenditure reduction to get rid of the huge waste and duplication that this government has involved taxpayers' money in year in and year out since it took office and which we have been pursuing the government on ever since it embarked on this reckless adventure of expenditure. The Prime Minister last year accused us and anyone else who dared to question the performance of the government in the area of fiscal policy as budget and deficit wreckers, or budget daleks, or whatever term came to his mind.

Yesterday we had the Treasurer virtually admitting that the economic policies that the government has been pursuing have failed. They have failed miserably. As a result of that, we have had in the last three or four months almost a 60 per cent increase in interest rates. We have seen little fall in unemployment; it remains at unacceptably high levels. We have seen the government go absolutely dead on any form of continuing micro-economic reform, which is absolutely essential if this nation of ours is going to be able to continue to grow on a sustainable basis in the future.

We have seen an enormous blow-out in the external accounts of our nation. The Treasurer admitted yesterday that his budget estimate is going to be something like 50 per cent wrong and that the budget estimate for the current account deficit of something like $18 billion, which was far too high anyway, is now going to look more like $26 billion—almost six per cent of GDP, precisely the sort of level that the deficit was back in those dreadful days of May 1986 when the then Treasurer, now Prime Minister Keating, made his infamous banana republic statement.

At that time, the then Treasurer drew attention to the extreme dangers that the Australian economy was facing because of the blow-out of its external accounts—for other reasons as well, but particularly the external side—and he pulled the plug on the Australian economy. Down we went into another recession. Up we came until the same thing happened in 1990: down we went again. Now we are on the way up and before we are even halfway up the government is about to pull the plug on the economy again and send us on this tragic boom-bust cycle that has been so devastating to the Australian economy and to every Australian in terms of their standards of living throughout the period of this government.

The foreign debt, which was something like $23 billion when Labor came to power in 1983, is in 1995 more than $160 billion. There has been an eightfold increase in the foreign debt of this nation during the period of Labor's term of office. That is not just an economic problem. That is a problem of huge dimensions in terms of Australia's independence in the world.

We get this Prime Minister talking about our lack of independence because we happen not to be a republic. The greatest damage to our independence and our sovereignty is to have the government put the nation into hock to the rest of the world. That is precisely what the policies of this government have done throughout the period of Labor's term in office.

The interest rate situation is exacerbating the problem. Because of rising interest rates, external debt this year is going to be increased by a further $1 billion to $1 1/2 billion above the earlier estimate, simply because of rising interest rates. Interest rates are increasing in the rest of the world, but they are increasing more in Australia. In real terms, we now have the highest interest rates of any country in the industrialised world—far higher than interest rates in the countries of Asia which are amongst our major trading and competitive partners.

Despite all that the government claims it has done during its term of office, particularly in the last couple of years—we have heard all the hype in recent months about how the economy is growing—no sooner does growth start than we have a situation which takes us back automatically to the dangers and the dark days of the mid-1980s and to the recession period starting in 1990.

It is a tragedy of the highest order that all the advantages a nation like Australia has—the resources, the skills, the talent, the geographical position in relation to the fastest growing region in the world—cannot be capitalised on, cannot be used to build a sustainable economic growth, low unemployment, low interest rate, low taxation economy. Those advantages cannot be capitalised on for one reason only, and that is the gross irresponsibility of this government in managing the finances of the nation and, in particular, its total failure to pursue economic policies of a fiscal nature—the budget policy—which are appropriate to the needs and the circumstances of Australia.

I was reading with great interest yesterday the ethnic press summary of some of the commentaries in the ethnic press in Australia in recent weeks. I found a very interesting commentary in, of all papers, the Dutch Weekly in which a very experienced commentator Andries Snoek said on 20 January:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . young families-
this is the English translation—

beginning a career have hardly a good word now for the government. Interest rate rises have hit this group the hardest and Keating cannot expect them to swallow for a second time the same excuses as he gave before the recession. Thirteen years of Labor government have left the rich richer and the poor poorer, a travesty of Labor policies; big money manipulators like Bond and Skase get off practically scot free, so that Labor's principles of social justice are made a mockery. Other nails in Keating's political coffin, he says, are: the woodchip licences . . .

And anyone who has been in this city and the parliament in recent days knows just what an absolute disaster that has been created for Australian families and employment associated with the timber industry by the tremendous mess, incredible mess, the government has got itself into on this issue.

PARA.TAB: The government has virtually destroyed one of Australia's most valuable industries. It has destroyed, is destroying and will continue to destroy the livelihoods of tens of thousands of Australians and their families who are dependent on the timber industry in all its phases. That is associated with the government's failure to allow the development of new pulp and paper mills in Australia. In other words, the dead hand of Labor has prevented the growth of industry in Australia in a way which will not enable us to capitalise on the great natural advantages that we have—the skills of our people and our export potential as a nation.

So the woodchip issue—and it is not just the woodchip issue; it is a question of the whole future of the timber industry—has been an absolute disaster at the government's hands, which has continued with a tax system that hits low and middle income earners harder than the top earners and also panic stricken shoot from the hip policies and actions that this government has taken not only in the economic area, although importantly there, but also in a whole range of policy areas with which it has been associated.

The whole question of pay TV is one example. The question of aviation is another. You name it; across the political board of government actions and policies, this government has been a disaster. As a result, you have a very divided government, a government that does not know where it is going. There are reports in today's press that up to five members of the Labor Party here in Canberra, five members of parliament, could resign over the government's handling of the woodchip licences issue. One senator from Tasmania has already resigned over the issue.

There is enormous division within the government. I believe that yesterday and today's comments by the Prime Minister and the Treasurer show that they are going to be at loggerheads over the next few months on the course of economic policy. The Treasurer seems to be saying, `Let's go tough at budget time.' The Prime Minister seems to be saying, `Let's go easy; no real need for concern.'

There is great division in the top portfolios of government. Obviously the environment minister is at odds with all the other economic ministers. What we see is a tired, divisive government in a state of decay that is leading to a perpetuation of the economic and policy failures that have so damaged this country in recent years.

It is about time that we had a government which took seriously the need to control its expenditure in order to eliminate the enormous waste and duplication that is involved in its accounts. The government spends something like $120 billion a year, yet it does not seem to be able to find its way to make even minor reductions in that expenditure—minor reductions, in a relative sense, which would have an enormous effect on the whole finances of the country. The government has said—I think the Treasurer said yesterday—that it would be trying to get the budget back into balance a couple of years earlier than it was planning to do formerly; it is planning to do it in a couple of years time instead of in four years time. Big deal!

What the government ought to be doing is getting the budget back into balance here and now. The more that the government remains in deficit, the more it draws on the nation's savings. Our savings are at record low levels. The government is to be absolutely condemned for its economic failures across the board, particularly at the moment of this damaging and critical time for the Australian economy.

As I have said, we will not be opposing the appropriation bills, but we will be requiring proper process in their consideration and in their passage we will continue to maintain our condemnation of the government for its continuing failures of economic policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support my colleague Senator Short with regard to these appropriation bills. As he has said, the coalition will not be opposing these bills but proposes to use the debate to highlight the weaknesses in the government's economic policy.

PARA.TAB: The first point that needs to be made is that the government continues to hide its head in the sand over the state of the national economy. It fails to concede that the current deficit reduction strategy is exacerbating the boom and bust tendency of the economy. Although we welcome the information which came from Treasurer Willis last night and yesterday, we wonder why we have to wait until May before there is any real action from the government.

The increases in official interest rates over the past few months are evidence of the wrong direction of the government's economic policy. The government has tended to rely more heavily on monetary policy—that is, increasing interest rates—rather than a more responsible fiscal policy. Budget Paper No. 1 for 1994-95 indicates, for example, that between 1991-92 and 1995-96, as a result of its continuing deficit financing, the government will have increased public sector debt by almost $64 billion—I repeat: $64 billion.

The Commonwealth's large structural deficit has arisen not primarily as a result of cuts to taxation but as a result of large increases in spending. Between 1989-90 and 1993-94 the Commonwealth government's current outlays grew by an average rate of 8.5 per cent per year. In that time these outlays increased from 23.5 per cent of gross domestic product, GDP, to 27 per cent of GDP. The Commonwealth's own general purpose outlays—that is, excluding grants to the states and territories—are expected to grow by 7.7 per cent in this financial year to a record high of 21 per cent of GDP, the highest on record.

Over the last several years we have seen the state governments reduce their outlays quite substantially; particularly over the last three years, most state governments have reduced their outlays. But during that same period of time, during the recession, the Commonwealth government has made virtually no reductions in outlays.

Let me cite the actual real increases in expenditure by this government over the last several years. In the 1990-91 budget, the real increase in expenditure was 4.8 per cent; in 1991-92, 5.1 per cent; in 1992-93, 5.6 per cent; in 1993-94, three per cent; and in 1994-95, 3.1 per cent. They are all real increases, so you can add inflation on top of that to get the actual increases.

This government has done nothing to contain its expenditure. By comparison, all the state governments have made major efforts to contain their expenditure, trim their budgets, be more efficient and have less waste. When comparing this with the private sector, everyone in the community knows that right through the last three years of the recession every organisation in Australia had to trim its budget, get more lean and efficient and become more internationally competitive. Here we have all of Australia—apart from the Commonwealth government—trimming budgets and becoming more efficient. But the Commonwealth government has done exactly the reverse. It has kept spending taxpayers' dollars.

Today we have the result of those excesses. The economy is in trouble. We have had significant growth for a short period of time, but we now have the warning signs, because interest rates are rising fast and will continue to rise, and the government has given notice to us that it is going to increase taxes. The poorer parts of the community—the unemployed and those people in small businesses—are going to get hit again. People with mortgages have already been frightened away from the marketplace. How are they going to continue and want to invest and expand? They will not want to do so, because they are scared about what will happen in the future.

The 1994-95 Commonwealth budget made no effort to contain current outlays. Despite an improving economy, with less demand on a number of key welfare and associated transfer payments, the Commonwealth increased its current outlays by 6.6 per cent. The states, by comparison, increased their level of current outlays by 3.8 per cent in the same financial year.

The government must now concede that its fiscal priorities are wrong. It is spending too much and taxing too much. As a result of that strategy, all Australians are paying a premium on interest rates. I remind you that interest rates have gone up by 2.75 per cent at the short end in the last few months. Already the markets are signalling that they are going to go up further.

As my colleague Senator Short said before, we have the highest real interest rates in the world at the long end. Why? Because the world does not believe that this government is serious about inflation and serious about running a tight fiscal policy. As a result, everyone is paying the price.

A plea for a faster deficit reduction program was made recently by the Governor of the Reserve Bank in the bank's recent annual report. In that report, the Governor called on the government to do much better in its deficit reduction strategy. The Governor said, in essence, that the level and composition of economic growth in Australia in the years ahead would be influenced by the ability of the government to do better in its deficit reduction strategy.

That was a clear message to the Treasurer that the deficit was too high and that the deficit reduction target is not good enough. It was also a clear message to the government that, unless remedial action is taken on fiscal policy, there will be continued pressure on monetary policy which will result in unnecessary increases in interest rates.

As I said earlier, we welcomed Treasurer Willis's statement yesterday that the government is serious about bringing forward its fiscal targets of getting into surplus earlier than it indicated previously. It has brought forward the target of getting into surplus that it set at the budget last year by two years. Really, we ought to be in surplus right now. While the economy is growing at 5 1/2 per cent, and it has been at six per cent, we should be in surplus instead of in deficit.

The Reserve Bank report also highlighted the importance of a structural improvement in our national savings. That is what the coalition has been saying for a long time: get the deficit reduction down and increase savings. The most significant culprit in Australia's current dis-savings strategy is the federal government itself. The federal government can have an important impact on national savings by reducing its level of deficit financing. Unless it does that and does it quickly households will, to quote the Reserve Bank annual report, `become exposed to the risk of interest rate rises'.

The continuing adverse trends in the nation's balance of payments figures are a further illustration of the dangers that face the Australian economy unless the government is prepared to be more fiscally responsible. The government will continue to be a major contributor to the current account deficit and the growth in foreign debt because of its deficit strategy. In the 12 years to 1993-94, Australia's net foreign debt has risen from 13.4 per cent of GDP to almost 37 per cent of GDP as at the end of September last year.

A further underlying warning of the disastrous effects of running a continuing high current account deficit has recently been outlined by the Chairman of the Federal Reserve in the USA, Alan Greenspan, who has suggested that the Mexican monetary crisis may well have what he calls a contagion effect on all world economies. By definition, such an effect would lead to a drying up of capital flows, particularly to those countries, such as Australia, which run high current account deficits. The resulting devaluation of the exchange rate would require sharp increases in interest rates in order to stem the capital outflow. The magnitude of those increases would certainly stall the level of economic growth in this country.

We have heard a lot of talk from the government about the quality of its budgetary management, but the truth is that the federal government has never, in the past 11 years, reduced the real level of its own purpose spending. The government's answer to deficit reduction even now is to focus on taxation increases rather than reductions in spending. I contrast that to the attitude of the state governments and the 700,000 to 800,000 businesses in Australia that have been through cost reduction strategies over the last several years. Those people wonder why the Commonwealth government has not done more to reduce costs. For the government to claim that costs cannot be reduced from a total budget of $120 billion is ridiculous.

In the private sector, there would be no managing director worth his salt that could not achieve very substantial cost savings in whatever enterprise he is managing. I could quote my home state of Tasmania or we could look at what Victorian government has done in this regard. Both those state governments have substantially reduced expenditure in real terms over the last few years. As a consequence, they have much leaner and more efficient state government services. There is no reason in the world why the Commonwealth government could not do exactly the same thing.

Recently the Business Council of Australia and other business groups urged the government to adopt a speedier deficit reduction strategy by implementing spending cuts of $5 billion. The BCA rejects calls for taxation rises to reduce the deficit and suggests instead that there ought to be an external review of government spending to isolate those areas where expenditure could be reduced.

We have had examples in the other states where external reviews have worked well. In New South Wales, the Greiner government had an external audit of expenditure and it adopted most of the recommendations that came out of that process. The Victorian Kennett government did a similar thing. Again, that was an excellent process and it adopted most of the recommendations that came out of that process. In my home state of Tasmania I was involved for a while in setting up and helping manage an audit for the Groom government when it first came to power nearly three years ago. It was designed to do exactly the same thing and proved to be an excellent and very worthwhile process.

Earlier this month Professor Ross Garnaut, a former adviser to the Hawke government, issued a blunt warning that the budget deficit must be erased if continued economic growth was to be assured. Professor Hughes, another adviser to the government, gave similar advice. The other day Standard and Poors warned Australia that its credit rating was at risk unless the budget deficit was reduced. We welcome the Treasurer's announcement, but it is too late, not enough and there are no details about what we are going to do. Why do we have to wait until May before adopting actions to reduce the budget deficit? Why can't we do it now? If it was done now, we would relieve the pressure on interest rates, but the government says we are going to wait until May.

Let us contrast Australia's position with that of our neighbour just across the Tasman. When we in the coalition have said to the government that it has been weary on micro-economic reform and that it should look at what our neighbours across the Tasman have been doing, we have been told to avoid the New Zealand idea of freeing up the labour market; we have been told to avoid the New Zealand strategy of cutting back on wasteful government expenditure; we have been told that the New Zealand government's strategy of budgeting for a surplus and paying back foreign debt would have disastrous implications for the New Zealand economy.

For those doubters, the facts are clear and unequivocal. The New Zealand economy is currently growing at 5.3 per cent a year, with growth of 4.6 per cent forecast for the next financial year. Unemployment is expected to decline to 8.5 per cent this year and to 7.5 per cent within two years. The New Zealand budget now has a surplus—contrast that with our deficit—of 0.6 per cent of GDP, which is expected to increase to 2.7 per cent of GDP next year and 5.1 per cent of GDP by 1996-97. The budget actually went into surplus in 1993-94, three years earlier than originally expected.

The New Zealand government plans to use the increased budget surpluses—which after all are savings—to reduce New Zealand's net public debt to less than 30 per cent of GDP by 1996-97, compared with 48 per cent in 1992-93, which is much worse than that in Australia. While our federal government attempts to convince the financial markets that it is aiming for a budget deficit of one per cent by 1996-97—it announced yesterday that it intends to get into surplus by 1996-97—New Zealand will be achieving a surplus equivalent to 5.1 per cent of GDP in that year.

We can believe the New Zealand story. What has it done? It has adopted a much tougher financial strategy than this government in Australia. New Zealand people are reaping the benefits from that. As a consequence, they have much greater credibility in financial markets and hence their long-term interest rates are lower than ours. People in New Zealand do not pay as high a premium on the long-term interest rates as we do here.

This government really has made a mess of running this economy, particularly with regard to keeping its own house in order. Who can forget the One Nation statement, designed as a blatant political document with overly inflated forecasts of employment and economic growth and the promise of a return to budget surplus by 1995-96? That is right; it promised a return to surplus by next financial year. We ought to be in surplus right now. The budget target has changed on a number of occasions since then, and we are now left with a deficit path continuing to at least 1998-99.

It is a pity that the government has not taken up the task of maintaining true micro-economic reform; of running an efficient central government; of reducing its expenditure; of taking pressure off interest rates; of taking pressure off the unemployed and all businesses in Australia, particularly small business, which is badly affected by the interest rate structure; and of creating more savings in Australia. After all, in the long term, Australia's savings structure is the fundamental problem which we face. Who is the biggest culprit with regard to savings? It is the Commonwealth government itself. The sooner we get into surplus the better.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to join my colleague Senator Short today because it is very important to deal with the issues of this budget. The foreshadowed second reading amendment that Senator Short has given notice of is very important. It draws our attention to the massive increase in interest rates and the consequences that therefore flow to Australian businesses, families and particularly home buyers.

PARA.TAB: Senator Short's amendment draws our attention to the continuing levels of uncertainty caused by high unemployment. It draws our attention to the almost certain prospect of savage tax increases in the 1995 budget and what effects they will again have on families and home buyers. Senator Short's amendment draws our attention to the huge deterioration in Australia's balance of payments and the consequences that will therefore flow economically. It also draws our attention to the continuation of the unnecessary boom-bust cycles that have been the hallmark of the Labor government's disastrous performance in the last decade. Senator Short's amendment highlights and brings to our attention the need to address the issues of these appropriation bills that are before us today. From my perspective as the shadow minister for housing, I want to spend some time today looking at the effects on families and their homes and the provision of shelter.

Senator Short also commented at the beginning of his speech on the insult to this Senate directed by the government at the estimates process of this parliament. I asked a series of questions that can really illustrate the same point that Senator Short made. Eleven weeks ago, I asked a series of very important questions relating to the budget effects on housing in Australia, and the answers are not yet in. It has been 11 weeks, and the government cannot attend to the issues that have been put before it, many of them on notice and many of them on the day in the Senate estimates. After 11 weeks, none of that information has yet flowed through to the Senate. Had I put those questions on notice on the formal Notice Paper of this Senate, the government would have had to respond to them within 30 days or face the appropriate questioning that would have taken place in this parliament. After 11 weeks, we are here today debating this important information while none of the government replies are yet on the table. It is an appalling disgrace.

I have had similar experiences in the portfolios of transport and the Prime Minister's department relating to the issues of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs. None of those answers was supplied. As Senator Short said, whilst we will not be opposing this legislation, we will certainly not give passage to it until all of that appropriate Senate estimates information has been tabled and made available.

Let me highlight what answers I was keen to receive before this debate in the areas that vitally interest me but which have not yet been provided. I wanted information on housing statistics, Aboriginal housing, affordability levels in housing and how they affect average Australians, the better cities program and the Australian Housing and Urban Research Institute. All of those answers are crucial and very relevant to the debate here today.

There has been a lot of media discussion in the past few weeks as the Minister for Housing and Regional Development and Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Howe, has toured around the country with a propaganda machine putting out very prophetic speeches relating to urban development and the future. But I notice in all his statements that Mr Howe did not address any of the detailed questions that I put to him 11 weeks ago. He did not address those specific issues, yet he has the capacity to dream about the nature of the future of Australia and the grand design of new urban development that he foresees. But, when you get down to it, it is all really nothing more than a lot of extra consultancies and bits of money being handed out to mates of either the minister or the government in that area. They are trying to create new industries in exporting our housing potential internationally in order to keep a few jobs in specific areas. However, they will not provide housing for struggling Australians in many of these areas.

Mr Howe's propaganda machine is well and truly gearing up for what he says will be a major housing initiative statement in May. That will follow the housing ministers conference of the Commonwealth and state housing ministers in April, when a new Commonwealth-state housing agreement is to be structured. All Mr Howe will do is pick up off the table the pieces of a new program. So Mr Howe, with his new universal social protection umbrella or the new social justice agenda of this country, is really only responding to a lot of adjectives. There are no hard facts. The questions that were asked 11 weeks ago have not been answered. It is disgraceful that he has not addressed all of those issues.

We need to look very carefully at the blow-out in the public housing waiting lists around Australia. We need to concentrate the pressure back on the government. We need to ask the government what is causing those problems in public housing, which Minister Howe wants to address, as he said in his recent statements, by involving the private sector much more in public housing. He is looking for a scapegoat. The problems he did not address in any of his recent statements relate to interest rate management and the effects that has on home owners, home buyers, people renting and the whole housing industry in Australia. Other problems relate to the consequences of unemployment for Australian families in regard to housing issues.

As I said earlier—and it was addressed in Senator Short's amendment—we need to look at the effects of the current account deficit and its blow-out. The deficit in 1994-95 will be about $24 billion. It was $16 billion last year and it will rise to over $29 billion next year. The OECD expects Australia to have the highest current account deficit as a percentage of GDP in the developed world in 1995 and 1996. Australia's deficit represents about five per cent of GDP—worse than the US, with 2.4 per cent; the UK, with 1.1 per cent; and Canada, with 3.3 per cent. The effects of the current account deficit need to be addressed.

We had a foreign debt of $160 billion as at the end of September 1994. The high interest rates are certainly horrific, are certainly having consequences and are certainly hitting the pockets of every Australian family at the moment, particularly through their home mortgages and home loan interest rates. Our interest rates are among the highest in industrial countries. Australia has the lowest level of savings for fifty years. These are the facts that the government needs to deal with. What about unemployment and the effects on Australia of the fact that nearly 800,000 people are currently out of work? It is the interest rates and the poor investment levels—Mr Keating's and Mr Howe's responsibility—that we have now inherited that we have to look at.

There is an increasing gap between the rich and the poor. The recently retired Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, can afford a brand new beautiful castle on the north shore of Sydney, and can quit that home if he likes and go and live in the Ritz hotel. I would hate to know the daily housing rate he must be paying—or someone is paying. We have the present Prime Minister, Mr Keating, buying $2 two million houses at the top of the housing market in the nice suburbs of Sydney. But what about addressing the problems of the average Australian? Obviously Mr Hawke and Mr Keating have been able to manage their financial affairs under a very differently structured arrangement.

The business outlook, particularly as it impacts on mortgages, shows a disastrous scene. The biggest losers are the young married couples with two kids and a mortgage, earning $800 a week, with private health insurance and their own car. Their gains since 1990 from the lower mortgage rates have been mostly offset by rapidly rising health insurance costs. In the period ahead they will have the added weight of higher mortgage costs. That comes from a statement from the Business Review Weekly looking at some work compiled by Access Economics. That prophecy will affect hundreds of thousands of average Australian families. What about the quote that surfaced yesterday in the report, that was tabled here, of the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation? I refer to the section on arrears at page 9 of that report:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it is interest rates that will determine the level of housing loan default over the next two years. Other factors to be taken into account are an increase in the proportion of loans in excess of 90 per cent loan-to-value ratio and a perceived general decline in loan quality due to intense competition in the home loan market.

PARA.TAB: HLIC expects the level of default to increase towards the end of 1994-95 and to continue to increase in the following year.

SPEECH.PARA: What a prognosis and an expectation for average Australian families that the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation has alerted us to that particular area. Buying a home usually represents the single largest lifetime investment for Australian families and involves substantial financial obligations, including maintenance, rates, insurance and mortgage repayments. The traditional means of assessing home affordability is to consider the magnitude of typical mortgage repayments for a typical home purchase and relate these to movements in household income. Family and individual home buyers have to consider how affordable a home is likely to be over a number of years rather than in only the first year. The Keating government has severely shaken home buyers' confidence with increases in mortgage repayments and persistent talk of further increases in interest rates and taxes.

PARA.TAB: What does the government have to say to those Australians who now find themselves struggling with mortgage repayments and who, through no fault of their own, are paying the price of this government's inability to manage the economy? What does the Labor government say to home buyers who may be forced to on-sell their properties at a loss? What does it say to the home buyers whose loans have become uncapped after one or two years of fixed honeymoon mortgages and now find their repayments have increased to a level that they did not anticipate and they are just able or unable to meet their commitments? What does the Labor government have to say to young home buyers who find themselves owing more on their homes than they are worth because of climbing interest rates?

Let us look at the other people who are caught in this net, the people who are tenants or renters of homes. Let us look at the effect of rising interest rates on families and individuals who rent their homes. Those Australians are among the hidden victims of the interest rate strategy. They will be hurt along with the home buyers. Landlords will need to push up rents to cover their mortgage commitments, and the people caught in the private rental sector will struggle with tighter household budgets as a consequence because their rents will rise. For many of these families, the deposit gap will widen and, therefore, it puts off the prospect of being able to move into the home buying area.

In the public housing area we will see increasing waiting lists and pressure back on the government through the Commonwealth-state housing agreement. The latest Real Estate Institute of Australia figures released a few days ago confirm the widening gap between home mortgage repayment and wage rises. That survey revealed that home loan affordability has fallen in three consecutive quarters of 1994, that higher mortgage interest repayments rose by 8.8 per cent during the September quarter while the medium family income increased by 0.7 per cent. The medium family income needed to service an average housing loan rose from $32,680 in the June quarter to $35,545 in the September quarter.

The Labor government has created a housing market where home buyers at the top and prestige end of the market are able to absorb the higher interest rates while low to middle income home buyers at the other end of the market struggle. The Hawkes and the Keatings can cope, but Mr and Mrs Smith in Bankstown cannot cope. I am surprised that Mr Keating does not understand this.

The government has created new class divisions between home owners. With house prices at various levels, there are starts and falls at the bottom end of the market while people at the top end surge ahead. All of the peak groups, whether in the housing industry or the construction and building industry, or those relating to welfare and social issues, have attacked the government over its interest rate strategy. It is worth putting just a couple of quotes on the record. Mr Bob Lim of the Business Council of Australia said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . interest rates hit production and investment. It is critical that production and investment continues to grow. The thought of further rises sent shivers through the ranks of industry, particularly mining, agriculture and small business.

Of course, consequential to that are the effects on families that work in those industries. Mr Ian Spicer of the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry said business confidence will be hit hard, and plans for purchasing new plant and equipment would have to be reconsidered. What effects will that have on all of the thousands of Australians and Australian families caught up in this?

PARA.TAB: The President of the NFF said the interest rate rises were a major blow to farmers struggling to survive the drought. The Chief Executive of the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia, Mr Rob Bastian, said that small business, almost totally reliant on varying rate loans, regarded the spectre of high interest rates, particularly combined with the prospect of increasing taxes on consumers, as an horrific overkill to cool the economy. Father David Cappo of the Australian Catholic Social Welfare Commission said interest rate rises would harm lower income earners and hit investors. He said that the government has hurt the most vulnerable in our society and that Australian families should not have to shoulder the responsibility of getting the right mix in Australia's monetary and fiscal policies.

If we look at building approvals we see that for the third month in a row they have slumped. Industry groups fear the housing sector is heading for a nosedive. The market is predicted to fall further, which will mean big job losses. The Housing Industry Association predicts up to 30,000 jobs could be lost this year as construction plummeted under the weight of higher interest rates. Master Builders Association National Economic and Housing Director, Mr Wilhem Harnisch, said the fall in building approvals demonstrated the `devastating' impact recent interest rate rises were having on the housing industry.

Meanwhile, we have the Deputy Prime Minister and the housing minister, Mr Howe, trying to play down industry concerns by saying that the downturn in housing activity was `quite a good thing' in the context of an overheating economy. But the housing minister, Mr Howe, has acknowledged that the government should shift the focus towards fiscal policy to control the economy. On the other hand, his Prime Minister continues to stubbornly resist calls to cut the budget deficit further to ease the pressure on interest rates and is intent on imposing on Australian home buyers and renters—never let us forget those people who are caught in the rent market—the suffocating high rates of the 1980s. So we have a predicament where the housing and finance figures, the construction figures and the anecdotal evidence for actual work coming out of all the particular groups illustrate this more and more.

After 12 years in office and a plethora of reports, strategies, visions, agendas and reviews, this federal Labor government has ignored the housing and poverty crisis in Australia. The economic and administrative policies during this time have complicated and compounded the problems in the public housing area. It is very necessary that, in the lead-up to the April-May statements, Mr Howe addresses some very desperate issues needing attention for reform in public housing. Will the Howe statement—whenever it comes; whenever it surfaces—reveal the full detail? Will the answers I asked for 11 weeks ago surface? Will the issues be addressed? Will my questions be answered? The question we must ask of Mr Howe is: can he deliver on his new vision, or is he just putting more hype into the equation just for the next federal election?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Debating appropriation bills provides one with an opportunity to raise issues that often do not receive much attention, and to put the focus on areas of government neglect and mismanagement. What has concerned me over a long period is that this Labor government trumpets loud and long about what it allegedly does for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in this country, and yet it is totally neglecting some very vital areas of health concern among those communities. I wish to focus on that today.

PARA.TAB: While the Senate Community Affairs Legislation Committee was considering the estimates in November last year a question was asked about a very important issue relating to AIDS in Aboriginal communities. The disturbing response is something that needs much closer attention. The response from the Department of Human Services and Health was that there are `no national publicly available statistics on HIV-AIDS in Aboriginal communities' and that the decision to record such statistics was up to the communities themselves as they had previously indicated that they do not wish to have Aboriginality identified at a national level.

What is inherently a national problem, a global problem in fact, is left up to the state and territory health authorities to manage. It is also their responsibility to collect and collate the statistics for Aboriginal communities, and this can only be done if the sufferer identifies himself or herself as being Aboriginal.

In my state of Western Australia, according to evidence given at the estimates hearing, the incidence of HIV/AIDS in the Aboriginal communities in the north-west has crept up above the national rate of infection. I find that particularly disturbing, but so should this government. I put a question on notice back on 9 December asking the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) what records were being kept, what was being done about it, and about the identification. It would not surprise anyone to know that I still have not got a response—because it is contradictory to say that no records are being kept. Yet the rate of HIV/AIDS infection in the northern communities of Western Australia is above the national average. How can the statement be made? There must be some records being kept and, if there are not, why not? Why isn't the focus on education much stronger?

Last year I also spoke on the poor living conditions in the northern Western Australian Aboriginal communities, especially those in the Kimberley such Oombulgurri, which is alleged to be the most poorly resourced community in Western Australia with its residents living in Third World conditions. This government, as I say, trumpets loud and long about the treatment of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. It is simply neglecting them. In Oombulgurri and many other remote communities there is a chronic infestation rate of scabies; threadworm; hookworm; trachoma; gastroenteritis; ear, chest and skin infection; chronic diarrhoea; and sexually transmitted disease. What is this government doing to resolve those very serious problems in those communities? The answer is simply nothing. Houses overflow with raw sewage, and infection is spread rapidly by flies and inadequate housing and hygiene. Alcoholism also has an iron grip on these communities. This in turn leads to unsafe sexual practices, among many other things.

These poor living conditions, matched with the often unsafe and promiscuous sexual patterns of the people living there, are creating the perfect environment for an AIDS epidemic, and this government should be focusing on how to resolve the problem. It is claimed that these living conditions will also see Aboriginal people die more quickly than most people after contracting the virus because of their general state of poor health and lack of available medical care.

A full-blown AIDS epidemic would be devastating to the members of those communities, who are largely untouched by AIDS education campaigns and who are unfamiliar with the cause of the messages conveyed in advertisements describing the grim reaper, symbolic games of russian roulette and the beds campaign or the `be safe, be sure' message. Those campaigns are not relevant to those communities, so there is no point in this government pointing out to me the amount of money that it is spending on AIDS education when none of that education is targeted specifically to those communities to which I am now referring. They are totally untouched by printed literature, as many of them, of course, are unable to read the material.

It is evident from reports of the growing incidence of syphilis in Aboriginal communities that an HIV epidemic is simply a time bomb waiting to happen. Is anything being done to prevent that time bomb exploding? The answer, apparently, is no. If I could get an answer out of the Minister for Human Services and Health, Dr Lawrence, we might be able to see some light on the horizon, but she refuses to even answer the questions. One can only assume there are no answers and there are no directions being taken. If STDs are continuing to take hold at the current rate, then it follows that the same unsafe sexual practices which are causing cross-infection will also lead to the spreading of the AIDS virus. In the federal government's national HIV/AIDS strategy 1993-94 to 1995-96 it was noted:

SPEECH.PARA: There is an urgent need to continue and strengthen cooperative efforts to increase knowledge and practice of safe sex and safe drug injecting practices in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities. The continuing low health status and the high levels of alcohol use and sexually transmitted diseases in some of these communities and high rates of incarceration amongst Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people are indicators of conditions which would potentially facilitate the spread of HIV.
In view of that statement in the government's own strategy, what efforts have been made, what effects have they had and at what cost? The strategy also stated:

The available data on HIV and AIDS in the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander population indicate rates that are comparable to the non-Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australian population. However, the high level of STD's reported from a number of parts of Australia with higher proportions of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander populations indicates the potential for a substantial increase in HIV transmission, given the evidence that other sexually transmitted diseases are both markers of sexual practice and enhance the transmission of HIV.

Evidence of this appeared in an article in the West Australian on 9 January 1995 headed `Aboriginal syphilis shock'. In that report it was claimed that syphilis has become almost exclusively an Aboriginal disease, with the rate of infection in WA Aboriginal males at 386.5 per 100,000. That figure compares with a non-Aboriginal rate of three per 100,000. Among Aboriginal females the rate is 391.4 per 100,000, compared with a rate of 2.2 per 100,000 in non-Aboriginal females. Aborigines as young as 13 were found to have the disease. The incidence of congenital syphilis—babies contracting the disease from the mother—was also of concern.

PARA.TAB: Statistics on gonorrhoea are also unfavourable, with 1,000 Aborigines per 100,000 suffering the disease, compared with a rate of 180 per 100,000 in the non-Aboriginal population. Those statistics are very alarming. For the government to be sitting on its hands doing absolutely nothing is unacceptable to the extreme. Again it was stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . an increase in the incidence of syphilis is likely to be an important indicator of changes in patterns of sexual behaviour which may in turn influence the transmission of HIV.

Additionally, in the Australian in December last year a black wave of the epidemic was reported. In that report, health authorities claimed that the epidemic was in its first silent phase, with transmission occurring but the infection not present long enough in the community for people to present themselves with AIDS illnesses. In that same article, Dr Frank Bowden, head of AIDS and sexually transmitted disease programs in the Northern Territory health department, was reported as saying that forecasts based on health and social trends in the community indicated a doubling time of the epidemic of about one year, which was in line with African and South-East Asian communities. He also, quite alarmingly, I believe, estimated that the speed of the epidemic suggested that up to 20 per cent of the territory's Aboriginal population could be infected by the year 2000, a figure which he said was concerning and bound to worsen.

PARA.TAB: With those particular figures coming from professional people, why is this government doing nothing to prevent this problem? It is clear that plenty of money is being poured into nationwide advertising campaigns, education campaigns and AIDS organisations and advisory bodies, but that information is not getting to the Aboriginal communities. In last year's budget paper, for example, the government set aside $58.5 million for the treatment of AIDS patients in public hospitals and promised an allocation of $54.3 million in 1994-95 in the form of grants for education and prevention, treatment, care and training, the national public education campaign and research activities. Incidentally, its estimate for 1995-96 is $50.4 million—almost $4 million less.

As with most of the government's directions in health, it would seem that much more money is being spent on treatment than on critical research and prevention programs which would ultimately save it a great deal of money in the long term. But the government would seem to be totally and utterly myopic on this issue, as with many other health issues. The attitude of this government is to throw money at the problem after it has happened instead of preventing it happening in the first place.

There is also a program of matched funding under which each state and territory receives a base grant of $250,000 with remaining funds being split according to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander population, total population and the number of people living with AIDS.

As an aside, I point out that in the 1994-95 budget the federal government committed $110 million of the foreign aid budget to a four-year health initiative focusing in part on HIV/AIDS in countries in the Asia-Pacific region with the aim being to help overcome the growing incidence of the disease in the region. The motivation, according to a related budget paper, is that HIV is a domestic concern for Australia and growing tourism and economic linkages with countries in the region could potentially increase the incidence of infection in Australia. Probably no-one would deny that and probably no-one would say that that money should not be spent, but when there is a problem right at your back door, with your own communities getting no money and no specific research being done, you really have to question why you send money offshore.

What is not so clear is how much money allocated for AIDS-related health programs within Australia is being specifically targeted at Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people living in remote northern communities. Furthermore, it is also unclear whether any of the $40 million set aside for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander health funds will specifically cover effective AIDS education and awareness in those communities.

In 1992, the same year that the first National Aboriginal HIV/AIDS Conference took place in Alice Springs, a paper entitled AIDS policy—have we got it right? was presented to the Australian Doctors Fund in Sydney by Stanley Nangala, chairman of the communicable diseases advisory panel within ATSIC. He intended to bring to the forum an Aboriginal point of view on the AIDS issue.

In his paper, Mr Nangala argued that the government must consider a number of urgent policy directives including the provision of more information on HIV/AIDS to Aboriginal leaders to encourage them to put it higher on their agendas; the provision of culturally appropriate and locally based education programs which explain the threat of AIDS, how it is spread and how it can be prevented; and the provision of programs to target specific Aboriginal groups such as the young, young homosexuals or bisexuals, and drug injectors.

With no proper research being done, there is also great concern that there is no documentation on the spread of AIDS in the heterosexual community. As with the rest of the community, with this disease you cannot simply focus on one area and say, `We have done our job.' We have to have a total perspective.

While there is some criticism over the effectiveness of culturally appropriate programs and interfering with the objectives of more general strategies, there is no argument that education, followed by safer sexual and drug using practices, is probably the answer. But it needs to be targeted. How many of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities in Australia have been consulted as the most appropriate way for this to be handled?

Following on from that, part of the national HIV/AIDS strategy referred to the need for special ATSIC education initiatives. In the 1993-94 report on social justice for indigenous Australians, these were described as being a series of projects including television commercials, workshops and the development of community support systems for Aboriginal health care workers to be coordinated within guidelines of the Australian National Council on AIDS. Yet, overall there is still a piecemeal approach to this problem and a more holistic approach is desperately needed before it is too late.

There is currently no national data available. Consequently, I would argue that there can be no forward planning at the federal level by the Department of Human Services and Health, by the National Council on AIDS or by any other body. If the minister would care to answer some questions, we might find out what the direction of this is. But Mr Nangala argued in his article that the recording of racially based data would set Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people up for further discrimination. That might be so, but without it I would argue that they are being set up for a big let down again by the federal government when it comes to programs on HIV and AIDS.

I do not think it is paternalistic at all to say that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities are going to have a problem managing such data and developing appropriate solutions on their own. They are already facing a number of monolithic obstacles which have prevented them from taking better care of their communities and this is greatly hindered by the federal government's reluctance to offer more definite assistance in health management issues. Aboriginal communities can still retain their culture and their dignity while simultaneously seeking help on the AIDS issue and other issues from the federal government. Without that help, it can be argued that the federal government is doing nothing but writing a recipe for genocide.

The late Australian of the Year Fred Hollows warned us in May 1992 that it should be obvious that Aboriginal communities could be decimated by AIDS as they were by the smallpox epidemics of 1789 and 1829. At One Arm Point, north-west of Derby in Western Australia, the chairman of the Bardi community, Mr Eric Hunter, was reported in February last year as agreeing with Professor Hollows and expressing a grave fear not only for his people but also for those in communities around Derby, Fitzroy Crossing and Halls Creek where the AIDS message is simply not getting through.

It is true that it is only pure luck that AIDS has not swept through the Aboriginal communities in northern Australia. All the early indications are there, with the STD infection rates, that the time bomb is threatening to go off. To record data on the basis of Aboriginality might be paternalistic to some and discriminatory to others, but even ATSIC wants more to be done. Just last year the deputy chairman of ATSIC, Sol Bellear, told a conference of the Interdepartmental Group on HIV/AIDS that the virus posed a terrible threat to communities in remote Australia and that it was a miracle the predicted AIDS catastrophe had not yet occurred.

More importantly, as a representative of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, Mr Bellear criticised the lack of national data and statistics on the spread of AIDS in Aboriginal communities. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: We do not know what the current situation is. We do not know the incidence or rate of infection for much of remote and rural Australia. The reality is that HIV/AIDS poses a terrible threat to many of our communities as long as conditions remain as they are. Why is there such complacency? Is it because this issue seems far too difficult and the communities far too remote? Many Aboriginal leaders are deeply disturbed by the possibility of yet another tragedy confronting indigenous Australians in the form of an HIV/AIDS epidemic. If action is not taken then in the eyes of the world Australia will be found guilty and condemned of no less a crime than that of the genocide of its indigenous peoples.
Our luck cannot last forever. Something has to happen and I call on this government to act immediately. On behalf of Senator Short, I move:
At the end of the motion, add:
"but the Senate condemns the Government for its failure to pursue responsible economic policies, which failure has lead to:

PARA.TAB: (a)a massive increase in interest rates which harm all Australian businesses, families and home buyers;
(b)continuing levels of unacceptably high unemployment;
(c)the certainty of savage tax increases in the 1995 budget;
(d)a huge deterioration in Australia's balance of payments which has increased Australia's foreign debt to record levels and threatened our national independence; and
(e)a continuation of the boom/bust cycles which have been the hallmark of the Labor Government's disastrous performance since it came to power in 1983".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are here today debating the appropriation bills as we usually do at this time of year with the new system we have. I would like to congratulate Senator Knowles on her exposing the very sad situation that exists amongst Aborigines. I know it exists in Western Australia and what she said probably extends all over Australia. I certainly hope that what she had to say will be taken on board by the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) and also the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner). HIV/AIDS is a real problem and the first problem that has to be addressed.

PARA.TAB: We are, again, in the middle of a boom-bust cycle, which is the hallmark of this government. I would prefer to call these bills the `misappropriation bills' rather than the `appropriation bills'. When I use the term `misappropriation', I do not mean it in a criminal sense or anything like that. I mean `misappropriated' as in that things have been put in the wrong places. That is what I believe.

Unfortunately, the boom-bust cycle damages not only the boom-bust industries that we have in Australia. The most damage that is done is to the stable industries of Australia—the ones that year in, year out, provide Australia's foreign export income. In this category I place the gold industry, although it has not been of the boom-bust type in the last 15 years; the coal industry, which is a very even industry that keeps going over the years supplying export income; and all primary industries with the exception of wool.

Wool had a massive downturn from 1988 to 1993, but that was through the fault of no one other than that of its so-called leaders of that time. I include in that the government and the then minister for primary industry in that they listened to the demands for the implementation of a scurrilous wool marketing plan that led to the downfall of that industry. Fortunately, that industry is reviving now. We do not have a great boom and bust in primary industries, although the boom and

SPEECH.PARA: bust mentality of this government certainly knocks them around no end.

PARA.TAB: It is interest rates that cause generally stable industries to boom and bust. As I said, they include the coal industry, primary industry, the gold industry and quite a few others. Those industries most of all need interest rates to remain stable. The biggest effect that interest rates have on those industries occurs when they come to purchase new plant. New plant is required on an ongoing basis. No industry and no business within any industry can afford to let its plant run down. It must keep its plant up. It must have a plant replacement schedule and keep that going over the years.

Hgher interest rates, or a massive rise in interest rates as we have had from this government in the last four or five months, cause businesses to delay purchasing new plant as part of their schedule. Once you have postponed acquiring an item of plant that should be replaced—one that has outlived its useful purpose or life—greater problems arise because you have more frequent and bigger breakdowns which become costly, yet you cannot afford not to repair them. The way to carry a good plant is to have a plan and stick to it, turning that plant over every three, five or seven years, or whatever may be appropriate as to the length of time that particular item of plant may last. So higher interest rates, and particularly higher interest rates which occur suddenly, throw plant replacement schedules out.

Then, of course, more in the area of primary industry, is the situation where interest rates badly affect people with their ongoing equipment. They may borrow money, say, to put in a crop, as many farmers do every year, and then repay that loan at the end of harvesting; high interest rates knock that budget around right from the word go. Then, too, a primary producer who wants to expand and buy the farm next door when it becomes available, or farm in a higher rainfall or lower rainfall area, is affected by a sudden rise in interest rates.

That is the trouble with this government with its boom-bust mentality and cycle that is occurring: it is knocking around and damaging the basic industries that keep Australia going. The government must be condemned for that.

Promises were made to us in the last federal election—the election that was won by this government by about 1,250 votes, if I can remember back that far—of no new taxes and no increases in taxes. As I said earlier, these appropriation bills are more about how money is misappropriated rather than the government's willy-nilly changing of directions with the appropriating of money to try to keep on side its diminishing number of supporters.

We have seen this happen in the last week. Workers in the forest industry are surrounding Parliament House, and they were still here this morning. They have changed their plans halfway through because they have budgeted on getting so many logs out. The mills have budgeted on getting so many logs, and they have contracts with overseas companies to supply certain orders. Then the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) makes a big change in direction because he can see some greenie, loony, leftie votes going out the door. The government makes those decisions on the run that damage the industries of Australia.

What I am on about is priority. I do not expect the government to spend more money. I am calling on the government to spend money wisely and to appropriate it to where it should be going, not to branch off down rabbit warrens where it thinks money is needed at different times just to keep a few voters onside. Of course, 1,200 votes made a big difference last election. Those sorts of votes can make a big difference in the next election.

While I am talking about the `no new taxes' and `no higher taxes', I will mention the carbon tax. Anyone who watched our Treasurer, Mr Willis, last evening on TV would have seen that he did not rule out a carbon tax. No doubt we will debate the carbon tax when the government introduces it in the next budget, but I would like to give the government a bit of advice while it is talking about a carbon tax. A carbon tax, as the name implies, is to encourage operators of plant or whatever to put less carbon into the atmosphere.

I suppose one could say that it is a fair enough move to have a tax to cut down that carbon content in the atmosphere. But if you are talking about the increase in carbon in the atmosphere and you are thinking of penalising industries that put carbon into the atmosphere, I believe that you should give credit to the other side, to the industries that reduce carbon in the atmosphere. Of course, the biggest reducers of carbon in the atmosphere are farmers right around the world who plant crops of whatever sort.

TALK.START.PARA: —And sustainable forest industries.

—Yes, I am coming to the forests, Senator Campbell. I was not going to forget the forest industry, especially this week. Of course, new plantations of forests do the same thing. I am looking forward to that item in the budget that will credit the rural industries for what they plant and for their approach to carbon tax, and credit the forest industry for what it does. I had better not use up too much time on that one.

PARA.TAB: I believe that the greatest area of misplaced funds in this budget, the last budget and the next budget to come is on roads. You do not need me to tell you how important roads are for the welfare of Australian industry. Of more importance to me are the roads in Western Australia, where we produce 25 per cent, and rising, of Australia's foreign export income.

Since 1983—and I will give you more definite figures later—there have been massive increases in fuel taxes and cuts in road funding. One could excuse the government for massive increases in fuel taxes. I always say `fuel taxes'. A lot of people call them `petrol taxes', but fuel is right across the board. You could excuse the government, but when such taxes are just used as a milking cow to fund its own favourite programs, I believe that it wants to be taken to task. While that has been going on, road funding has been continually going down.

Mr Keating has massively increased fuel taxes since the ALP came into office in 1983. Fuel taxes affect the cost of everything around Australia. Since the last election, which is not quite two years ago, the cost of the fuel excise to the average motorist and every family is $150 a year. In that short time the fuel excise levy has risen from 26c to 32c and it is going up further.

At 21 August 1973 the excise in Australia was 4.905c per litre, which is almost 5c. It took one month short of 10 years for it to increase to 7.155c. So in the 10 years from August 1973 to 1 July 1983 it moved only 2c. It is very obvious why it changed in 1983. Then from 1 July 1983 to 1 August 1994—that is 11 years—it has gone from 7.155c to 32.088c and rising. You have had a 500 per cent increase. In 10 years of coalition government it went up by 2c, and in 10 years of Labor government, it has gone up by 500 per cent. The government should be condemned for that.
