TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I will now mention the issue of road funding or the lack of road funding in Western Australia. Western Australia has a road network of 170,000 kilometres. Its road assets at the present moment stand at $15 billion, but they are depreciating at $80 million per year. Western Australia has a 16-year, $1.2 billion backlog in road re-building.

PARA.TAB: Western Australia supplies 25 per cent of Australia's foreign export income and that 25 per cent of Australia's foreign export income comes mainly from rural and very remote areas. The minister at the table, who represents Western Australia, knows how far those commodities are transported by road, rail or whatever to get to the ports. He should know and the Senate should know that good roads are important for Western Australia for that reason.

Australia leads the world in the amount of road transport per capita. Because of the size and extent of our continent and because our mineral resources are situated in very remote areas, that is understandable. Western Australia's state freight task is growing at a rate of 10 per cent per annum. This is because of the expansion of the rural resource sectors of Western Australia which has, incidentally, resulted from the rapid change since the Court coalition government came to power. The road task is expanding by 10 per cent a year. Because of the lack of funding from the Commonwealth, funding for national roads is going backwards. Western Australia's freight task is growing by 10 per cent per annum and accounts for 12 per cent of the nation's freight task—that is, 12 per cent of Australia's road task is in Western Australia.

I wish to discuss road safety, which is very important. There were 34,410 road accidents in Western Australia in 1993. Of course, we all know the cost of road accidents. The cost of road accidents in Western Australia is $1 billion per annum, or $600 per person per year. The road environment is a causative factor of those accidents, and I have plenty of statistics to prove this point.

I would also like to mention the black spot program which Mr Robert Brown introduced into Australia some four or five years ago. Admittedly, I criticised it at the time as an election gimmick that would see funds being spent in marginal seats. But I admit that it was a good program. As it proved to be a good program, I thought this government might continue with it.

The national highways system was defined in 1974. Western Australia now has 4,650 kilometres of national highways; that is, 25 per cent of the national network. Western Australia receives only 7.03 per cent of federal funding allocations for national highways. This compares with 11.70 per cent in 1985-86 and 9.92 per cent in 1975-76. In other words, during the time that the state and national Labor governments have been in power, Western Australia's share of highways has reduced dramatically. We have not got the share that we deserve when you take into account what we produce and the amount that we pay in fuel levies. You would think that the disgraced previous Labor government of Western Australia would have at least tried to keep its roads up if it had friends in Canberra, but it failed to do so.

Federal allocations for state and national highways in Western Australia should be increased to a level that will provide what we need and deserve. They should be increased by $40 million per year, but unfortunately that has not happened. We are in the unfortunate situation where the state Liberal-National coalition government of Western Australia has had to increase the state franchise fuel levy by 4c per litre.

I can assure honourable senators that every cent that comes out of the fuel franchise levy in Western Australia goes back to roads. It is a pity that other state governments around Australia do not do the same. It is a pity that this federal government does not reinstate the proper priority to Western Australia's roads. The government should be condemned for its mismanagement not only of roads but of everything else in these appropriation bills or, as I said, `misappropriation bills'. We look forward to better days under a Howard Liberal-National coalition government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the problems with the appropriation debate, and I guess with economics generally, is that the jargon, the figures and the terminology that get bandied around mean almost nothing to the poor Australian taxpayers out there who are wondering whether the sun will come up tomorrow as far as the future of their jobs is concerned. We have been reminded of this every day this week when we have come into this place. The fine people who have surrounded the building with their trucks, their plant and their equipment remind us of their lives and their futures.

PARA.TAB: The fact that we have so many of Australia's hard working small business people out there—the loggers and the truck drivers, the people who are the backbone of this economy and who produce wealth, as opposed to the many good people who live here in Canberra and who redistribute that wealth—is a very good reminder to politicians and bureaucrats. They can see the trucks and those people out there and are able to stop and talk to them to share some of their experiences.

In terms of the appropriations debate, many of those people fear that, because of the government's mishandling of this logging issue, they simply will not have jobs and small businesses to return to when they leave Canberra at the end of this most laudable protest. The consequences of that for them and their families would be devastating. But, in terms of the annual appropriations of the Commonwealth government, those individuals and their businesses would go from being net contributors to the Australian economy and the Commonwealth in terms of paying tax, company tax, export revenue and sales taxes to creators of a net reduction in Commonwealth revenues because they would go on to the dole and receive their income from the Commonwealth rather than give it to the Commonwealth. That is a very cold and crude analysis of the logging debate. Having spent some hours talking to many loggers over the last few days, I know that many of them are very worried about having to lose their businesses, jobs, trucks and livelihoods. One gentleman last night said that he has never been out of work all his life. He has worked from four in the morning until late at night virtually every day of his life. He never gets to see his kids because they are in bed when he goes off to work in the morning and are usually in bed by the time he gets home. He works very hard for this nation. He fears that the blundering of this Keating government and its failure to balance this important economic development against sensible environmental management issues will hurt these people and the Australian economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —And exacerbate the situation.
—As Senator Sandy Macdonald interjects quite correctly, it will exacerbate our absolutely appalling foreign debt situation.

PARA.TAB: In preparation for this contribution to the appropriations debate, I looked at some of the deficit figures, spending figures and taxing figures that surround us in the national economic debate at the moment. It really makes one wonder what the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has learnt since he made his famous banana republic speech in the late 1980s. In terms of the performance of the Australian economy and its fundamental institutional framework, nothing has really changed since Mr Keating made that speech. We have been through one of the worst busts in the history of Australia and, according to Mr Keating, a recession we had to have.

We have now entered a new boom. John Howard put it very nicely on Monday when he said that the Australian people are wondering how well off Australia really is after five minutes of economic sunlight. It must appear that way to so many people with the Prime Minister, the Treasurer (Mr Willis) and the various ministers saying how well Australia is going. People in the community are saying, `It might be great for you guys, the people who have jobs and the friends of the Labor Party, but it is very tough for us, particularly those of us who do not have jobs.'

The Australian has printed a very disturbing article on the attitudes of young people in this nation to the economic outlook. I will quote from a survey conducted by a Melbourne based research group that interviewed 400 young Australians across most of the states in the 15-19 age group. They are basically young people who are leaving school and looking at going to university. We would hope that they are looking forward to entering the work force and getting on with their lives. What is interesting in terms of this debate is that a general theme came from these young people. The most disturbing theme was that most of them are very worried and uncertain about the future. Many said that even if they go to university they are unsure about getting jobs at the end of it. That very disturbing theme came from this report.

The following response is interesting in relation to the economic debate—and I guess it paraphrases the responses of many of the young people who spoke to the survey company. I quote from an article by education writer Caroline Jones which appeared in the Australian newspaper of today and which mentions `a deteriorating economy and a society in which individuals had reduced control over their economic destiny.' In other words, there is a feeling of alienation, a feeling that things are beyond people's control. I guess that reflects the fact that we have a government in Canberra that has got bigger and bigger and intruded into individuals' lives more and more.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have got more out of touch.

—The government is more out of touch. The Commonwealth's own purpose spending is going up and up. Now that we have sensible economic managers in most of the states—because they are all run by Liberal and coalition governments—the states have been getting their budgets back in order and tidying up the mess of those disastrous Labor years, left by those paragons of Labor politics such as Brian Burke, if I might start in the west, and his followers Mr Dowding and Carmen Lawrence, the latter who has now moved to Canberra to spread her wisdom over here. In South Australia we had the Bannon years and the State Bank collapse. We have Dean Brown and his team trying to sort out that mess now in South Australia, trying to get that once proud state back on the road again. In Victoria we had the John Cain and Joan Kirner team heading a once proud state, the crown in the federation—certainly the jewel in the Liberal crown—with an incredible history and an incredible people. All its diversity and economic strength was destroyed by 10 years of Cain followed closely by Kirner. That is what we have had with these Labor governments.

PARA.TAB: I thought it would be interesting in this debate—so I have done some research on it—to compare the record of the Keating government's economic management with that of those people in those states, who are widely regarded by just about everyone in Australia as having been disastrous economic managers. I mention them again: Brian Burke in Western Australia with Dowding and Lawrence, John Bannon in South Australia with the State Bank collapse, and Cain and Kirner in Victoria. Everyone remembers those names. They should be deeply embedded in the economic debate of Australia. They should be synonymous with Labor economic mismanagement.

What we should do in this debate—and I will seek to do so—is to compare their records on debt and tax with Mr Keating's record. Mr Keating, like it or not, has built himself a reputation as a good economic manager. Of course it is not deserved, as you realise if you speak to the 268,000 people in Australia who have been unemployed for longer than 12 months or to the 70,000 young Australians who have been unemployed for more than 12 months or to the 70,000 young Australians who do not have a roof over their heads, our homeless youth. They are probably a little cynical about Mr Keating's claims that Australia is on a good economic course and everything is hunky dory. As Peter Cole Adams said in the Canberra Times today, perhaps Mr Keating should go back to his desk and start working again.

Let us compare those failed and disastrous state Labor administrations that were all thrown out by the electorates, chucked aside in disgrace, with the economic management of Mr Keating. I will refer to some tables. If you look, for example, at the growth in net debt for the Commonwealth, you will see that the net Commonwealth debt per capita—I have done an analysis with the net debt and

SPEECH.PARA: the number of taxpayers—in 1986-87 was $5,915 per head. That has grown, based on the debt figures as predicted in the budget for 1994-95—and this is at Commonwealth level, I remind the Senate—to $12,200 per head. So it has more than doubled since the fiscal year 1986-87. That is the Commonwealth record on debt.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at the Burke-Dowding-Lawrence governments in Western Australia. The net state debt per taxpayer went from $9,600 per head back in 1986-87 to $11,000 per head in the final year of the Lawrence Labor government. In South Australia in 1986-87 there was a state debt per taxpayer of $6,846, rising to $13,600 in the last year of the Bannon government. Of course we remember that in 1991, the year of the collapse of the State Bank, there was almost a doubling in South Australia because all of a sudden the chickens came home to roost. Again a Labor government was disgraced and thrown out of office in probably the most ignominious fashion in Australia's history. It is probably only comparable to the 1975 landslide here in the federal election.

Back in 1986-87—my good friend from Victoria Julian McGauran will remember this because he lived through it—the state debt per taxpayer was $11,239. Only a few years later it increased to $15,458. They are big figures compared to the other states; it is big debt. Of course, Mr Stockdale and Mr Kennett are working very hard to bring that state back to the prominence it should have in Australia. Victoria is a great state. It is not as good at football, but they are great people.

I have given you all those bland figures. I will now give you the comparison. I have an agreement with Senator Cook that I be granted leave to incorporate these tables in the Hansard. If would appreciate leave of the Senate to enable me to do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the government and the Senate for giving me that privilege. That one comparison of debt per capita shows that the Keating Labor government here in Canberra has actually increased debt per capita—that is, net Commonwealth debt per capita—at a greater rate than Brian Burke, Peter Dowding and Carmen Lawrence. This is phenomenal, I would have thought.

PARA.TAB: I went to the library and said, `I want some figures because I think Australia is really going the wrong way. I want the Australian people to understand how bad things are.' Everyone knows that Cain and Kirner were terrible, that Brian Burke and Carmen Lawrence were just as bad and that John Bannon was a disaster. I did not know how bad Mr Keating was. I said, `People will understand this. Give me the figures.' I did not know what I was going to get, but I have the figures here. They are in the Hansard now. In 20 years time the people who want to read this Hansard—God bless their souls—will be able to see the figures.

TALK.START.PARA: —Distribute it.

—I will do that. I will distribute it to all of our colleagues and you can distribute it to the voters of Australia. It shows that the economic management of the Keating government is actually worse than all of those disgraced Labor governments. It is an absolute disaster. What does this debt do to people?

PARA.TAB: What do we need to ensure that we have job creation in Australia? We need interest rates that are stable and low. What do we have? Figures set out on page 115 of the 21 January edition of the Economist show that Australia's bank prime lending rate is 11.5 per cent. That journal goes through all of the other OECD countries and we are the only one with double digit interest rates. If we compare this with similar nations such as Britain and the United States, we see that the interest rate is 7.25 in Great Britain and 8.5 per cent in the United States of America. We are paying two, three and four per cent more than businesses and home buyers in the United States and Great Britain for our money. We are trying to compete and sell our products on the world international market, but we have this lead weight in our saddle bags before we even create the first widget or the first thing that we are trying to sell. We are disadvantaged.

Even in the inflation outlook reported in the Economist magazine the government is claiming credit for having great achievements in inflation. Inflation makes our economy uncompetitive—it puts up prices; it puts up wages—not only for businesses but for every household in this country. It has Australia's inflation outlook for 1995 listed as 3.5 per cent. That is a relatively low figure compared with what we were used to in the Gough Whitlam era, but the outlook of 3.5 per cent happens to be the third highest outlook for inflation in 1995. Who is higher than we are? Only Italy and Spain. Again, on the inflation front, where the government is claiming great credit, Australia has the third highest inflation outlook for the next year amongst all OECD nations.

We cannot continue to go down the track that this government is continuing to go down. We cannot allow interest rates to be at these levels just because the government cannot control its own spending. It would rather control the spending of individuals than bite the bullet and control its own Commonwealth spending. Spending by this Commonwealth government is actually worse than it was in the Whitlam years. The growth in Commonwealth own purpose spending is worse now than it was in Gough Whitlam's era.

That is comparing Labor paragons or the things that the people of Australia understand—although maybe not those from the younger generation. They did not live through the Whitlam government. I am young, but I still lived through that. We remember Whitlam—a great Australian, a great Prime Minister in many terms. He was a radical Prime Minister but, from an economic point of view, he had a reputation as being an economic disaster. I do not think Mr Whitlam would deny that. The reality is that people understand that he was a disaster when it came to economic management, and the Keating government is worse. We cannot let Mr Keating get away with this concept of the government claiming to be a good economic manager.

On the employment front, on the economic consequences of all this economic mismanagement—which is what really counts; you can talk in jargon and you can talk in figures but what counts is how lives are affected, particularly, in view of my portfolio responsibilities for youth, young lives—Julian Pocock, the Executive Director of APAC, the youth policy in action committee, made a very poignant point to me at a seminar held in Parliament House late last year. He said that the federal government's own employment policy—I think it was the white paper on employment entitled Working Nation—predicted and made it a matter of national policy that the government would reduce general employment to five per cent by the year 2000. Julian made the point that youth unemployment is generally a factor of three above that. So it is now a matter of federal government policy to have 15 per cent of young Australians unemployed by the year 2000.

From the coalition's point of view, that is not acceptable. We cannot marginalise 15 per cent of young Australians. We have to offer them more hope than that. There needs to be a radical change in economic policy in this country. We cannot have a Commonwealth government that tells everyone else to tighten their belts but takes off its belt altogether and drops its economic pants. It is just not on. Those 15 per cent of young people who will not have a job in the year 2000 should be given more hope than that. This government stands condemned for its economic mismanagement and must get its house into order.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Debating the appropriation bills gives us the opportunity to put on the record the history of the National Party, which has just celebrated its 75th anniversary. It was formed at a meeting held 75 years ago. Eleven members of the federal parliament formed a separate party to represent rural interests and industries. The National Party grew spontaneously out of the reaction of farmer organisations to price control of commodities after the First World War, objections to high protective tariffs and embargoes, objections to exploitation by the middle man of farmers and their produce and a recognition of the need for special attention to country development and decentralisation of settlements.

PARA.TAB: A farmers' political party started firstly in Western Australia in 1913 and appeared in Queensland in 1915, Victoria in 1917, South Australia in 1918, New South Wales in 1921 and Tasmania in 1922, with the formation of the federal party in 1920. As true to its cause and purpose today as it was when it was founded, the National Party has remained the only political organisation represented in the federal parliament which focuses its prime attention on the needs of people living and working beyond the capital cities, and on the businesses and interests they represent. However, it has always been a party of adaptability. Today it speaks for the silent majority of Australians found in the cities as well as in the country who, like it, unashamedly support the wealth-creating industries of Australia, believe in equal opportunity and access to facilities for all Australians, support a fair go for small business with its potential to create jobs, and respect and promote the family as the foundation stone of society.

As evidence of its continued adaptability and relevance, the party exists today as a major political force in all states of Australia. It presently is a coalition partner in three state governments—New South Wales, Victoria and Western Australia—and it is represented by three state deputy premiers. Its affiliate is in power in the Northern Territory; it is the senior coalition party in opposition in Queensland; and it has strong branch structures in South Australia and Tasmania. As a mark of its strength and its ability throughout the last 75 years, its influence and achievements have not only been immense but totally out of proportion to its numerical representation in both state and federal parliaments.

The National Party is a truly democratic party. Its structure guarantees it represents the wishes of its members. It proudly has the largest membership of any political party in Australia, with 100,000 members and with over 1,400 branches all over Australia. Its strong state organisational structure provides participation by branch members and gives democratic grassroots control to its members and provides the party with its most marked and envied characteristic—its stability. The party also involves the participation of the Young Nationals and the Federal Women's Council, with the party being the first to have a woman as its national president and federal director. Today it proudly has a female federal director and national president of the Young Nationals.

The party may unashamedly have had its birth in regional Australia and may have always represented the non-metropolitan electorates, but it has always had a vision and influence to introduce measures that benefit all Australians. The National Party in power has been instrumental in a lengthy list of important changes that have been to the long-term benefit of all Australians. Following the securing of a coalition agreement in 1922, the National Party has for most of these ensuing years been part of a strong non-Labor coalition with its partner, the Liberal Party, and has provided a coalition government with a deputy prime minister for a total of over 46 years.

The National Party in government has been instrumental in the establishment of the Reserve Bank, the Commonwealth Development Bank and the Primary Industry Bank of Australia. It introduced a national hospital medical benefits insurance scheme that ensured medical and hospital fees would never financially ruin any Australian family ever again, and there would always be a safety net in times of medical misfortune. It was instrumental in setting up the CSIRO and providing it with independent and unthreatening funding. As well, it strengthened Australia and its industries through the 200-mile Australian fishing zone and the rural adjustment scheme.

The National Party introduced and guaranteed Commonwealth financial assistance for roads, plus the Australian bicentennial road development program; the Australian Institute of Sport; the Australian Trade Commission Service; Aussat; numerous trade agreements, notably with Japan, the Middle East, Korea and South-East Asia; cheaper international and innovative domestic airfare packages; Commonwealth assistance for regional aerodrome development; income equalisation deposits; the isolated children's assistance program and isolated patients travel and accommodation assistance program; national soil and water conservation programs; and the abolition of Commonwealth land, death and gift duties.

The National Party has always acted in a constructive way to achieve its platform. It has always brought a practical focus to the issue and it has had an innovative impact on many institutions of Australian life. To sum up, it has been successful—and successful it will continue to be.

As pointed out by Malcolm Mackerras after the last federal election results, the National Party was the only major political party to increase its political representation at the last election. One measure of success is the many eminent National Party parliamentarians who have contributed in a monumental way over the years. The party has provided immense impact from leaders such Sir Earle Page, Sir Arthur Fadden, Sir John McEwen and, in more recent times, the troika—as they were known—of Doug Anthony, Peter Nixon and Ian Sinclair. All these leading members of the National Party provided Australia with strong leadership and with clear direction combined with personal qualities of integrity and commonsense.

It is the enormous contribution that this party has made to this great nation which I wish to highlight today. The National Party is particularly remembered for the contributions it has made for all Australians through its vision and its toughness. One is reminded of the Japan agreement secured by McEwen in 1957, when Japan, through the treaty, was given some degree of preference in the Australian market in a bid to obtain a foothold in the expanding Japanese market. All this occurred a mere 12 years after the end of the Second World War.

But it was this far-sightedness that was instrumental in the foremost trading position Australia now holds with its important trading partner—Japan—and similarly with a renegotiated Ottawa agreement, which secured less British preference to our markets and more access to British markets for Australian exports, particularly wheat. This must be taken in the context of British-Australian relations in the 1950s and the UK application to join the European Community. This also was a far-sighted achievement. It is worth noting that in the 1960s Sir John warned of the effects on world trade that would follow from the members of the EC restricting access to Australian exports. On the eve of the implementation of the Uruguay Round of GATT, which has gone some way to remedying the distorting factors of massive EC subsidies, it is fitting to remember the wisdom of Sir John McEwen's criticism at that time. Politically speaking, he led the party into five general elections; the coalition won all five. He also made major contributions to the wool industry's effective marketing arrangements, the wheat board and the meat industry.

To look further back in history is to acknowledge the contributions of the first National Party coalition government—the Bruce-Page government. With the National Party holding the portfolios of Treasury and transport, this government played a major role in nation building. It introduced a central banking system, a cooperative system of collecting federal and state taxes, uniform bankruptcy laws, a national system of transport, the forerunner to the CSIRO, the Standards Association and the federal council of health. It even managed to win a constitutional referendum in 1927 to authorise the Commonwealth to make arrangements with the states for taking over debts and the payment of interest.

The party's second leader, Sir Earle Page, set a respected tradition, serving as leader for 18 years, as did his successor, Sir Arthur Fadden, who followed Archie Cameron in 1940. Sir John McEwen was then leader for 13 years, followed by Doug Anthony for a further 13 years. Party leader, Artie Fadden, like Page and McEwen, was also Prime Minister in his own right for 40 days and was Acting Prime Minister for a further 692 days.

Artie Fadden is particularly remembered for his term as Treasurer and Deputy Prime Minister to the late Sir Robert Menzies from 1949-58. His influence in the 1940s and 1950s was comparable to that of Page in the 1920s and 1930s. Starting life as a billy boy for a cane cutting gang, he became a qualified accountant and, before entering state politics, had one of the largest accounting practices in North Queensland. He was considered an admirable Treasurer, delivering a record 11 budgets, and was able to skilfully deal with the rapid growth in the economy from the massive wool profits during the Korean War by working out the tax credit system to slow down their flow into the economy.

After 18 years with Fadden as leader of the party, the National Party continued its reliable and stable representation with Doug Anthony. To reflect on a more recent leader, Doug Anthony was Deputy Prime Minister to three Liberal Prime Ministers: Gorton, McMahon and Fraser.

Doug Anthony made tremendous gains to secure the future of our rural industries. He was able to secure a minimum price scheme for wool when the volatility of the wool price was destabilising the industry. He also persisted with reforms to the dairy industry, dragging it out of its impoverished condition. He must be pleased with the position of the industry today.

Anthony was also a committed advocate of strong social and family values, on which he took a courageous stand. He displayed a common quality of the National Party: loyalty to the party and loyalty to its coalition partner. Loyalty and stability have been National Party qualities that the electorate has always been able to rely on.

Doug Anthony had a reputation for driving a hard bargain. The closer economic relations agreement with New Zealand stands as one of Doug Anthony's most important achievements. His contribution as trade minister has been to the long-term benefit of Australia with the opening up of trade to the middle east and his pivotal role in securing a new international sugar agreement which, had the European Community only been prepared to cooperate, could have set a pattern for all future international commodity marketing arrangements.

Even out of power, the National Party has fought strongly to maintain arrangements that enable our major export industries to remain profitable and competitive. It fought to maintain the sole export trading powers of the Wheat Board and for the reintroduction of the underwriting for the wheat industry. It fought for the sugar industry by means of continuation of the sugar tariff when the industry was a victim of the hugely unfair trading situation because of massive subsidies provided to our major competitors. It influenced the changes to our antidumping and countervailing systems. It ensured bipartisan support for landcare and the conservation of the Murray-Darling. It stopped the introduction of the Australia Card.

At the same time, it is alarming to note the measures this ALP government has removed from primary industry in the 12 years it has been in power. Rural people know that roads and petrol prices are their lifeblood and that a proper drought policy is essential. They must be able to plan in good seasons for the inevitable bad season. Since 1983, when it came to power, the Labor government has systematically removed drought planning incentives, removed immediate write-offs for expenditure on water conservation rebates, cut soil conservation funding, continually increased the excise on petrol and indexed it, abolished the income equalisation deposit scheme for six years, cut wool research promotion funding and increased export inspection charges and quarantine fees—all to the detriment of rural industries.

The $167 million drought relief package announced last year, which only reintroduces some of these measures secured in the past by the National Party, is a belated contribution to a vital industry sector. By contrast, the Fraser-Anthony coalition government, with primary industry minister Peter Nixon, dealt with the crippling drought of 1983-84 in a way that enabled rural industries to lead the nation out of the recession of the early 1980s.

When you consider the vital importance of our road system to our continuing international competitiveness, you see that the government is doing a disservice to all future Australians by redirecting the petrol excise to the extent that it now does. In 1980 under the Fraser-Anthony coalition government, $925 million was collected in petrol excise of which 67.9 per cent went back to road funding. By 1988, the Labor government was taking 80 per cent of petrol excise for other purposes. This year only 8.8 per cent of the petrol excise will go to roads and a massive $9.641 billion will be collected.

Increasingly, it is the needs of the silent majority of Australians in areas such as small business and traditional family and social values that are ignored by this Labor government. The National Party has always been the voice for small business, wherever it is found around Australia. Small business is an important component of the Australian economy.

The Australian people know that the National Party will always take a strong and principled stand on issues that are related to social and family values. The runs are definitely on the board and the National Party is committed to its party beliefs of giving priority to policies that support the family as the foundation of society.

My purpose today is to pay tribute to the National Party and its achievements and contributions to this nation over the past 75 years. From its foundation of representing rural and regional interests, it has blossomed into a party at both the state and the federal level that speaks for all Australians, their beliefs and aspirations. It is a party that I am proud to represent. Its past achievements and defined purpose and aims for the future will, without any doubt, see the National Party continue to play a major role in the long-term future of Australian political life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate on the appropriation bills dramatises one disastrous thing that was underlined just half an hour ago when Australia's worst ever monthly current account figure of $2.4 billion, seasonally adjusted, was announced by the Commonwealth statistician—the worst ever in Australia's history.

PARA.TAB: People say, `What does the current account deficit do to me?' What impact does it have on the pocket of ordinary Australians? The impact it has is that it destroys our economic recovery; it pushes up interest rates; it forces the government, reluctantly and at last, to take notice of the advice that has been given by the opposition, by leading economists and by basically anyone who knows anything about finance that last year's budget was a disaster and that we are revisiting yesterday's crises. This is a crisis and it is yesterday's crisis. We are repeating the problems of yesterday.

Is it not extraordinary that it was said that Louis XVIII of France had forgotten nothing and learnt nothing? How appropriate that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating)—I suppose one could call him the minister in charge of French empire clocks—should be in exactly the same situation. He has learnt nothing from the disasters he presided over as Treasurer. So here we have yesterday's Treasurer as Prime Minister repeating yesterday's mistakes. If anyone is yesterday's man, it is the present Prime Minister. He cannot escape from yesterday. He is repeating the disasters that brought about the last two recessions and in particular the last recession that he says we had to have.

One of the Prime Minister's closest former advisers was Dr Morgan, who is the husband of one of his former ministers, Mrs Kelly. Dr Morgan is now very senior in Westpac. Over two years ago, in fact almost 2 1/2 years ago, Dr Morgan wrote in a Westpac monthly document a very clear analysis of how the 1990-91 recession—that was the recession we had to have—came about. He said:
The main catalyst for the 1990-91 recession in Australia was the Government's imposition of high interest rates aimed at curbing rapid growth in domestic spending (primarily business investment).

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, whose government was it and who was the Treasurer? The government was the Hawke government; the Treasurer was Mr Keating. Dr Morgan says that the seeds had been sown by the Hawke government's mishandling of the recovery from the 1982-83 recession. Dr Morgan says:

PARA.TAB: The 1982-83 recession—

SPEECH.PARA: which consistently has been blamed on the Fraser government—was caused by a combination of external and domestic factors . . .

I repeat: external—interest rate rises; changes in commodity situations; worldwide problems that were affecting Australia; and, of course, the worst drought for something like 60 years. But Dr Morgan says that `the 1990-91 recession' was caused `by purely domestic factors'. What are the factors causing the present disaster? They are domestic. They are as a result of this government's massive incompetence in the face of plenty of learned advice.

PARA.TAB: So while Mr Keating, yesterday's Treasurer, was sowing the seeds by mishandling the recovery from the 1982-83 recession, there was all this advice about how to avoid such a problem. Dr Morgan also says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . most of the gains in reducing inflation during the recession were lost in an over-rapid recovery—

Incompetence, stupidity, a mistake being repeated again. As I said on 7 October 1992 in this place, that is exactly the sort of situation that Mr Keating is repeating right now. Dr Morgan had said that this mishandling by Mr Keating laid the groundwork for the spending boom, high inflation and large balance of payments problems in the late 1980s, so that, as Dr Morgan said:
. . . another recession, this time due only to national—
not international—
problems, became inevitable.
So here we have it again.

PARA.TAB: As I said in 1992, Mr Keating was trying to buy his way into power by excessively boosting the economy, trying to create jobs at the cost of tomorrow's jobs. We have the same situation now. The statement that came out yesterday boasted about the remarkable and very speedy improvement in the jobs situation. But the way it has been effected condemns people tomorrow to mounting unemployment—just as happened in the 1990-91 recession. It is a repetition of exactly what happened before.

More warnings from experts nowadays continue on the same sort of front; in fact, they started when this government brought out its incompetent budget in May of last year. I noticed a couple of years ago that Mr Argus, the Chief Executive of the National Australia Bank, said that Australia could not afford the government's unfunded tax cuts—which it was offering at that time to buy its way into power, by the way—because they would overstimulate the economy, leading to a blow-out in Australia's foreign debt. That remark was prescient; it was made back in October 1992.

The government took no notice of Mr Argus—he did not know what he was talking about! But, of course, Mr Keating did. Mr Keating knows all. He knows all about yesterday's mistakes because he is the expert at repeating them: yesterday's man repeating yesterday's mistakes and pushing Australia back into yesterday's recession, with the worst ever balance of payments figures ever recorded in Australia.

But what is intriguing is the continuing pressure on spending by this government itself. We in the opposition have continually said that the government must cut its spending, that public sector spending must not continue to be the added stimulus to the excessive growth which is causing serious problems, because of the government's incompetence, and pushing us back into being threatened with serious recession. But the government says, `Oh no, we can't cut spending; it is sacrosanct.'

Let us see what Dr Morgan said in 1992. He said that public sector spending was too high. In the budget of that year, it was government spending that was pushing the economy along. The budget papers say, `Public sector final demand will continue to support activity in 1992-93.' Yet what is happening this year? Public sector expenditure is up again.

It is intriguing to note that, in the revised statements in yesterday's announcement by the Treasurer, Mr Willis, there is no comment about any variation in public sector spending. Yet in the budget papers, we see quite clearly:

SPEECH.PARA: Public final demand is expected to make a larger contribution to GDP growth in 1994-95 than in recent years reflecting an increase in underlying public investment.

What is the government up to? Here it is threatening to take serious fiscal measures—in other words, increase taxes—in order to slow down this expansion which is causing such disastrous problems in our debt situation, but it is not prepared to do anything about its own excessive spending—spending that has been a major factor in increased demand in recent times.

PARA.TAB: It is quite fascinating to go back and have a good look at last year's budget forecasts to see how extraordinary and wrong they were and how ludicrous it is for anyone in this country to take any notice of any economic promise, forecast or what have you given by yesterday's Treasurer, the man who, to my knowledge, has been wrong on all these matters more than any other Australian. Wrong, wrong, wrong, Mr Keating, and you are going to be wrong again and are being proved wrong by what is happening at the moment.

The budget papers said, `The current account deficit is forecast to increase moderately in 1994-95.' What is the reality? The reality is that it is going to burst out to $26 billion, which is almost six per cent of gross domestic product.

TALK.START.PARA: —The same level as on banana republic day.

—The same level, as Senator Short interjects, as on the day that Mr Keating said that we were headed towards a banana republic. I do not know whether they grow many bananas in Mexico, but the only nation in the OECD worse than us in the economic stakes at the moment is Mexico.

PARA.TAB: We have key forecasts, one of which was: the balance of payments deficit is forecast to increase moderately in 1994-95, both in absolute terms and as a proportion of GDP. That forecast is absolute nonsense. Let us have a look at another forecast. The budget papers said:

SPEECH.PARA: Monetary policy will need to continue to focus on maintaining low inflation through the medium term—

In other words, the government was saying, `We are going to put your interest rates up.' Let us concede that. The government did say that it would put interest rates up, although Senator Gareth Evans continually said in this chamber that they would be only modest rises, not the almost 60 per cent rises that have taken place. It goes on:

. . . while the Government's deficit reduction strategy will be crucial in boosting national saving, minimising interest rate pressures as business investment recovers and establishing scope for future fiscal flexibility.

Where has that happened? Where has all that gone? What has happened to the genius, the world's best Treasurer, who is now Australia's worst Prime Minister? Truly yesterday's mistakes are being repeated by yesterday's Treasurer who, hopefully, after the next election, will become yesterday's man.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday's Prime Minister.
—Certainly yesterday's Prime Minister. The budget paper continues:

SPEECH.PARA: With further significant falls in world interest rates unlikely, given recent developments in the US, a modest increase in the net income deficit is projected for 1994-95 as the impact of a continued rise in the stock of foreign debt again begins to dominate—

This is, of course, despite the fact that in recent times we have had a significant appreciation of the Australian dollar against the American dollar. That appreciation is now being hit severely on the head. These foreign debt figures are based on a level of the Australian dollar that is probably too high in context of the sorts of judgments that the rest of the world is going to make about us. Last year's budget stated:

A strategy to increase national savings is in place, enabling the impending recovery in business investment to be financed without excessive reliance on foreign savings and so preserving sound prospects for stabilising external debt as a proportion of GDP in the medium term.

Have you ever heard such nonsense? We now have in the same budget year the worst ever quarterly current account deficit figure. It is around $6.6 billion for the December quarter and follows the September quarter record worst ever figure. We have this situation at a time when the government is telling the Australian people that there will not be an excessive reliance on foreign savings. I wonder what the meaning of `excessive' is. I suppose we can believe that comment just as we can believe the Prime Minister's comment that tax cuts are l-a-w, law.

PARA.TAB: You cannot believe a word this government says. It will do or say anything to buy its way into power. Once again, in the area of unemployment, it is buying jobs that it knows it cannot sustain. It is getting the unemployment figures down by putting Australia further and further into debt. It is not cutting its own spending. It is giving false hope to those Australians who have been able to get unemployment benefits and it is imposing a dreadful threat on all those Australians who have jobs.

In the present situation excessive measures are going to have to be taken and the government admits that it is going to have to take fiscal measures. It is too late. Had it taken them at the time and had it followed the advice of the opposition, Australia would not be facing this kind of crisis. I do not expect we will get an apology from this Prime Minister. He does not know how to say sorry, just as he does not know how to be right. The budget paper stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The policy task ahead is to build on these achievements by maintaining a stable macroeconomic environment in which private sector activity can flourish—
that was the policy task, but it has failed with its policy again—
and pressing ahead with structural reforms aimed at raising the long-term growth potential of the economy.

Where are these structural reforms? What has happened to them? They are all falling apart. The government is not proceeding with the sorts of structural reforms that are absolutely vital and which the opposition has been pressing for years. The budget paper stated further:
All areas of policy—fiscal, monetary and structural—have a role to play in this process.
We have not seen enough of the `structural' and we have seen nothing of the `fiscal' that is now being waved over the head of Australians. It goes on:
Inflation and the current account balance, and policies to keep them in check, have constrained growth on many occasions in the past. The assess
ment in this Statement is that they are unlikely to impose such a constraint in the near future and need not do so in the longer term if the policies discussed are effectively pursued.

That is a disaster, isn't it? They have not been effectively pursued. We are back on the old roundabout. We are back in disaster. We are back because this Prime Minister has learnt nothing. He has certainly forgotten nothing. He does not forget his hatreds, but he has certainly learnt nothing. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table outlining the balance of payments current account deficit over the years back to 1959 to show just how disastrous this current balance of payments situation is.

TALK.START.PARA: —Appropriation bills are not often questioned in this place. The last time was in 1991. It is probably an outcome of the two-party system which either mindlessly supports or mindlessly opposes. Since appropriation bills are supply bills in the classic sense, they are usually passed without question unless someone is trying to block supply. There is no reason for this. Appropriation bills are bills, the same as other bills. They are not inviolate or on some pedestal.

PARA.TAB: The constitution does not say that appropriation bills cannot be altered. In fact, it specifies that the Senate cannot alter them but can send them back to the House of Representatives with a request for alteration. There have been many instances where recommendations for amendments have been put up and debated in the Senate. Appropriation bills, like any bills, should be subject to review and change. We will therefore put to the Senate a request for amendment to the House of Representatives in relation to Appropriation Bill (No. 3).

The intent of the change is to eliminate the $215 million sought by Defence mainly for new equipment. The reason for this unbudgeted expenditure has not been adequately explained. It is a large sum—16 per cent greater than the entire annual budget for environmental protection, parks and the national estate. It is basically an issue of proper process. Why is there this unexpected sudden massive increase in the need for equipment? If it was expected, then why was it not included in the normal budget in Appropriation Bill (No. 1)? What reprogramming of payments is involved? If they are payments that were not made last year and were known to come due this year, why were they not included in Appropriation Bill (No. 1)? If they are payments that were planned for future years, why are they needed now? If they are for new equipment, what new equipment are they for? Why and how is this demand for new equipment justified? What urgency is involved?

Other departments justify additional expenses. In the additional appropriation bills before us, there is the money for drought relief, rural restructuring and jobs programs. These are clear issues that are obviously results of decisions made in this place. They are commitments that involve an additional expense not budgeted for. There are other expenses, including the veterans' health care cost resulting from the shutdown of public institutions. They can be seen as expenses that should have been calculated in the savings from privatisation but were not calculated for political and ideological reasons or as a consequence of incompetence.

Still, the nature of the expenses is specified and it is clear that the failure to provide the funds will result in hardship for veterans who had no part in the decisions to shut down facilities they were using. There is no such clear rationale for a group giving a quarter of a billion dollars to Defence for war toys. While Defence has specified what it wants the money for, there is no reason given for failure to include it in the normal budget, nor is there any exceptional event creating the need. Only the administrative division expenses have some justification, since without funding some non-defence group or the general community will have to carry the can.

Defence has held a privileged position in the sense that it has been allowed to determine what it wants and then been given it. It really justifies anything. Questions are deflected by claims of national security. It operates under a global budget and the kindest description of processes of accountability is that they are opaque.

Defence operates on a huge budget, yet answers to questions about expenditure are often deliberately obscure and sometimes blocked completely. I recently received answers to many pages of questions. I will tell my fellow senators some of the answers so that they can understand something of my frustration.

In the defence exports inquiry, we were told that Customs does almost no checking of arms exports and generally would not know if what is going out is what is described on the manifest. The committee, both in the primary and additional reports, rightly directed intense criticism at this practice. We were told that Customs depends almost entirely on information gathered by military intelligence to stop arms smuggling and illegal arms exports. We were told that this is inadequate.

I asked a few questions about this. I am the last person who would want to compromise anything working to stop illegal arms transfers. I asked good general questions just to get some idea of what intelligence actually does and whether the money we give it is being used well. I asked how many illegal trade events have been detected and how many times intelligence has informed Customs of a potential problem. I asked whether intelligence cooperates with other nations and international intelligence agencies in monitoring legal and illegal arms transfers. They were good, basic questions.

I was told that it is policy never to answer any questions about intelligence. This is not about security. There are no security issues here except the question of whether there is adequate security against illegal arms trading. This is an issue of accountability.

These people were given $130 million last year. That is more than two and a half times what was given to rural adjustment and services. Surely we have some right to ask whether it is doing any good. My questions were entirely non-specific. Nothing about intelligence methods would have been revealed except to give some idea of whether they are doing the job for which they are given funding. The only reason I can imagine for stonewalling on such answers is that they are not doing a good job and that the answers would have been dramatically embarrassing—too much so for even this place to tolerate.

I asked several pointed questions about the minehunter project. I did not question the need for an anti-mine capability. I would just like some assurance that this project will not be a repeat of the inshore minehunter fiasco, which was terminated after it was recognised that the ships being built were hardly seaworthy in a bath tub and were useless in even a light breeze under real conditions. Yet we spent $150 million building exactly two of the useless things before the program was shut down after revelations of the total stupidity and waste involved. I cannot see how even the most devout arms advocate would accept such expenditures for ships that cannot be used.

The most expensive part of a minehunter is the sonar telecommunications component. In the case of the new ships, we have opted for another gee-whiz, high-tech model of questionable value. These techno toys not only are initially much more expensive but also cost more to maintain. The costs blow out rapidly if there are any problems. Problems are much more likely since they have not been routinely adapted to many and varied environments.

My worry is that this part of the minehunter project will be a liability rather than an asset, so I asked several questions relating to both the cost and the consideration of potential problems and the need for exotic rather than standard minehunting hardware. This was not an ideological rejection of defence expenditure but an effort to ensure economic responsibility. The rationale for this high-tech variable debt system is that it is good for defence against ultra-sophisticated underwater mines. They were used by the USSR in Europe, and the technology was developed against them for use in the Baltic.

There are questions about whether their technology can be adapted easily and reliably to tropical waters, which experience large temperature variations. The instruments are extremely sensitive to temperature. The Baltic has a very even temperature gradient. Defence experts estimate that the potential cost of modifying this equipment to tropical conditions could blow out the MHC budget.

In light of this, I asked some questions about the need for this technology. We are not in the Baltic. We are not operating subs in an enclosed sea. We do not have neighbouring nations also bordering a sea in a way that endangers our movement in and out. Coastal areas where subs will be based, such as Garden Island, are often relatively shallow. Control of the surrounding sea is relatively easy. Who do we imagine might mine the Fremantle harbour area? Who will mine Sydney? How would they do so undetected? As far as I know, none of the regional powers have anything like the Russian deep sea mines or would have the capability of mining our harbour areas undetected.

With the location and topography of proposed sub-bases it is very likely that we could establish multiple passage areas around submarine bases, monitor them and keep them mine-free using cheaper, proven and more reliable equipment. The Department of Defence did answer that Garden Island is too shallow for such mines, and it is not considered likely that they would be used elsewhere.

I asked some questions about the cost of the variable depth system and the need for it. I got answers that could only be described as contrary and evasive. I asked if any neighbouring nations held such mines and was asked in turn to specify which neighbour. Why? It was a general question in relation to the need for expenditure. Surely if this special equipment is required, the Department of Defence knows whether any neighbours have such mines and can tell me which ones. I asked if any potential enemy had such mines, thinking maybe some non-neighbour was the problem. It was not an adequate answer to say `We do not designate countries as potential enemies.' This is evasion. `Potential' means possible. The dictionary defines it as `latent, that may or might but does not now exist or act.' I did not need to know who was considered a potential enemy, just whether such an enemy existed. So there is no diplomatic problem in answering that question. If we have no potential enemies we do not need a defence force at all.

These kinds of answers to questions on notice in estimates committees are simply not adequate. They are irresponsible, evasive and anti-accountable. They tie the questions up in bureaucratic jargon and refuse to respond to the clear concerns raised. In such a case I cannot condone giving more money to Defence. They have received the money they asked for in the budget. They have shown no reason for additional expenditure outside the normal budget process. I see no urgency here. They can wait for next year's budget.

I go into some detail about the minehunters and mines because the quality of answers I received is indicative of the reason I cannot support this Defence appropriation. I also mention it because at least $90 million of the amount sought is for the minehunters. I note that in the annual report there is a little net underspending on equipment, some $66 million. But this masked the fact that there was actually an underspending of $185 million on the minehunter project to be rolled over to this year while there was additional spending in a number of areas like Anzac frigates, Raven Radios and so on to the level of about $123 million.

Defence seems to be one of the most heavily padded budgets in the Commonwealth. Until I start seeing some real justification of expenditure, scrutiny of performance and cooperation in answering questions I cannot agree to additional expenditure beyond that covered in the budget and will continue to push for more accountability within the budget process.

Other non-defence aspects of this bill fall clearly into the area of additional appropriation. The need for funds for veterans' affairs or human services reflects real needs that will create hardships if not met. So does the housing component of the Defence request. So I have not asked for that to be excluded. Otherwise I do not see any evidence of urgency or hardship or unexpected expense in relation to defence. I do not see any danger in waiting until next year's budget. I cannot see why, when the people of both sides of this house call for fiscal restraint and are concerned about the current account, we should spend a quarter of a billion dollars extra on defence. I believe that there are significant ways Defence could save money or use it more wisely. The Institute of Public Affairs, hardly a radical group, agreed. Let Defence do what other departments do, what Health, Social Security and Environment do, and find ways to internally adjust for increased expenses.

TALK.START.PARA: —You give us an example. Specify what you are saying.

—Senator Panizza claims that I need to give examples. He obviously has not been listening to the last ten minutes of my speech because I gave him several. I think it is more a problem of closing ones's ears rather than wanting to hear what was going on. Items such as those here, and I will use the P3C component—another $96 million expenditure—may actually be acceptable and a good idea. I understand that these will improve safety and surveillance ability. My point is that it is not urgent. It is not something that arose unexpectedly. I understand that the P3C Orion technology has been a problem for some time and that the technical upgrades have been examined for some time. So why is it not included in the budget? Why was it not included in Appropriation Bill (No. 1)? Why can it not wait for the next budget, which is only a few months off?

PARA.TAB: It is unaccountability. It is a way of making the Defence budget appear lower than it is. Defence puts in a submission, leaves off the P3C, leaves off the minehunter costs and then comes in and says, `Oh, there is an additional demand we didn't know about. We need another $200 million.' It expects simply to get it. This is not good enough. No other federal department would get away with it, and Defence should not get away with it either.

For this reason, we have excluded the bulk of the Defence request. Let it put it in next year's budget in an above board manner. Let it know that it cannot simply forget to mention a couple of hundred million dollars that it wants and then ask for it later in the full expectation that it will get it. Defence makes long range procurement plans—we know that because it gives them to industry, not necessarily us—and these should be reflected in a minimal request for additional money.

We have left two areas of the request stand. The request for $12 million for housing should have been foreseen, but housing has been low priority in Defence and housing stocks have been run down. It is only because of adverse publicity that something is now being done. We think that upgrading housing should be supported because it is a case of imposing hardship if it is not done.

At the same time, I would like to point out that there is considerable need for public housing upgrades, yet on page 44 of this bill the entire additional appropriation for housing and crisis accommodation is only $300,000. This is for the first home owners scheme, incidental expenditure for a scheme being terminated. Yet the Department of Defence claims it suddenly and unexpectedly needs $12 million for Defence housing. Can it really be the case that Defence did not know it needed to fix up housing, or is this just evidence that it was not going to and has changed its mind because the dreadful state of housing was publicly revealed?

I would also like to point out another disjunction, which is that the total amount housing and regional affairs got in Appropriation Bill (No. 1) was $1.6 million. This is to deal with the need for crisis accommodation and general public housing. Less than $2 million was considered to be all the nation needed or could afford, and yet volunteer welfare agencies are complaining about heavy loads of the poor and homeless. By contrast, Appropriation Bill (No. 1) has already given the Department of Defence $332 million for defence housing this year. It needs another $12 million. Something is wrong here. There is a problem with priorities.

The other request of the Department of Defence that we accepted was the administrative component. This was for clearing unexploded ordnance, paying compensation claims and settling underpayments to Aboriginal soldiers who served in World War II. Why this was not settled long ago I cannot imagine, and why this is an unexpected expense I do not know. But if the Commonwealth will finally pay these people the Greens will support it.

I note that $11,000 was appropriated for payments in 1992-93 and they were not made. I note that the expenditure for 1993-94 is listed as nil on page 27, yet I believe $20,000 was appropriated—$11,000 as budgeted and an extra $9,000 that was in additional appropriations.Appropriation Bill (No. 1) this year included $10,000 for this purpose, and we see yet another $4,000 in additional appropriations. Why this additional sum, I am not sure. It was World War II and we ought to know what we owe. I expect to see an expenditure as a result of this. These are servicemen who are now becoming old. Year after year money is appropriated and not paid. Please pay them.

I believe we must demand a level of accountability from Defence at least equal to that of other departments. It is not good enough that it is a law unto itself. The rule for Defence cannot simply be `ask and you shall receive'. For this reason, I commend my recommendation for amendment to the Senate. A saving of $200 million today would be timely.

I would also like to add that for any party to be credible in terms of accountability—the opposition often claims to be concerned about accountability—it must also look at accountability for Defence spending. It is not about ideology; it is not about whether you support defence or not; it is about whether you support accountability and whether you let a defence department off the hook simply because it is defence and not social security or any other department spending money from the Commonwealth's budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too would like to speak in this debate on the appropriation bills. It gives us an opportunity each year to do an assessment of the government's performance and how this nation is travelling without necessarily going into a lot of detail. We can look at the things that matter in terms of making that assessment. When we do that in terms of the current performance we find that what we were told would come out of the last budget process is not only wrong but dramatically wrong.

PARA.TAB: We have a situation where our deficit is going up, our foreign debt is going up and interest rates once again are on the move upwards. They have gone up significantly and are likely to go up more. In fact, we can almost guarantee they will go up more. There has also been an alarming drop in housing investment. Probably even more important than any of these things is the fact that confidence is once again disappearing from the business community. It has no faith, no trust, in this government's economic management. Without confidence, you will not get the types of consistent levels of investment that are required to have an economy consistently performing well.

What has been extremely lacking during the whole period of the Hawke-Keating and Hawke-come-Keating governments is consistency in economic performance. We have consistently had a boom-bust scenario. Either growth has been out of control, unemployment has been out of control, our foreign debt has been out of control or our current account has been out of control. According to predictions, the figures coming out today—I have not seen the figures but the predictions probably will be right—are expected to show a record blow-out for the current account. I believe some press coverage was predicting as high as $25 billion to $26 billion. A simple fact of life is that this cannot be allowed to continue. If it is allowed to continue, gradually your trading position will deteriorate.

We also hear, and I am sure this has been mentioned, that we are moving back to a position we were in when the current Prime Minister, Mr Keating, was Treasurer. Some time ago he commented that he was responsible as the Treasurer—just as he is responsible today as the Prime Minister. As reported in the press today, while Treasurer Willis does make some comments with regard to the economic levers, as they are called in this country, it is really the Prime Minister who controls them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that the same man who is known Australia-wide as `Cheating Keating'?

—Yes, that is the same man. You are absolutely right, Senator Short. He is the same man who is known as `Cheating Keating'. That is absolutely right. In relation to this matter I want to deal with one of the principal reasons why we are in this demise. It goes back to the inability of this government to sensibly and seriously address industrial reform in this nation. I mention the fact that, in the debate on industrial relations just over 12 months ago—

I ask you to ask the senator to withdraw it.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Herron)—The phrase is clearly out of order.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen C.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —There must have been a number of people like myself who returned from their holidays over Christmas and were shocked to read in the newspapers last week of the death of Dr Grisha Sklovsky. We would have wanted to have the opportunity to join the some 450 people who paid tribute to Grisha, who died peacefully on 9 January this year aged 79. My colleague Senator Short, the shadow Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, who is in the chamber with me today, would also like to join me in these remarks. I know that Dr Sklovsky was a source of wise counsel to Senator Short.

PARA.TAB: The obituaries in the Age and the Australian newspapers were appropriately extensive. Grisha Sklovsky had a wide range of friends from science, business, the arts, politics and education. I was proud to count myself among his friends. I first met Grisha when I was a very young child. At that stage he had just come to Australia, and he often played tennis with my parents following his migration to this country in 1947. During the 1980s, Grisha kept in touch with me through his interests in the Institute of Public Affairs. His involvement with multicultural activities brought him into contact with my wife, who was employed at the Special Broadcasting Service. Grisha, as senators will know, was the foundation chairman of SBS from 1978 to 1980.

It was a mark of the great respect held for Grisha Sklovsky that three most eminent Australians spoke at his memorial service, which was held at the Camberwell Town Hall on 11 January. Sir Zelman Cowan, former Governor-General, spoke of Grisha's involvement with the Institute of International Affairs and of his lively concern for international affairs and relations. Among other things, Sir Zelman mentioned Grisha's extraordinary network of friends, his style, his zest and his enthusiasm for life.

Phillip Law, the noted Antarctic explorer, mentioned Grisha's wide range of interests which, of course, included helping to establish SBS, his involvement in Antarctic expeditions, and his service on many cultural organisations. Phillip Law said:

SPEECH.PARA: His value to the community, first recognised by his election to the Royal Council of Victoria in 1967, spread through many areas. From 1975-77 Grisha was President of the Australian Institute of International Affairs; in 1987 he was elected president of the RSV for three years, and in 1994 he accepted the position of inaugural chairman of the advisory board of the Institute of Reproduction and Development at Monash University.

I am pleased to hear that the institute will be setting up a postgraduate scholarship to honour Grisha Sklovsky's memory. Sir Gustav Nossal, recently announced as Australian of the Year and one of our most distinguished scientists, spoke of Grisha's rich professional life both before and after his work at ICI, and the recognition he received by receiving the Order of Australia award. This week the Australia/Israel Review wrote these words to describe Grisha Sklovsky: `his intellectual breadth and rigour, his vision, and dedication to multiculturalism'.

PARA.TAB: Grisha Sklovsky's early life was marked by huge change and upheaval as some of the tragic events of the 20th century shaped his early experiences. In his own words he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia was my fifth start in settling anywhere in a community. Yet it is the first country and place where I have felt welcome and free and at home.
Grisha summed up his early years in this way:

Escaping oppression in Russia aged 8, and, on completing school, in Hitler's Germany; pre-War University years in France as a welcome paying guest as long as I did not have to earn a living there. Free Czech Army Service in Wartime England and Europe made it impossible to obtain even a visitors entree to post-war England. It seemed, in 1945, unsafe and unwise to remain in Free Czechoslovakia after 6 years of Army service.

Since I was 9, I dreamt of life in the New World. I fell in love with a Melbourne girl in France just before the War started. We managed to remain in contact, and married as Australian Red Cross Officers in Greece in 1946; and I arrived here in 1947, delayed by only 23 years.

In the last two months, I met Grisha twice. The first occasion was at a conference held jointly by the Australian Defence Association and the Institute of International Affairs. The conference concerned Australia's role in peacekeeping. He was, as ever, an active participant. I saw him again in November. He telephoned me and said that he would like to have a discussion about some political issues. We spent well over an hour together in my office and we covered a wide range of matters. An article had appeared that day in the Melbourne Age on his son Michael, and this led to a very enjoyable exchange on family matters. He was enormously proud of his family and I was able to catch up with all the activities of Celia, his children and grandchildren.

PARA.TAB: He handed me a speech on Australian citizenship which he had made a number of years ago which covered many of his attitudes to Australia and multiculturalism. He felt this speech was still relevant today. He was a passionate Australian—a passion reinforced by his knowledge of how other societies functioned. He greatly appreciated the openness and tolerance of Australian society which, in his view, made us a unique community. I would like to quote from that speech he gave me on this issue. Grisha Sklovsky said:

SPEECH.PARA: Never did so many people of different, at times hostile backgrounds, move with so little friction or conflict into a new host society. No host society accepted a sudden influx of so many foreigners so readily. This does not mean that Australia became an instant paradise, nor that all newcomers or inmates became instant angels. But here we created and maintained a way of life the like of which none of our Home Countries ever achieved. Of course there is room for improvements, but the general level of racial, religious and general tolerance is quite outstanding in Australia.
Grisha, however, was critical of what he saw was a lack of national pride. He said:

It seems very sad to me that all Australian Governments have tolerated in the past 15 years a manifest devaluation of national pride, radical approach to our government system, to our flag, without any attempt to revalue Australian Citizenship, or to raise incentives for residents to become citizens. People should be clamouring to be accepted into the Australian community.
Grisha Sklovsky was one of Australia's leading advocates of multiculturalism. He pointed out:

Australia is one of the oldest democracies in the world. Australia is one of the very few countries whose Governments enable newcomers to remain active in their original ethnic groups, while being 1st class citizens here. We tend to take this for granted, forgetting that this is not so elsewhere.
Yet Grisha believed it was important that new Australians should reach out to the wider community. He said:

I believe that having accepted the privilege of becoming Australians, we should reciprocate by joining in activities beyond our past ethnic ties. We can do this by becoming active in wider areas of our choice, by reaching out more often to our Australian neighbours of all backgrounds, without conflict, with our religious or ethnic origins.
He was a pioneer of multiculturalism, yet he had some concerns about recent developments. Grisha pointed out:

Considerable bureaucracies now exist, a whole ethnic industry. Many are useful, but there can be too much of a good thing. It is my belief that we need to review all this, to reduce the US and THEM gap from both sides, and concentrate on real needs while reducing self-serving groups.
I seek leave to table the full text of Grisha Sklovsky's speech on citizenship.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Dr Grisha Sklovsky was a great Australian. His life experience meant that he could appreciate, in a way not open to most of us, the reality of a free society. He was a beacon of commonsense and dedication to the values of a free society. It is appropriate that the Senate honours his memory today. We send our condolences to his wife Celia, his daughters Anna and Jane, his son Michael and his grandchildren.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I raise the matter of the inquiry by a Senate committee into Australian soccer. This is a very serious matter because it involves the question of large amounts of money going astray to the detriment of the game and to the detriment of the reputations of many people in the game. It also raises serious questions about the propriety of the actions of some people. The inquiry is being carried out by the Senate Environment, Recreation and the Arts References Committee. The Committee has already had one series of hearings at which some very serious allegations were made.

PARA.TAB: My purpose here today is not to canvass the outcome of that hearing but to respond to some matters that have been raised in relation to me. It is also to commend the Australian Soccer Federation for an action that I understand it is taking today.
