As I understand it, the federation is recommending in a press release that players and officials—in fact, anyone involved—should give evidence to the Senate committee. In other words, it is getting totally behind the Senate committee and encouraging anyone with any knowledge to come forward, to reveal to the Senate inquiry whatever they know about impropriety relating to soccer—in particular, transfers, transfer payments, money gone astray and so on.

We understand from evidence given to Mr Stewart in his inquiry into these matters that players had been stood over and threatened in respect of giving evidence to him. Now, hopefully, people will come forward to the Senate inquiry. The ASF, as I understand it, is going to assure players that they have nothing to fear by way of retribution if they come forward and give evidence freely and fully to the Senate inquiry.

As I think many people would be aware, the Senate inquiry is very soundly based on several grounds. In the first place, the federal government provides something like $1 1/2 million in taxpayers' funds to assist soccer football in Australia in one way or another—apart from whatever taxpayers' funds are provided at state level. It is essential that before taxpayers' money is contributed to a sport there should be no question about the integrity of its administrators.

I think what will emerge from the Senate inquiry is that some people, I hope, will be given a totally clean bill of health and others who are demonstrated to have been involved in improper behaviour will be cleared out of their roles in soccer. Some people appear, on the evidence so far presented to the Stewart inquiry, to have been interested and involved in providing even greater benefits to themselves than to soccer football, no matter over how many years that had taken place.

The Senate inquiry also has enabled the Stewart inquiry into impropriety in soccer to be made public. Those people who were criticised, who were found to have behaved in an improper way, by former Justice Stewart in his report, which was commissioned by the Australian Soccer Federation itself, will have the chance before the Senate inquiry to answer those allegations, either in writing or by appearing in person. In other words, it puts an end to the leaks, innuendo and claims of cover-up that were involved when the Stewart inquiry report was not capable of being released because of legal advice that it was defamatory. That was why the Australian Soccer Federation could not release it.

My friend and colleague from Western Australia who initiated this, Senator Ian Campbell, is only too well aware of the reasons that the Australian Soccer Federation could not release the report. In fact, he had discussions with the Soccer Federation before initiating the call for a Senate inquiry to, if you like, complete the circle which was unable to be completed because of these matters—particularly, I might say, the failure of the Stewart inquiry to be able to overcome the threats made to various people not to give evidence.

By having this Senate inquiry we have now made this report public. Instead of relying on innuendo and rumour, people can now see what is said about them. They have the right and it is the Senate committee's duty to give them the opportunity to give their side of the story.

I do want to stress that the threat of retribution against witnesses is a very serious matter. That is why I am so glad to see the Australian Soccer Federation getting behind our inquiry. I am glad to be a member of that inquiry, as is Senator Abetz, who I see is in the chamber today. This is a big matter. We have already established from the Stewart inquiry that in five transfers alone something like $1.2 million dollars has magically disappeared.

This question of retribution is a matter of concern. Our committee did hear evidence that the Chief Executive of the Australian Soccer Federation, Mr Ian Holmes, had been subjected to threats about the provision of evidence to the Stewart inquiry. In fact, he was accused of leaking evidence to the Stewart inquiry. The Stewart inquiry was set up by the Australian Soccer Federation. Here you have an allegation that a man who was a commissioner of the Australian Soccer Federation was accusing the paid chief executive of the Soccer Federation of leaking to that inquiry when he provided it with information.

Clearly, this is a matter of immense concern. We understand the Soccer Federation is very concerned that this kind of attitude appeared to exist among not only at least a commissioner of the ASF but also among some officials and coaches. Clearly, there is a problem. I certainly was on the receiving end of that problem when I saw a headline in the Telegraph Mirror on 14 December, across five columns, saying, `Get it right, Senator,' in which Mr Anthony Labbozzetta, the Chairman of Marconi, criticised, in fact, attacked me for being wrong. I will quote some extracts from that article:

SPEECH.PARA: The Marconi president says that Senator Baume has clearly mislead the public, parliament and the media. "He (Baume) has made certain allegations under parliamentary privilege and I want an apology."

PARA.TAB: Senator Baume says in the Senate Hansard that Labbozzetta resigned as a director of the Australian Soccer Federation and identified a person as his brother as having links with the South Australia firm, Sea Travel.
Labbozzetta said that at no time did he ever resign from the federation.
"I sought leave of absence while the inquiry went ahead," he said. The statements he (Baume) has made are totally inaccurate.

SPEECH.PARA: Then he went on about how there was someone else called Francesco Nicola Labbozzetta who was involved with that company and he said:

PARA.TAB: "It is simply staggering to think that a man (Baume) of such high standing—

SPEECH.PARA: I have to agree with that bit—
has not done his homework correctly and has used parliamentary privilege to the detriment of people. I believe that is unacceptable.
Then the article ended saying:
Labbozzetta is so incensed with the Senate Hansard that he has written to Ms Janice Crosio, the Federal member for Prospect, and also to Federal Immigration Minister Mr Nick Bolkus.

PARA.TAB: Senator Nick Bolkus, of course, has achieved some fame by reappointing Mr Labbozzetta to the Immigration Review Tribunal despite the fact that Mr Labbozzetta managed to sit on an average of one inquiry a year during the four-year period or so that he was on it. Despite a recommendation that he not be reappointed, Senator Bolkus reappointed him. Of course, Senator Short has pointed all that out.

These allegations are just total and absolute nonsense. They are backed up by a letter to the President of the Senate from Tony Labbozzetta in which he repeats those allegations, saying that I am wrong. The letter says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Senator has said that I have resigned during the year. This is untrue.
Let me quote exactly what I did say—this in Hansard of 7 December 1994. I said:
For example, the annual report of the Soccer Federation for 1993 reveals that. . .
It deals with Mr Constantine. I then went on with another matter. I said:
. . . a director of the federation, Mr Tony Labbozzetta, who resigned during the year, has an interest as a partner in the business Marconi Travel.
Notice that I said, `who resigned during the year, has an interest as a partner in the business Marconi Travel.' I went on to say:

This business renders service in connection with travel arrangements for the federation in respect of interstate and international travel. All dealings with the business are in the ordinary course of business and on normal commercial terms and conditions. Moneys paid to Marconi Travel during the year in respect of travel arrangements amounted to $129,246.

Where did I quote that from? From the annual report of the Australian Soccer Federation; it is here in Mr Labbozzetta's own federation's annual report. It is as clear as crystal, unless someone is seeking deliberately to misinterpret what I have said. I was reading exactly from that report. It is under the paragraph that says:
For example, the annual report of the Soccer Federation for 1993 reveals that . . .

Mr Labbozzetta knows perfectly well that that is chapter and verse what is in the report, and he knows perfectly well he resigned in that year. Whether or not he subsequently resigned or whether he just stood down, or whatever, is beside the point. I object to someone of Mr Labbozzetta's standing accusing me of lying when I read from an annual report of the body of which he was a member. It is to be noted that Labbozzetta said that at no time did he resign from the federation. That, not to put too fine a point on it, is simply false.

PARA.TAB: I do not want to prejudge Mr Labbozzetta, just as I am certain Mr Labbozzetta does not want to prejudge the Senate committee. All I suggest to Mr Labbozzetta is that, if he has concerns and complaints to make, the place to make them is in front of the Senate committee. I might add that at no stage did I say that Francesco Labbozzetta was his brother, Frank. I do know how loosely the Labbozzetta family interprets the word `family' in these circumstances. I thought one's cousin was family, but I am not quite certain in which area of Italy the word `family' develops different meanings. The fact is that I had said that some members of the Labbozzetta family, particularly Francesco, who was involved with the Marconi Travel company, have been the subject of an internal police confidential inquiry. I have that document.

If Mr Labbozzetta has concerns about it, as I said, let him present them to the Senate inquiry. I am quite prepared to hear them, but I am not prepared to have Mr Labbozzetta falsely pretend to the President of this place that I have improperly and disgracefully maligned him by quoting from the annual report of the Australian Soccer Federation. The President has kindly suggested that I should examine the claims herein and consider whether they require further clarification by me in the Senate. I thank the President for giving me that opportunity. All I seek is the truth and I would be very grateful indeed if Mr Labbozzetta could show the same enthusiastic pursuit as I have for the truth in this soccer matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this afternoon to bring attention to the plight of the families and workers who are involved in the forest and satellite industries and who have been thrown into absolute chaos as a result of Labor's internal divisions and policy schizophrenia.

PARA.TAB: At the outset, we need to reject the simplistic definition of this debate being about heritage values and trees. There is another important dynamic in this whole debate, and that is the people: the families and the communities which are affected by these on again, off again decisions whilst the Labor Party is trying to work out whether it is going to be the Green party or whether it is going to be the party for the workers, for whom it was founded some considerable time ago.

It is most unfortunate that, in this whole debate, the Australian Labor Party and the Greens have not been able to grasp the important dynamic of human involvement in their decision making processes. I congratulate those who are outside this place for having shown the very significant human element that is affected by the Labor Party's decision and its pursuit of the green agenda without regard for those who used to be its constituents.

As all of us in this place know, regional Australia is hurting badly because of the drought, high interest rates and the substantial lack of job opportunities within those areas. On top of that, the government has now thrown one of the important industries of regional Australia into absolute chaos as a result of its policy schizophrenia.

Senator Faulkner indicated to us that he recommended that 1,300 coupes be preserved because of their important conservation value. In writing to his ministerial colleague—I use the description `colleague' loosely; I would have thought he is an archenemy—the Minister for Resources, Mr Beddall, on 7 December 1994, submitting the first instalment of his forest preservation list, Senator Faulkner said:

SPEECH.PARA: In preparing my advice I have been rigorous in identifying forests of high conservation value.

In other words, after this rigorous examination there were 1,300 coupes. Suddenly, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) intervened and the 1,300 coupes have been reduced to 509 coupes. One wonders how rigorous the examination really was when 791 coupes can be simply crossed out at a stroke of the Prime Minister's pen, especially when the Prime Minister said publicly that, before Christmas, the green movement would have been satisfied with 200 or 230 coupes. After Christmas, the number of coupes suddenly became 509, and we are now led to believe that 17 coupes in New South Wales may be put back on the list. Senator Faulkner told us that this is as a result of a rigorous examination!

PARA.TAB: Yesterday I asked two questions about the situation. I asked what scientific basis there is for detailing these coupes, and I asked the whereabouts of the scientific evidence. There has been no satisfactory information brought forward to this place in any shape or form. Senator Faulkner indicated in this place, and to the people of Australia, that conservation groups have been consulted. How biased can he get?

I would have thought that a rigorous examination is an examination conducted by an independent person or an independent group of people who would cast a rational eye across all the coupes and determine, on a proper scientific basis, which ones will be preserved. But no, it was only the conservation groups. To assist the conservation groups, Senator Faulkner and his government—the Labor Party—provided funding to the tune of $120,000 to assist them in making that rigorous examination.

It is interesting; that investigation took seven weeks to consider which coupes were of high conservation value. How long is seven weeks? It is 49 days. Within that 49 days, they recommended 1,300 coupes. They were therefore recommending roughly 26 coupes per day or more than one per hour if they were working seven days a week, 24 hours a day. If there is one thing we know about the green and conservation movements, it is that they do not know what hard work is. I would have thought that it would be highly unlikely that they would have worked 24 hours a day, seven days a week, for that full seven-week period.

So they spent one hour per coupe and we are to believe, according to the minister, that it was a rigorous examination. I would suggest to senators rather that it was a farcical examination. Indeed, if we divide the $120,000 that they were given to look at all these coupes, we would find that they spent approximately $100 per coupe. It would not have even paid for all the petrol if they actually drove to the coupes, examined them and made a proper determination. One does suspect that they were sitting in offices and made their determinations by writing with pen on paper and not on the basis of a proper examination.

Of course, those interesting statistics that I have just mentioned do not take into account the possibility that they may have looked at other coupes that they then did not recommend. If that was the case, the $100 per coupe would be even less and the time spent per coupe would have been less than an hour per coupe.

So I would suggest that when one analyses this very sorry history the examination undertaken by the minister and his department was not rigorous, as he has sought to assert to the people of Australia. Indeed, the Prime Minister could not have been convinced of that. Why did the Prime Minister with a stroke of a pen say to the minister for the environment, `Out of your 1,300, I am just going to strike out 791'? I would have thought that was a fairly devastating prime ministerial rebuttal for the minister for the environment.

The people of Australia ought to be entitled to hear the truth about our resource heritage which is renewable in the resource industries and, in this case, in relation to the forest industries. There has been a lot of belly-aching as to what is happening to Australia's forests. Let us explode some of the myths.

In 1988 the World Bank published data that indicated that Australia, with a population of just 17 million, had 41 million hectares of closed forest. The aggregate area of closed forest for our neighbours such as Vietnam, Laos, Cambodia, Malaysia, Thailand, the Philippines and the two Koreas was 35 million hectares. Those countries, of course, have a total population of several hundred million and not the 17 million that we had. Yet we actually import wood products, including sawn wood, from the forests of those South-East Asian countries. If we lock up more of our forests, what will happen is that we will be importing even more timber from those South-East Asian countries and that will be affecting our balance of payments even more. We would then, of course, find our economy getting more and more out of kilter and suffering even higher interest rates.

The data indicates that Australia has 2.5 hectares of forest per head of population, and that is the 12th highest ratio in the world and 5 1/2 times the world average but, in terms of product removal or forest removal, Australia's rate of 0.5 of a cubic metre a hectare is equal 13th lowest in the world. The world average is 1.4 cubic metres a hectare or 2.8 times the Australian rate. Given the data that I have just referred to, the idea that Australia has so little forest as to prevent any timber production is clearly a nonsense.

I would urge people to deal with the facts. Only 20 per cent of Australia's public forests are, in fact, available for logging. So we are only talking about 20 per cent of the total forests within Australia. Out of that 20 per cent, less than one per cent of that 20 per cent is logged and regenerated annually. Native forest harvesting is conducted in a very controlled way under state supervision in accordance with plans and codes that protect all forest values. Populations of native animals are safeguarded by retention of habitat trees, stream side reserves and wildlife corridors. We never get to hear about that from the Greens who continually seek to denigrate this great industry.

The parts of the tree that are utilised by the paper industry and woodchips are those parts of the tree which generally are of too poor a quality to be used as sawlogs, and would otherwise be burned or simply wasted and left to rot. If harvesting were to cease in native forests completely, then hundreds of sawmill workers would lose their jobs and the country's import bill, of course, would skyrocket.

My home state of Tasmania relies very heavily on the timber industry. In general terms, one in seven of employed Tasmanians work within the timber industry or the satellite industries. We are continually reminded by the greens that we should develop specific world class industries and make a little niche market for ourselves. We in Tasmania have done that with Elphinstone Engineering which now exports timber equipment to the rest of the world. But where did it gain that experience? It was out of the Tasmanian forest, and without the Tasmanian timber industry there would be no Elphinstone Engineering on the east coast of Tasmania.

So when we talk about the timber industry it is not simply just the forest that we are talking about—it is the people, their communities, their lives, and the satellite industries such as engineering which also provide employment. In that context of its importance to the state of Tasmania, it is noteworthy that, during this debate yesterday and so far today, the only people from Tasmania who have got to their feet have been Senator Bell—of course, we know where the Australian Democrats stand; and they make no bones about where they stand—Senator Brian Harradine, supporting the industry, and Tasmania's Liberal senators.

The people of Tasmania have every right to ask: where are Tasmania's Labor senators on this issue? Where are they? Their silence has been absolutely deafening. At least Senator John Devereux had the decency to resign from the Labor Party, join the greens and get out of his policy schizophrenia which was to try to play both sides. He said, `I'm coming down on the greens' side.'

The Labor Party senators have a challenge, and that is to determine on which side of the debate they are going to fall. It was very interesting to read the first speech of Senator Shayne Murphy, a Labor senator from Tasmania, who waxed lyrical about his involvement in the timber workers union and how he fought for the workers and their lives, their families and their communities. Where has he been on this debate? There has not been a single word in this place. One would hope that he will get on his feet later on today, or some time during the course of the week, and tell the people of Australia where he stands. Is he one of those five who are prepared to resign from the Labor Party about this issue? The Australian Labor Party has sold short the timber industry, its workers, their families and their communities.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 1.25 p.m. to 2.00 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I remind the minister of June last year when he said:

QUESTION.PARA: The government has no intention whatsoever of diverting from the fiscal path that we have mapped out and identified in the course of recent budgets . . .

I could have quoted from any of many such comments in this place. I ask: in light of the Treasurer's bombshell announcement of the perilous state of the Australian banana republic economy, how can you now explain the complete failure of your government's economic policies and the electoral fraud you perpetrated upon the Australian community at the last election—an election campaign, I remind you, in which Mr Keating promised no new taxes, l-a-w tax cuts and a reduction in the budget deficit?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a little rough to talk about the economy being in a parlous or a perilous condition when you have a GDP increase running at 6.4 per cent at the moment and estimated at being 5 1/2 per cent over the full year as compared with 4 1/2 per cent in the original forecast. It is a bit difficult to regard it as perilous when you have an inflation rate currently running at just around two per cent and estimated to be no more than 3 1/4 for the whole year under the revised forecast.

PARA.TAB: It is a bit rough to say the economy is in a perilous condition when you have unemployment falling very significantly to an expected 8 1/2 per cent out turn for the year. It is a little rough to say the economy is in a perilous condition when you have interest rates running at an historically overall very much lower level than has been the case at any time during the last 20 or 30 years.

It is a little rough in particular for an opposition to be making these sorts of claims about an economy when their own leader, as Treasurer, left office with an inflation rate of over 11 per cent, an unemployment rate at over 10 per cent and an utter incapacity to produce growth in any year averaging more than around two per cent. That is the condition of the economy at the moment by contrast to what it was over a decade ago when you last had an opportunity to do something about it. Do not let us hear any more nonsense of this kind.

The reason for the necessity to adopt a more stringent approach to the fiscal deficit than we thought was going to be necessary at the time of the budget last year is essentially that stress is being placed by the blow-out in the current account deficit, creating a necessity for a bigger effort on savings in both the public sector, through the budget fiscal strategy, and of course the private sector. What is in our control is essentially the public side of it. That is why we will be trying to do more and why we will do more. We will bring the budget back into surplus two years earlier than was originally indicated.

Why has the current account deficit, which has stimulated that change of policy, blown out to the extent that it has done? Why has it blown out by $8 billion this year from the $18 billion estimated to the $26 billion that we are now talking about?

TALK.START.PARA: —You tell us!

—Well, one of the elements for a start is the weather—the drought, the rain. That has been an absolutely crucial phenomenon. The impact of that on this month's current account figures is self-evidently biting in a very serious way.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —A second element in the situation, if you will listen and not shout, is the massive surge in investment—14 per cent estimated in the budget; 24 per cent in the figures as they now emerge. What were you saying about 14 per cent when those figures were announced in the last budget? You were saying that that 14 per cent figure was a fiction. You were saying it was a furphy. You were saying it was an outrage. Well, it has come in at 24 per cent and when you have an investment running at 24 per cent of course you suck in producer goods, of course you suck in capital goods, and that is what has been happening. Then you have had a worldwide two per cent increase in interest rates—worldwide, quite apart from any factors operating within the country.

PARA.TAB: When you add all those factors up together, you have an impact on the current account of nearly $5 billion—around $4 1/2 billion out of the $8 billion that was indicated. The other increase contributing to that blow-out in the current account deficit is obviously the impact of the overall flourish and momentum in the economy which is sucking in other forms of goods, other than purely capital goods.

That is why the current account deficit has blown out—by a combination of those factors. That is why it has been necessary to do something more on the public savings side. That is why it will be necessary for us to approach—in a systematic, measured, careful and thoughtful way, appropriate to the circumstances of the economy at the time—the need for a revision of the fiscal situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer in the Senate. In light of today's publication of the December balance of payments figures and the revised official economic forecasts released by the Treasurer yesterday, can the minister inform the Senate of the government's response to the current economic statistics?

—Looking at the current economic statistics, of course we are expecting a higher level of economic growth than forecast; we are expecting a higher level of job increases than forecast. The outstanding economic performer has been business investment. In the budget we estimated that business investment would rise by 14 1/2 per cent.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Evans has said in answer to the earlier question, at the time we forecast that increase in business investment the opposition and some pundits rubbished the forecast as being unrealistic and deceitful. Of course, as it has turned out, it is wrong—but not in a deceitful way, in a very positive way. We were conservative and cautious in our estimate of 14 1/2 per cent. The revised estimate figure is 24 per cent growth in business investment and, importantly, for investment in capital equipment and plant and equipment, the figure is expected to be greater than 24 per cent.

The reason for this performance, of course, is that inflation has remained low. The underlying inflation forecast rate is for 2 1/4 per cent; the headline rate, of course, is a little higher than that. But I repeat: the underlying inflation rate is 2 1/4 per cent. I remind the Senate that, when the now Leader of the Opposition, the most recent Leader of the Opposition, was Treasurer, he presided over an inflation rate that never fell below eight per cent and, when he left office, was at the level of 11 per cent.

Company profits have also been a strong and bullish figure in the market. On trend terms, company profits have increased over the last 13 quarters of our government. Importantly as well, competitiveness of the economy has gone sharply upwards. We are almost now 20 per cent more competitive as an economy in the world than we were three years ago. Over the last 10 years—the 10 years of our government—the Australian economy has in world terms become 30 per cent more competitive than it was before. Productivity has increased strongly; that has been a feature of the economic performance over recent years. Over the last four years national productivity has averaged an annual growth rate of two per cent a year, which is a tribute to the management of the economy by this government.

The consequences of these changes—increased productivity, increased competitiveness in the economy—mean, as I said yesterday in answer to a question, that manufactured exports have been a strong performer for the Australian economy. We are seeing a diversification of our export base with manufactured goods and services taking a much bigger role, so that we are not now almost exclusively an exporter of under-value-added mineral products and raw materials or bulk materials from the agricultural side. We are an exporter of manufactured goods significantly too and of sophisticated services as well. Since 1985-86 manufactured goods have increased in exports more than three times—they have trebled—and the most elaborately transformed, the most complex and sophisticated manufactured goods have gone up by more than 400 per cent in that time.

Business investment has added $2 billion to the current account deficit, but that has been in building up strong stock for sustainable growth. Those in the Australian business community are, in fact, investing in extending their own capacity, ensuring that Australia can take a bigger share of world manufacturing, ensuring that the capacity of the economy is extended, taking the heat off inflation—and that means employment, as Senator Evans has said, which is now forecast to grow by 3 3/4 per cent, with unemployment to go down to 8.5 per cent, which is a much stronger performance in the economy for those who are concerned with employment opportunity. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the President's gallery of the Standing Committee on Local Government and Labour of the Norwegian Storting led by Mr Roger Gudmundseth. On behalf of honourable senators, I welcome you to the Senate and hope that your visit is productive and rewarding.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is the minister aware that the December current account deficit of $2.4 billion is the highest monthly figure in Australia's history and higher than the run of deficits which prompted Mr Keating in 1986 to warn that Australia was on its way to becoming a banana republic? Is the minister aware that this figure puts Australia squarely in the league of those banana republic Latin American economies which are now in the middle of a financial crisis brought on by their chronic foreign debt? Is he aware that Australia has a current account deficit barely one per cent of GDP below Mexico's and a foreign debt level almost double that of Mexico's? What explanation does the government propose to give to the Australian people for its failed policies, which have led directly to this disastrous situation? And why, in the light of this developing crisis, is the government failing to act immediately?

—The preliminary balance of payments estimates for December show a currently estimated seasonally adjusted current account deficit of $2.4 billion. That particular sum, though large, is within the range of market expectations, not outside it.

PARA.TAB: Let me explain the components so you see how it has come together. The increase was due to a rise in the merchandise trade deficit, with imports increasing by six per cent while exports fell by five per cent. The fall in exports was mainly due to a decline in rural exports. The impact of the drought has obviously been making itself manifest. It was inevitable that that would happen. It was inevitable that it would start showing up in the figures about now, and that has been fully factored into our expectations for the remainder of this year—and indeed into market expectations.

Imports of capital goods rose by 28 per cent, heavily influenced by one purchase—as they often are in particular months. In this instance, it was an LNG tanker valued at $362 million. Those imports, of course, have their own significance in adding to the productive capacity of the economy. They will play an important role in boosting future exports. They are not to be sneezed at as in some way being something bad for the economy. Imports of consumption goods reflect the overall health of the economy—the number of people getting back to work and the continued relaxation of inflation. Imports of consumption goods rose by two per cent. Imports of intermediate goods fell by two per cent.

The slow growth in exports reflects partially not only the drought problem but also lower prices for non-rural commodity exports—iron ore and coal. The growing strength that we are seeing all around the world economy at the moment should, on everybody's estimates, see a gradual improvement in the outlook for those sorts of exports, with good prospects both for higher volumes and for higher prices.

The response by the government to this is as I described it in my last answer. When you put these figures together, you are looking at an uncomfortably high percentage of GDP—we are fully conscious of that—and it is necessary to respond accordingly with a greater effort of the public savings kind. But do not get carried away by these comparisons between the situation now and the situation in the mid-1980s, when again we approached similarly high levels of current account deficit as a percentage of GDP.

If you take the basic figures, you will see the points of difference. In 1985-86 growth was running at 2.2 per cent; now it is 6.4 per cent. Inflation was then 8.4 per cent; the forecast inflation at the moment is a maximum of 3 1/2 per cent for this year. Of course, the underlying rate at the moment is only around two per cent. Mortgage interest rates then were up around 15 1/2 per cent; now they are 10 1/2 per cent. Of course, as has been said over and over again, you had an infinitely less competitive environment.

Net foreign debt has fallen by $12.6 billion since September 1993. It has fallen from 42 per cent of GDP to 37 per cent of GDP. The important thing always when you are talking about foreign debt is your capacity to service it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are far too many interjections on my left. It is in the interests of everybody in an important matter like this that the minister be heard.

—What matters with foreign debt is your capacity to service it. Our capacity to service it is as good as it has ever been with a debt-service ratio now running at around only 11 or 12 per cent. If you want to go back to 1983, let me remind you again what happened. What we inherited in 1983 was 11 per cent inflation and 10 per cent unemployment and growth running at about two per cent. If you reckon that was leaving an economy in good shape for ordinary Australian people, then you found the answer to that in the 1983 election and you will find it again if you persist with this line of approach.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The government certainly did inherit some things in 1983. It inherited a foreign debt of $23 billion. It is now $163 billion and that is more than twice what it was in the banana republic warning given by the then Treasurer in 1986. Are you trying to tell the Australian people that with a debt level more than twice what you had in 1986 this situation is not of greater crisis proportions than it was then? Is that what you are trying to hoodwink the Australian people into believing?

—There was something else we inherited in 1983, and that was a fiscal deficit of $9.6 billion, against a budget forecast of $4 billion which honest John Howard said was going to be $6 billion, notwithstanding advice from his own Treasury that the figure was not four, wasn't six, but, in fact, was eight and then nine and then he got advice it was 9.6. That is what we inherited. We inherited a bunch of lies from an incompetent Treasurer. That is what you have got to offer the Australian public.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: United States Dairy Export Subsidy Program

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. The recent extension of the United States dairy export subsidy program to Australia's markets in Asia is clearly a matter of concern to Australia's dairy farmers and puts at risk millions of dollars of export income. I understand that you specifically raised this matter with the United States Deputy Secretary of State, Strobe Talbott, at a meeting this morning. Can you advise how Mr Talbott responded?

—As Senator Burns has been the chair of the rural committee of the Senate for some time, it is a matter that I know he has had a continuing interest in. That is why I am pleased to have the opportunity to respond to what I think most people in the Senate would agree is an important issue and one which many senators, certainly those on this side, would like to hear the answer to. It is an issue that is important not just for dairy farmers but for Australians.

PARA.TAB: Both the Australian government and the Australian dairy industry have made it clear that we are deeply disappointed by the United States decision to introduce export subsidies into the Asian dairy market and specifically into markets which the Australian industry has assiduously worked to develop. I specifically sought a meeting with the US Deputy Secretary of State, Strobe Talbott, to discuss this issue.

I found both the tone and the substance of the meeting with Mr Talbott constructive and encouraging. He said that he wanted to provide Australia with what he termed a reassuring context in which future decisions on the implementation of the dairy export subsidy program were made. I will come back to some of the specifics in a moment.

While Mr Talbott has come to Australia to discuss important regional security matters, I made the point at the very outset that we considered the US dairy export subsidies a very big issue in the bilateral relationship—and I believe Australians do—and that if the US were to take the even more serious step of subsidised wheat sales to, for example, Indonesia, the issue would be much bigger again. In response, Mr Talbott stressed that he fully recognised the seriousness with which Australia viewed the recent decision and he said that he saw this issue as a major one. I sought to register, and I believe I did register firmly, the extent of potential damage to Australian dairy farmers and the fact that the US actions are not even in the interests of US taxpayers or the efficient US dairy farmers.

The evidence I was able to provide to Mr Talbott, with the assistance of the Dairy Industry Council and a chart provided by the Dairy Industry Council which I will table in the Senate, shows that not only is the United States subsidising but also the subsidy levels are substantially in excess of what is necessary to make sales. With the nature of the dairy market and the growing demand for dairy products in Asia, it is economic nonsense for the United States to be acting in the way it is. It is also trade irresponsibility. This chart graphically illustrates this point. If the United States government has got money to throw away, it will be much better used addressing the very serious issues raised by the President in his state of the union address to Congress, meeting the needs of Americans in need instead of attacking the incomes of Australian dairy farmers.

Mr Talbott, in response, made three key points. He undertook to convey back to Washington every nuance of what the Australian government had said to him on this matter. He said that President Clinton had given the Prime Minister, as we know, assurances on the implementation of the US export subsidy scheme and that the President would stick to those assurances. He gave me the assurance that whatever the US might do subsequently in regard to the export subsidy, it would act in a manner which was consistent with the spirit and the substance of the Uruguay Round.

We are concerned and will continue with the cooperation of the Dairy Industry Council and the dairy industry to provide the United States administration with accurate market intelligence as a basis for the US to set more commercially sensible export subsidy levels. If it must subsidise—of course, we wish it would not—we can try to contribute to minimise the impact on Australian exporters and also US taxpayers.

I sought during the meeting to drive home and reinforce our concerns so that they are heard in Washington. The Dairy Industry Council, through Mr Rowley and others, is there in Washington with the ambassador making that point now. We are very concerned about the impact of this on Australian dairy farmers, on Australian exports and on the Australian economy. We would be very concerned about the impact on the relationship between similar programs on grains and developments arising in the farm bill. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I too refer to this morning's balance of payments figures which show a huge deterioration in the nation's current account position. Can the minister tell the Senate whether the government has learned from the 1980s and will strategically tackle each of the components which make up the current account deficit rather than relying solely on the use of interest rates? Will the government rule out any further increase in interest rates—not generally but specifically—as a response to the current account deficit, or was the Prime Minister's talking down further interest rate rises on television last night just part of a stunt for the New South Wales election campaign?

—I have already described what the primary components of the blow-out in the current account deficit are. Our capacity to address each one of those individual components is obviously somewhat limited, not least in the case of the weather. But, so far as investment is concerned, which is the other major component of it, that is very much a product of success. When you have a booming economy, when you have hauled yourself out of recession and when you move down the path of investment running at 24 per cent rather than the 14 per cent that nobody believed was possible just a few months ago, obviously that has implications. Obviously, the other major component of it, the rise in world interest rates, which impact on what we have to pay overseas in servicing our debt, is beyond our control as well.

PARA.TAB: But the overall situation does have to be addressed. You cannot be running figures at that level. You have to increase the saving stock, both public and private, in order to be able to pay for deficits of that kind. Thus it is that the Treasurer emphasised yesterday the need to go back to the fiscal strategy and to accelerate the pace at which we get the budget back into surplus. We will be bringing it back into surplus in 1996-97 in the budget that we produce in May.

The components of that particular budget will be undoubtedly all three—the outlays side, the revenue side and the assets side. It will be a matter of careful balance and decision to see how that particular balance sorts itself out. The primary emphasis will undoubtedly be on the outlays side. We will not even get to a consideration of revenues measures until we see what more it is absolutely possible to do on the outlays side, as we have done rigorously and relentlessly over the years, but we will be doing it again because we understand our obligation.

We think it is desirable that more of the burden of redressing this situation and contributing to savings be through fiscal policy—the budget and those three components of it. We would like to be able to avoid a further reliance on interest rate increases in order to slow down demand in the community as a whole, because that is a very blunt instrument and it has a very adverse effect on private householders, as we all know. It has not been a blunt instrument so far. It has necessarily been a carefully applied instrument because of the way in which the lead times and the lag times work.

We are still operating in an interest rate environment that is very much lower than the one which has prevailed over the last few decades, not just the last few years. It is an interest rate environment in Australia which is very much less than the one which was prevailing right through the 1980s, and certainly at the time the coalition was in office. Do not lose that particular perspective.

The Prime Minister said yesterday—he has been widely quoted—that he does not believe there is cause for any adjustment. That is why, as the Prime Minister said, in terms of policy we will be looking at the budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, you say that some things are beyond the government's control. But some things are definitely within the government's control; you talked about them in general terms. Does the government think it is time to take action to make sure that the scarce capital which flows into the country goes into productive rather than speculative areas? Is the government ready to seriously question whether selling assets is the best way of funding our spending habits?

—We are not in the business of selling assets other than as a marginal addition to the budgetary process. What might be possible in that respect will be a matter for careful assessment. As I indicated, the primary emphasis will be on the outlays side. But, particularly given our status as one of the very lowest taxed countries in the whole OECD, it is necessary to contemplate doing something more on the revenue side.

PARA.TAB: Of course it is wholly desirable that any capital coming into the country be directed to productive rather than speculative enterprises. That is one reason why we have continued, in an FIRB context, to maintain some restrictions on residential real estate and so on in order to avoid fuelling booms of that kind, which are not helpful to the economy as a whole.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does National Mutual fit into that?

—Do not let us be too feudal, medieval or prehistoric in our attitude to this. The overwhelming benefit of the foreign capital that has come into this country has been for ordinary Australians through adding to the health, production and productivity of the economy.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction in his capacity as the minister responsible for Australia's national space program. I am aware that the EXPRESS capsule, which was due to be recovered at Woomera last month, did not achieve its correct orbit and was destroyed in an uncontrolled re-entry over the Pacific Ocean. Can the minister advise the Senate what effect this unfortunate outcome will have on the minister's intention to revitalise Woomera as a centre for space related activity?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Foreman for his question. There was a lot of publicity in January about Australia's involvement in the EXPRESS program, which stands for the experimental re-entry space system. It was a joint German-Japanese funded program valued at about $100 million that involved a rocket and satellite being launched from the Kagashima space port in Japan on Monday, 16 January to be recovered at Woomera on Saturday, 21 January. The recovered satellite was to be examined for a number of scientific and industry related experiments. Unfortunately, as the publicity has shown, the capsule did not achieve a correct orbit after launch. It is believed to have burned up and made an uncontrolled re-entry into the Pacific Ocean with no danger to human life.

PARA.TAB: I have subsequently written to the German minister, Dr Ruttgers, expressing my disappointment at the outcome and explaining that we hope the setback for this launch of EXPRESS did not have any long-term negative impact on his country's overall space program and that we wish to continue to be involved in any future EXPRESS program launches and recoveries. It had been proposed by the German space program to have at least another four launches of this satellite.

ANSWER.PARA: While some senators opposite interject, they do not realise that Australia was being paid $1.5 million by the German space agency to be employed in recovering the satellite at Woomera. That is money for Australia and jobs for Australians in a space industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, don't let Faulkner near it.

—I am sure that Senator Kemp, and I am surprised that Senator Hill, a South Australian, would be dismissive of South Australia's involvement in this program. Nevertheless, we are hopeful that the German commitment will continue. In the meantime we will have another program, a specific Japanese program, called ALFLEX, which is an automatic landing flight experiment, as part of the long-term space program. We are negotiating with the Japanese that Woomera can be used for the testing of the vehicle. This would be a one-third scale model of a proposed space vehicle as part of the long-term HOPE program. The negotiations have not been completed but already the Japanese have indicated that of all the sites they have seen around the world they believe Woomera is the best place to test at an experimental level this space vehicle.

PARA.TAB: If they do get agreement from the Japanese government in the years ahead to spend $A2 billion to have a full-scale program, we believe Woomera would still be the preferred site to recover that experimental vehicle on probably up to 10 occasions a year which would mean, again, involvement of Australian people, Australian jobs and Australian expertise. This is one way Australia can very usefully re-enter a space program. As Senator Kemp might not know, a Senate committee took a bipartisan view some years ago to encourage Australia to be re-involved in space programs as it was in the 1960s. That was supported by Liberal senators as well as Labor senators. This is all part of achieving the outcome which this Senate requested the Australian government to achieve. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. Minister, your department recently provided $44,000 to the Nature Conservation Council of New South Wales to fund an assessment of high conservation areas proposed for logging in northern New South Wales. The assessment purports to have been done by consultants and coordinated with assistance from a group of people including `Natalie and others'. Who were the consultants? What are their qualifications and those of their assistants? What was the nature and extent of the consultations and what were the methodology and criteria used in the assessment?
—In fact, four conservation councils—
—Who is Natalie? Any relation to Kristine?
—Order!
—That just puts you down as a slimy bastard, Macdonald. And you know it. So do your colleagues.
—Order! Senator Faulkner.
—In fact, four conservation—
—Mr President, I take a point of order. The remark from Senator Ray was very clearly heard by the whole chamber.
—I chose to ignore it but I would ask you to withdraw, Senator Ray.
—I withdraw, but it won't be forgotten, Senator.
—Order!

—On the point of order: if Senator Ray is being asked to withdraw that remark, and that remark accordingly does appear in Hansard, Senator Macdonald's interjection ought to also be recorded in Hansard, which of course was: `Natalie. Is that any relation to Kristine?'
—Order! I have no way of judging the parliamentary nature of that comment so I will not ask him to withdraw.

—In fact, four conservation councils received money in the process that Senator Alston referred to, which goes to, of course, the accountability of grants to conservation organisations who were involved in the high conservation value exercise that was undertaken by my department. They did sign a legally enforceable agreement specifying the work to be undertaken, the timetable that was required and binding those bodies to standard terms and conditions that were set out by the department for grant recipients.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the state of New South Wales, the Nature Conservation Council of New South Wales was paid $38,180 plus $6,240 for additional specified work. In relation to all the states, the total amount of money in volved—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. This is an appalling performance. I asked about one—
—Mr President, Senator Alston should not be allowed to get up on purported points of order and make debating points.
—Senator Alston has not made his point of order yet, but I would ask him to get to it.
—Mr President—
—Would you mind; I am on my feet.
—Order! Senator Evans, Senator Alston has not made his point of order. Would you be seated. I call Senator Alston.

—The point of order is very much one of relevance. My question related to one assessment in the northern part of New South Wales. Firstly, we were told quite gratuitously that there were four studies carried out. Secondly, we were told about the composition of the money—
—What is your point of order?

—I am just making the point. My question asked very specifically about the qualifications, the criteria and the methodology involved in one single assessment. So far we have heard everything but anything to do with that assessment.

—Mr President, on the point of order: I ask you to rule that that kind of purported point of order by Senator Alston beginning with his assertion that X was appalling and Y was wrong in ABC respects is simply not a point of order on any view as to the scope of the standing order in relation to relevance or anything else. It is a grotesque abuse of the procedures of this house in question time, and I ask you to rule accordingly.

—Mr President, on the point of order: to back up Senator Evans, you may as a senator intervene on points to do with standing orders. The ability for you to recognise anyone on a point of order is given so no-one in this chamber is disadvantaged. But if it is misused simply to get up because you do not like the answer or you want to argue against it, that is an abuse of you recognising someone for a point of order.

PARA.TAB: Two years ago this chamber went to the trouble of making official noting of questions so these matters could be debated after question time. We got rid of the unofficial procedure that required leave. We structured it in such a way. What has developed, especially from Senator Alston, is simply to interrupt a minister in his answer at whatever point he does but immediately launch into debating it rather than drawing the attention of you, Mr President, directly to the point of order or a breach of the point of order that he wants to make. If we let that go on, question time will simply become a case of who can stand up first and slag someone else.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on the point of order: I want to make it very clear what the question was. I said that the minister's department recently provided $44,000 to the conservation council. Then I said—
—It is not a point of order.

—I am just explaining the relevance. I went on to say that the assessment purported to have been done by consultants coordinated with assistants. Then I asked who were the consultants, what were their qualifications, what was the nature and extent of the consultations and what were the methodology and criteria.

PARA.TAB: In the 2 1/2 minutes that Senator Faulkner was on his feet he told us there were four conservation councils that had received money, he then gave a breakdown of the figures that were paid to the New South Wales conservation council—$38,180 together with $6,240 for additional works—and then he started to talk about what was happening in the rest of the country.

Mr President, do not be misled. My point of order is related purely to relevance. I am very concerned to obtain an answer to the question I asked. If Senator Faulkner is unable to do that, it is quite within your capacity to ask him to sit down. But I ask you to ignore the sorts of red herrings thrown up by Senator Evans and Senator Ray, which did not in any shape or form suggest that my point of relevance was wrong. They simply tried to suggest that I was debating the point. I hope I have demonstrated quite comprehensively why I am not.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I have made it very clear very often, it is impossible for me to judge relevance except in a very general way. I am not in a position to order the minister to answer in a certain way or to address certain issues. There is no point of order. It is one of a continuing series of specious points of order that are raised so that the questioner can make a statement. It does not help the processes of this house for that to go on.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I understand the point that you have made in relation to that, but you would be entitled at the end of an answer to say that you gave the minister tolerance, hoping he would become relevant, that he did not and that you did not expect that kind of answer to be given in the future. You do that on points of order and plenty of other things that we do. It is within your power to listen to an answer and say afterwards that it never became relevant to the real question and to tick the minister off and upgrade the standards in this place. You can do that.

—Mr President, on the point of order: on at least three or four occasions the President has upheld points of order on relevance. He has done that, but he is not and cannot be expected to rule on detailed matters that are beyond his knowledge. There is no way the President can establish whether the subject matter that Senator Faulkner is going to matches in absolute minutiae what Senator Alston has asked. The President then has to, according to the proposition you put, rely on Senator Alston's judgment as to whether the answer is satisfactory. That is a nonsense.
—I made the point quite clear in my original response. I suggest you read Hansard, Senator Vanstone.

—As I was saying in relation to the initial grant—this is important—it was paid in instalments. There was the first one following the acceptance of the grant conditions, there was a second following the completion of a progress report—which is approximately halfway through the process—with the final payment being made after the report had been received by the department.

PARA.TAB: The conservation groups were also required to provide a draft report one week prior to the final report to enable portfolio comment. As I have indicated previously in the chamber, that was one input into the identification of high conservation value areas which my portfolio and portfolio agencies undertake. I also say that, having had notice of motion given for a return to order in the Senate asking for these sorts of details on the process that Senator Alston has asked a question about, I have asked my department prepare the material. It is in the process of doing that. I will be accepting that that motion be taken as formal, but the time frame in relation to providing that information was deferred as a result of a motion this morning from Senator Macdonald. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Do I understand from that answer that the minister has not the slightest idea of the details of an assessment commissioned by the Nature Conservation Council of New South Wales for which his department cheerfully handed over $44,000? If we proceed on the basis that the minister had four minutes to give even the vaguest answer and he could not do it, will he go away, find out, come back and tell us all of the things that I asked about?

PARA.TAB: An incident having occurred in the gallery—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I remind people in the visitors gallery that spontaneous eruptions of applause like that are disorderly and will not be tolerated. I do not want to be forced to clear the—

PARA.TAB: An incident having occurred in the gallery—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! If they go on, I will be forced to clear the gallery.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. When the Mabo bill went through this chamber, there was widespread applause in the gallery and the President did not make a ruling. I suggest we have a consistent ruling. If it is good enough for one group to applaud, it is good enough for others.

—Mr President, on the point of order: one cannot help but notice that, when people in the gallery broke into applause on your point of order, your ruling to sit down Senator Gareth Evans, I did not notice you ticking them off for giving you some applause.
—Are senators really encouraging me to accept any sort of behaviour in the galleries? If they are, I ask them to go away and seriously consider what they are asking me to do.

—Senator Faulkner did quite irrelevantly refer also to a standard agreement. Given that you think it is important, could you make that available and table it in the chamber together with all the other relevant material that I have asked for? Why won't you realise that, if there is one thing you are not very good at, it is trying to fix the conservation vote like Richo did.

—I was outlining a little earlier that in fact there is a return to order, notice of which was given by one of Senator Alston's colleagues on the first day of sitting. It related to me, as the minister for the environment, providing all the information that Senator Alston has asked for in his question and his supplementary question. I have indicated that it is my intention to agree with that motion and declare it formal. You ask: will I provide it this afternoon? This morning Senator Macdonald moved that that return to order be deferred to another day of sitting. I say to you, Senator Alston, very clearly that, as far as I am concerned, that matter and those documents will be made available to the Senate, as the return to order from the opposition requests.(Time expired)

—My question is directed to Senator Evans, representing the Prime Minister. Is the minister aware of the comments of Mr Adrian de Bruin, the Managing Director of SEAS Sapfor—one of Australia's leading timber companies—that sawn wood products from plantations could very feasibly replace wood products from Australia's native forests within the next two to five years? Do you agree with the comments from this leader of the timber industry that `time is running out for our native forests, wilderness areas and endangered species'? Is it the government's view that the future of the timber industry lies entirely with plantation forestry? Isn't it time the federal government put in place a timber industry plan which maps out a transition to a plantation based sustainable timber industry?

—The government's attitude towards the future of the timber industry was well and truly mapped out and stated in the context of the national forest policy statement in 1992. The future of this industry is manifestly not one that the Commonwealth government can determine alone. It is quintessentially a matter for the states in relation to which the Commonwealth only has extremely limited powers. Nonetheless, within the context of those powers, we have done our best to try, with the states, to negotiate an approach to the industry which gets a necessary balance of all the competing values that are involved in this particular area, and that is exactly what the national forest policy statement of 1992 does. Regrettably, it is still lacking the signature of Tasmania but it has got everyone else's. It is to be hoped within that framework that we can get a result that you and those on the other side of this equation can regard as sensible.

PARA.TAB: I remind you of the elements of that statement so far as the national goals and objectives are concerned. They are very largely, if not wholly, consistent with the philosophy that you have espoused in that question. So far as conservation is concerned, the goals are to maintain an extensive and permanent native forest estate in Australia and to manage that estate in an ecologically sustainable manner so as to conserve the full suite of relevant values the forest can provide for current and future generations. No statement could be clearer than that.

As to wood production and industry development, the goal is for Australia to develop internationally competitive and ecologically sustainable wood production and wood product industries. So far as decision making is concerned, the goal is to reduce fragmentation and duplication in land use decision making processes between the states and the Commonwealth. We all know that that is one of the biggest problems of all in trying to get rational decision making in this area.

The objectives also go to private native forests because they can be as significant in the long term as the forests in the public domain and it is crucial to ensure that they too are managed in an ecologically sustainable manner. The goal so far as plantations is concerned, on which you place particular emphasis in your question, is to expand the commercial plantations of both softwoods and hardwoods so as to provide an additional economically viable, reliable, high quality wood resource for industry.

I do not think anyone believes that it is possible to wholly phase out the logging and so on of native forests. What is certainly possible is to deal with it in a way that produces not only ecological sustainability but also an extensive and permanent national native forest estate which does conserve the full suite of values that forests can provide—including biological diversity, heritage and Aboriginal and other cultural values, as well as purely environmental ones. So they are our objectives. That is what we believe is achievable and that is what we will be continuing to work away at achieving with the states, given the very limited range of policy weapons that we have at our disposal. That is almost certainly the best we can do.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Could the minister tell us, in view of the 1992 statement by the then Prime Minister, what specifically has the federal government done to ensure that there is an expansion of plantation forestry in Australia?
—That is not my portfolio area and I do not want to talk on that off the top of my head. I will give you a detailed answer as soon as I can.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. The human rights subcommittee of this parliament and the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade in its report last year requested the government to make bilateral and multilateral representations to urge the cessation of coercive population programs. Because China's brutal one child per family policy involves forced abortions and coerced sterilisations, including castrations, what action has the government taken in respect of our report? Has the human rights section of your department considered the human rights implications of your government's bill introduced yesterday which would have the effect of forcibly returning to China a woman asylum seeker, pregnant with her second child, to the torture of forced abortion?

—The reference to torture of forced abortion is a pretty large assumption in that particular context and I do not think there is any reason whatever for Senator Harradine to assume that that would be the outcome in that particular case. There is an obvious problem, as has been identified by Senator Bolkus, with the court ruling which makes potentially almost the entire population of 1.2 billion people in China refugees simply by virtue of the population policies and the one child limitation that applies in that country. Manifestly, that is simply an unsustainable basis on which to conduct any kind of rational refugee humanitarian policy. That has been the view taken by the UN High Commission on Refugees and others.

PARA.TAB: I do not think we have anything to defend in that respect. We are concerned and have been concerned all along—as Senator Harradine well knows from the extensive debate on these matters in estimates committees and elsewhere—about those elements of the Chinese population program which are coercive in character. A number of representations have been made on that subject and will continue to be made, not least in the context of the human rights delegations that we have managed to send to China on two occasions and which we are now trying to negotiate for a further instalment.

I cannot answer off the top of my head what has been done in the last few months specifically on that topic. I will seek such further information as I can and let Senator Harradine know. But Senator Harradine knows that I fully share his distaste at anything that is coercive in this particular area. He knows how hard we have been working with the UNFPA and others to try to get accepted in China standards and practices which are consistent with basic human rights rules and principles in this particular area.

Would that we were able to do more in that respect, but we are certainly trying and we do so, to the extent that we participate in family planning programs in China—fund them and so on, or fund international agencies—from the perspective that we genuinely believe it is much more influential to be working from inside the system, by example in this way, rather than simply standing back and addressing objections to it from the outside.

Senator Harradine has debated all of this with me on multiple occasions. I guess we are destined to differ in some continuing respects about this, but please do not differ in our assessment of the nature of the problem and the genuineness of our attempts to do something, however small, to change it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Senator Gareth Evans denied that there was any coercion in China's one child family policy up until six years ago. I repeat my question: has the human rights section of his department considered the human rights implications of this bill? If it has done so, will the minister table that particular report? Secondly, in some parts of China, as the minister would know, for every 100 boys born there are only 79 girls born. Much of this is a result of ultrasound technology. Could the minister give an absolute guarantee that the ultrasound machines that AIDAB provided to China have not been used for the purposes of aborting girl children?

—I am familiar with that unhappy statistic that Senator Harradine mentions. It does certainly make colourable some aspects of the population policy as it presently applies. We have never doubted that there are more than colourable dimensions to that. The point is: what can you best do about it? That is an issue again, as I have said, that we have debated.

PARA.TAB: As to the nature of the advice that was available to Senator Bolkus's department or to the cabinet, I will have to check that. My recollection does not extend at the moment. I will see what further information I am able to give Senator Harradine.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. Minister, is it true that you wrote to the state minister for natural resources in Victoria on 17 October last advising him that a coupe in Upper Hensleigh Creek could not be logged because, among other things, `it included the nationally rare plant Eucalyptus denticulata'?

—Not being a botanist and wanting to ensure that the Latin botanical name of the plant mentioned by Senator Gibson is correct, I will certainly check my correspondence file on that and I will confirm it with him.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, I actually have a copy of your letter—signed by you. Is it not a fact that Eucalyptus denticulata, in your letter quoted as a nationally rare plant, was formerly known as Eucalyptus nitens, or shining gum, and that it is an abundant forest species in eastern Victoria and southern New South Wales? Is it not also a fact that thousands of hectares of this species is contained within the Errinundra National Park which is adjoining this area? Is this not another example of the shoddy process that you and your department went into in nominating the 1,300 coupes?
—I congratulate Senator Gibson on answering his own question.
—My question is directed to the Minister for Family Services. What action has the minister taken to ensure parents have a national voice on child-care policies and issues?

—As many people in this place would know, there has been since this government came to office a very significant growth in the number of child-care places—from about 43,000 or 46,000 when we came into office to around a quarter of a million now. Last year we commissioned a number of reports to examine child care to make sure we were fully aware of and up to date with the state of play in the child-care area.

PARA.TAB: A concern that emerged was not about the number of places, although there is still an ongoing concern about that, but about how child care was actually meeting the needs of parents. The first thing parents asked for was places. Those places have been delivered and will continue to be delivered. Parents were also concerned about quality, and we are delivering on that, but particularly things like flexibility, hours that centres are open, penalty fees and so on.

To that end, and because I am very concerned that child care does meet the needs of parents, I have established a national advisory council on child care which is made up of parents and parent users of child care. The 12 member council includes people who either have used or are currently using a whole variety of child-care facilities that we provide. Those members have a wide experience and expertise across child care and represent the whole range of the child-care industry.

I have met with the council once, and it will be holding a two-day meeting in Canberra in February. I have asked it to look at three issues in particular: flexibility of services, a complaints mechanism, and parental involvement in the delivery of child care. There is a very big disparity between parent participation, and I think it is very important that we hear from the parents how and to what extent they might want to be involved in the child-care centres and the care that is being provided for their children.

The council is to be chaired by Christine Woodrow. She is a lecturer in early childhood development at the university of central Queensland in Rockhampton. I believe that, with the deputy chairman Mr Peter Cozens, who is a research officer from Sydney, we have established a council that will speak on behalf of parents. That is the council's brief. On the evidence I have so far, the members of the council are very pleased to represent parents' voices and are setting up ways in which they can hear from parents.

It is a very exciting recognition of a new stage of the child-care industry in this country. We have the places—not all but we are well on target. We have the accreditation system delivering quality care with something like 88 per cent of those centres registered and participating. We now have a committee that ensures that parents' concerns are going to be available and accessible to government—a critical part of continuing to deliver the excellent kind of child care that the community has wanted and now welcomes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.
—I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Hill moving a motion that questions may be put to Ministers until 28 questions, including supplementary questions, have been asked and answered.

TALK.START.PARA: —You disrupted question time.
—I beg your pardon!

PARA.TAB: Senator Robert Ray interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You will presumably ask him to withdraw that.
—Order! Withdraw that, Senator.
—I withdraw.

—Occasionally, in the process of ministers being accountable to the parliament, it is convenient that a series of questions be asked and answered. Today is clearly one of those days because the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) is being asked a series of questions relating to the process of assessment of certain areas for their conservation value. The evidence so far, on the basis of just two questions, is that there is very little evidence at all that the public can be confident that the process was carried out in a way that accurately reflected a scientific assessment of the conservation values of those areas.

PARA.TAB: To be assured of that situation—and the community is entitled to be so assured, because taxpayers' money is being expended to Natalie and others, which is apparently the basis upon which such assessments have been made—it is necessary in the interests of proper parliamentary practice that the series of questions continue. It is not very often that we ask for this privilege, but we do so today because obviously the public are entitled to know. Certainly those who are losing money, those who are struggling in small business and who are surrounding the parliament at this time because this government is depriving them of their reasonable business opportunities, are also entitled to know the basis upon which this minister reached his conclusions.

We therefore ask the Senate today to suspend standing orders in order that I might move this motion to give the Senate the opportunity to ask this series of questions of the minister and hear his answers in order that the public might then be able to make an assessment of his performance. Whether or not the government is prepared to accede to this demand will indicate just how willing the minister is to stand by his ministerial responsibility.

If this government wants to run and hide, if this minister wants to hide from his responsibilities, the government will vote against this. If the minister is prepared to stand up and try to argue that he has done his job properly and that he has nothing to hide, then he will say, `I'll take your questions.' This is a test. It will be very interesting to see the way in which this government responds.

Furthermore, it also will be interesting to see what the Democrats and the other Independents do. Where are the Greens today on these important matters; where are they? Why aren't they participating in this process? They will all get an opportunity to debate. Is the parliament going to be able to hold this minister to account or not? This vote will clarify the situation.
