TALK.START.PARA: —How the government responds to this particular motion will have much more to do with how we respond to pathetic adolescent stunting of the kind we have just heard from Senator Hill than having anything to do with the merits of the procedures that have been outlined. I am advised by the clerk that we average in question time, and have been arranging over the last couple of years, around about 23, 24 questions and supplementaries a day. Today we had less than that; we had 11 questions and six supplementaries—
—We had 17.

—Seventeen, yes indeed. The reason, of course, was self-evidently the case that there was a series of spurious points of order and other interruptions taken by the other side of this parliament. There is ample opportunity in the processes and procedures of this place for asking questions of the environment minister or anybody else. There are still days left this week for that process to occur. There is the opportunity for debate after question time in terms of taking points based on the statements that have been made during question time. That procedure or privilege is available to the opposition.

PARA.TAB: There is no more substance in this than that it is a pathetic stunt, as I have said. The government will resist the motion simply because we want to get on with the proper business of this place and to get some legislation passed. We want to do so early in the session, so that we are not subject to the kind of nonsense we get from the other side later in the session when, as always occurs, we waste so much time in the early weeks, the early days, that we simply do not get the business done in time. We want to proceed at a measured pace. You will have ample opportunity to get out of your system whatever it is you want to get out of your system on that particular subject. We reject the motion accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr President—

PARA.TAB: Senator Abetz interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not scared of your tests, Senator Abetz. Senator Hill is very fond of putting up the challenge, `Here's a test for the Democrats'. I am not afraid to stand here and talk to you, as I have privately, about the way the opposition approaches question time. Take today's question time. Not only is it a matter of whether points of order are vexatious; it is a matter of how long they take. Senator Alston's point of order was summed up in the very last sentence; it was a relevant point of order but it took one sentence, not four minutes, to make it appropriate.

PARA.TAB: I would point out to the opposition that straight after question time we have scheduled a matter of urgency on this very matter. Apart from that, I would point out—through you, Mr President—to the opposition that the information that is being sought by the opposition is actually due to be tabled in a return to order which has been put forward by Senator Ian Macdonald. That information will be forthcoming this afternoon or tomorrow, as I understand it, on Senator Ian Macdonald's agreement of the time. So we do not need an extension to get this specific information: there is a matter of urgency and there are other formal avenues available to you straight after question time—and you know it. Senator Hill, you talk about Mabo—
Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to finish the point.
—Order! Senator Kernot has a right to be heard in silence.

—You talk about Mabo because you are still sulking about it, but I want to say to you that you would not be playing to people in the gallery because it is the first time that you have got someone there!

—Yes, Senator Kernot, we are worried about jobs. There are people in the gallery who are worried about jobs. They are entitled to hear answers, as we are entitled to ask questions, about those jobs and about Senator Faulkner's impact on people's employment. It is going to come as a shock to you, Senator Kernot, that we are entitled to ask those questions. That is why we were seeking your support: so that three or four more questions could be put to Senator Faulkner about this exceedingly important issue.

PARA.TAB: Many people have come to Canberra today. There are hundreds of trucks outside which belong to people whose jobs are under threat and who want answers to questions. Senator Kernot, why aren't you prepared to stand up and support our attempt to make the government more accountable? Senator Kernot, in your remarks today, you have revealed the true colours of the Democrats. You have revealed why your support continues to be low. This is a classic case of our trying to make the government more accountable.

Mr President, what we had today was not a problem of points of order; we had great points of relevance. The minister has ducked fair and straightforward questions on important issues. The strategy of the government was to take up time, so we had long, tedious answers from Senator Cook, Senator McMullan and Senator Schacht when there were important issues on the public agenda. I put it to you that the motion brought forward by Senator Hill should be supported.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would not be obvious to everyone how question time works, so let me at least put it on the record, especially for those in the gallery who are interested. Generally, the President is given a list from both sides of the priority order of questions. The proposition that Senator Hill is putting forward today is that opposition senators think the latter two questions were the most critical, and they want to continue with them. If this was the most critical issue, why didn't they ask about it in the first two questions?

PARA.TAB: The fact is that it is opposition senators who determine the priority of their questions. When it came to the two questions on the issue that they now want to pursue, they asked stupid and irrelevant questions—not relevant or robust questions, but shallow and irrelevant questions.

What Senator Hill has done today to prop up his doubtful leadership of Australia's answer to the barmy army opposite is to say, `We will have another three or four questions.' People may not realise that for the next half hour under the standing orders we can have the noting of questions, which means that those two questions on the logging issue and the environment can be debated then. Not only that, but we can then have an urgency motion on the same subject. Potentially, we can quite properly spend between 2 o'clock and 5 o'clock on these issues. All that Senator Hill has done is put in another half hour of misguided slanging matches that get this country absolutely nowhere. Senator Hill, you had your chance today to show some leadership, and one of your frontbench disgraced himself. He disgraced and ashamed your new leader and you failed to do anything about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Point of order, Senator Abetz.
—If he is finished, I will not take up the point of order.
—I am not finished.

—Mr President, the point of order clearly is this: it is absolutely irrelevant to the motion that is before the Senate at the moment as to who or what was interjected from the opposition front bench. It is the minister who is being irrelevant by bringing in extraneous matters to the debate, and he ought to be ruled out of order.
—There is no point of order. I call Senator Robert Ray.

—Senator Abetz has failed to understand what I am saying so I will go back and do the linkages for him. I said that this is a stunt. I claim this is a stunt. I claim that the motive for this stunt is that Senator Hill is trying to prop up his leadership. In deducing evidence of that, I pointed out today that this weak leader of the Liberal Party in the Senate does not have the courage to rebuke the bullyboy behind him when he misbehaves. He does not have the courage to show any leadership whatsoever.

PARA.TAB: There are serious issues that this chamber can address in relation to the decision on logging. There is no question about that. There is no desire by this government to run away from those issues, but they should be addressed seriously in debate and not by way of cheap stunts. We have the opportunity in the next half hour to debate those issues when taking note of answers. We then have the opportunity to debate them in the urgency motion. That is properly the way it should proceed. The reason we have one hour for questions from 2 o'clock to 3 o'clock is so that senators and others can organise their days in terms of a work pattern.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is to get some answers that we haven't got.
—Senator, it is great pity that you were not in this chamber from 1980 to 1983 when I first came here.

PARA.TAB: Senator Kemp interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Go back and read the non-answers. Go back and read the non-answers of Sir John Carrick and Margaret Guilfoyle.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. He raised the issue of what happened in the 1970s. There were on average 28 questions a day answered.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—That is a spurious point of order. You say `answered'. You mean the person opened their lips and issued some words. Go back and read the content. In those days, if you represented another minister, you did not give a substantial reply; you put it on notice. No wonder you got 28 questions a day when three or four were put on notice. That is a false batting average syndrome and you know it. It is the same specious argument. When you were the Director of the Institute of Public Affairs, all you ever did was professionally attack working people in this country. That is your track record.
—On a point of order, that is offensive to Senator Kemp and should be withdrawn.
—I was concentrating on what was being said to my left. I do not know what was said.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am certainly supporting this motion. I want to pick up Senator Ray's point that we are hurting the workers. If any government is hurting the workers, it is this government. The evidence of that is all around Parliament House today—truck after truck.

PARA.TAB: I had one woman come to me today and say, `Today is the day my child starts school and I will not be with my child today because I am here supporting my husband.' You have the audacity to talk about hurting the workers. Every one of you ought to hang your heads in shame. These fellows put in $180 a year to keep you in parliament. You go out there and kick them in the tail and then you stand there and say that you represent the working class of Australia. Each one of you ought to hang your head, and particularly Senator Murphy whose wife is a workers union representative. No wonder you are embarrassed.

We want to ask some questions. There are seven questions that we want to ask. Senator Ray and Senator Evans burnt up the clock with spurious points of order so that we could not get our questions up. There are a number of questions that must be asked. Why was $120,000 given to the green movement to assess the right of workers to work? Why was that money spent? Surely there must be a fairer way to assess the environmental impact of logging than to have those people who have their own ideas make that assessment.

That is terribly unfair. It is unfair in the eyes of every Australian. Those people have their own agendas. Those agendas are well known. Why would $120,000 be given to those people to make the assessments? What scientific assessments have been made on the 509 coupes? We cannot get an answer to that. Two years and two months ago the national forest agreement was signed. Every premier in Australia has written a letter to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) saying, `Yes, we're prepared to get behind this national forest agreement, but give us the criteria.'

TALK.START.PARA: —Two years we have waited.

—Two years and two months. I have letters here from Mr Fahey and the Premier of Victoria pleading for the criteria to be given so they can go ahead. We have to ask the questions. If we do not get the opportunity to ask those questions, then we will never get the answers. All the Labor Party has done today is burn up the clock, burn up the time, so that we cannot ask those questions.

PARA.TAB: I very strongly support the motion that is before the Senate today to allow at least another four questions to get up. That is the only way we will be able to get fair answers to those questions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I oppose this motion, and I will tell you why. As has been demonstrated by the people in the gallery and on both sides of the house, this is a very emotional issue, and so it should be. But the difficulty is that it has become so emotional that the questions are emotionally asked and the answers are emotionally given. I do not mind the questions being emotional, but unfortunately they breach all the tests set out in chapter 11. They are argumentative; they contain imputations; they contain inferences; they contain ironical expressions.

PARA.TAB: If these questions are allowed to be asked, this situation is going to continue. I am not against questions being asked of Senator Faulkner. Senator Faulkner is a senior minister and he has to answer questions. As I understand it, he has not denied that fact. He is willing to answer questions. But the conduct of this chamber—I am not suggesting either side—at question time and before has not been as edifying as it sometimes is. If we continue to ask these questions while we are all emotionally charged, this situation is going to continue. This was Senator Ray's point, as I understand it. I am not saying that there should not be emotion in debates in this chamber. I am not saying that people in the gallery should not become emotional if they so desire, but can't they do that just as well in the procedures that are already open to us? First of all, there is the half hour that Senator Ray talked about and then there is the matter of public importance.

TALK.START.PARA: —With no answers in either of them.

—Senator Vanstone, can I say to you in all sincerity that I have nothing but respect for you, but given the way emotions are going in this chamber at the moment, question time, which you want to extend, cannot be conducted in the way that it should. There is tomorrow and all next week, when emotions will have died down a bit, to ask these questions. But, if we go on in the way that we have been, this chamber is not going to be seen publicly as a very edifying chamber. If we allow question time to go on in the way it has, this is going to be very bad for the reputation of parliament.
—How about answering some questions?

—Of course they should answer questions. All I am saying is that, considering the way the questions are being asked and the way they are being answered, you will not get what you are looking for. Senator Macdonald, if you are sincere about wanting the answers, you will not get them this way.
—I call Senator Harradine.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Why is it that you went to Senator Harradine on the same side of the chamber when Senator Newman was given the call by you and then, I presume accidentally, you went to Senator Boswell? I do not quarrel with that. However, I ask that you ensure Senator Newman gets recognition before the expiry of time.
—I called Senator Harradine because he jumped up first.

—Mr President, on the point of order: you studiously refused to look down this side. I watched you very carefully. How can you possibly tell who is jumping up if you only deliberately look in front of you or to the right? We on this side have grave concerns about your management of this chamber. That was a classic example of the blindness of our President. I ask you to get your glasses checked at the very least. You did call me earlier. I ask you to give me the call now ahead of Senator Harradine. I was called.
—I understand that Senator Harradine is going to concede to you, Senator Newman. Is that right?
—I think it might have been a case of age before beauty.

—I will take the age tag, Senator Harradine, and give you the beauty tag for your character. I am concerned about the statements being made so fiercely by Senator Cooney, who I have always regarded as a more gentle gentleman. A measure of the desperation of this government is that once again it has called Senator Cooney in for the death watch in defending the indefensible.

PARA.TAB: Senator Cooney is a Victorian who has been in the Senate a long time and who does not get out so much. Perhaps he does not realise what this issue means to the industry in Australia. Certainly as a Tasmanian senator I cannot be anything but passionate about it. I am astonished that he would suggest our behaviour is not edifying, because we have been fighting for our constituents.

Senator Cooney, your government has frightened these people and left them worried sick about their futures. You say when we want answers from the minister responsible, the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner), that we have had enough time. Yet you know full well on that side how little information we have been given, how evasive the answers have been and how desperate the minister's attempts to try to shout down the opposition and turn question time into a farce have been.

Questions have to be asked by people on this side of the chamber because nobody on that side of the chamber is prepared to ask the questions that they know need to be asked. Senator Devereux has already ratted on the Labor people who put him into the parliament. Senator Coates and Senator Sherry have absented themselves from the chamber during this time of great importance for their Tasmanian constituents. I give Senator Denman and Senator Murphy the acknowledgment that they are at least in the chamber. But, with his background as a union representative in the Australian Timber Workers Union, which carries a long tradition, does Senator Murphy realise that his name is now `Weasel' with the timber workers? He is regarded as having dumped them and tried to produce inefficient and unacceptable compromises that will do nothing for the industry which he knows.

Why is Senator Murphy not on his feet? Why are Senator Denman and the other senators not on their feet asking questions of their minister? This is their opportunity to prove that they really care about their state. Are some of them looking at jumping ship from the Labor Party altogether? They need to ask these questions. But, as they will not, we must. We are entitled to answers in this place. After all, the forum of the parliament centres on the accountability of the government to the parliament. We cannot accept the evasiveness of Senator Faulkner, who has excelled himself in evasiveness with the assistance of his senior ministers, who have done their utmost to turn question time today into a shambles.

People are still in this gallery—there were more of them earlier—listening to and watching everything you do. They will go outside this chamber and tell the rest of Australia, even if the press gallery has gone, what is happening with this tired and arrogant government that thinks it can play God with people's lives. This is the government that has put a million or more people out of work and that is now trying to put more out of work. These are people who are able to help our economy out of the mess that you put it in, yet you are stifling their initiatives, investments and futures.

How can you sit there and not be ashamed of your behaviour? You are Labor men. Why aren't you looking after people who believe that you are their natural leaders? What about the workers and the families? You have answers to give not just to us but to all of Australia. You should be ashamed of yourselves.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just in passing, I think Senator Boswell and Senator Newman have been a bit rough on Senator Murphy. This chamber is the chamber which is charged with the duty of bringing the executive to account. There are various methods of bringing the executive to account. One of the problems with this issue is that it is beyond our legislative power. These decisions are made by the executive government. There is no power for us to disallow them. There is nothing under standing orders to disallow them. Therefore, it is necessary to ensure that there is accountability, particularly where false information is provided.

PARA.TAB: Where policies affect thousands of people and the environment and those policies have been founded on false information then it is important to ask the minister concerned direct questions. You can have all of your matters of public importance, you can have all of your taking note of answers to questions, but they are no substitute for asking direct questions of the minister in this chamber. Under those circumstances I will be supporting the proposition by the Leader of the Opposition on this occasion.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Hill's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner), to a question without notice asked by Senator Alston this day, relating to forest management.

SPEECH.PARA: Yesterday afternoon, following intense questioning from my colleagues of the Liberal-National coalition, it became very evident from the lips of the environmental minister that the report that he issued to his colleague Minister Beddall is very one-sided. In fact, it lacks balance. The consequence of that report is devastating so far as the timber industry is concerned because it has placed at risk the livelihood and jobs of thousands of people around Australia.

PARA.TAB: The point of taking note of this answer is to point out that, on the one hand, the industry, the foresters and the states have to make a carefully prepared scientific evaluation and yet, on the other hand, the environment minister accepts quite a flippant, quick and inadequate response conducted by people who do not necessarily have the adequate qualifications. What was the sort of answer to Senator Alston's question? The Senate got a non-answer. Because of the minister's refusal to answer, senators were put in a situation of having to demand extra time because we want answers. In the circumstances, it is a democratic right for the Senate to receive a response.

While the minister might not have had an answer in relation to a particular coupe—or who Natalie was—I would have thought that he could have produced from his desk or from his files a representative case. He could have said, `I mightn't have this one, but I've got 20 or 30 others as a representative sample.' The minister's failure to produce to the Senate the sorts of assessments that were made by this ad hoc group of people with government sponsorship, with government aid, with government assistance, leaves a lot to be desired. Where is the accountability? On the one hand, as I say, state governments, forestry companies and others have to put a lot of money aside to prepare a scientific basis for these types of evaluations. But, on the other hand, we see jobs sacrificed on the altar of political expediency to try to get a few votes from the environmental movement.

I believe state governments have evaluated forest resources responsibly and set in place agreements that not only ensure the protection of the heritage value of forests but also provide a basis of certainty—certainty on which the forest industry can proceed. Unfortunately, that evaluation process has been placed in jeopardy. Where is the credibility of this whole process when a few people with prejudiced ideas can come in and so influence a minister that he prepares such a one-sided report to throw all these good people in the gallery, their friends and their relations right across Australia onto the scrap heap of despair?

The other night a Commonwealth driver asked one of those people how long they were staying. He said, `There's no point in going home. We've got no jobs to go back to.' They have no jobs to go back to because of the decisions, the ad hoc decisions, of this government, which is playing into the hands of a few extreme people—I emphasise `extreme people'—on the far left of the environmental movement.

What has happened? The very security of the management is wrecked by this federal government's unwillingness to put in place long-term export licence agreements because we have this stupid concept of annual renewals. Apart from that, we have chaos because of the ineptitude not only of Minister Faulkner in accepting and providing a shonky report to Minister Beddall, but also, of course, in Beddall's lacking sense in not following the procedures laid down by cabinet and the law. Far worse, there is a wider dimension to this chaos as a result of this whole debacle. The whole of our export industry, not only woodchipping, according to the Attorney-General, can be thrown into chaos. I am talking about alumina; I am talking about coal; I am talking about aluminium.

You people up there are representing just one segment of a wider section of the Australian industry and exporters who provide income and a remedy to our balance of payments problems. You people are providing export income. What is further surprising is that the industries that are most subject to attack are the very industries that the green movement and Minister Faulkner and his cohorts believe should be protected—the saw log industry, the veneer industry and other downstream industries. The government has got it completely wrong, and has thrown the credibility of whole evaluation process into complete chaos. (Time expired)

TAB.EMPHASIS: An incident having occurred in the gallery—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Can I say, with respect, to those in the gallery that insistent clapping when your cause is being raised by one of the speakers does your cause no help. It disrupts the parliament. It is not encouraged by either the coalition or the government, and tomorrow it will be somebody else and it is utterly disorderly. If you want this debate to be conducted properly, it is best you listen and best you do not clap. I remind senators that their comments should be directed through the chair and not to the gallery.

—The one thing that the people of Australia need to understand is that the people sitting in the gallery are the true conservationists of this country. They are the people that care about the forests because their livelihoods depend on them, and for them to destroy their forests would be to destroy their livelihoods. They are the people who are genuinely concerned, not the Australian Democrats and the Greens. The Democrats came into this parliament on the motto of keeping the bastards honest, but they are too scared to allow the opposition to ask questions of the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, Senator Faulkner. What about keeping them honest? They are scared because, if we ask the questions we have been asking for the last two days, it will be exposed that the organisations that support the Australian Democrats and the Greens are the ones that have been funded by Senator Faulkner and his Labor Party to give them reports and to give them the outcomes that will destroy the jobs of these people and the people in regional Australia.

PARA.TAB: Let us never forget that this minister said publicly that there had been a `rigorous'—his word—examination of 1,300 coupes, and he recommended 1,300 coupes. Let us look at the facts. The amount spent on that study was $120,000. That money was given to the green movement, it was their study, and it was done within seven weeks. If you analyse the statistics that means they analysed each coupe for one hour, and that is on the basis they worked 24 hours per day, seven days a week. They spent $100 examining each coupe of the 1,300 that were recommended. Of course, that raises the question: what about all the other coupes they allegedly looked at and considered which were not recommended?

The fact is—and I would lay my bottom dollar on this—that these people who made these sorts of recommendations to the government did not even go out to have a look at the coupes. They sat in their plush offices—undoubtedly taxpayer funded—to write these reports to try to assist the green cause. But how rigorous was the examination when the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) struck out 791 of those 1,300 coupes and said, `We will now make it 509 coupes'? How serious are they? How genuine are they? They are not genuine at all because the study that was funded by the Labor Party into the green movement to give the desired result was not rigorous. If it was rigorous, all 1,300 coupes must have stood up to the prime ministerial test. The simple fact is that the minister for the environment has been rebuffed, even by his Prime Minister, and had the recommended numbers more than halved.

It is a chronic shame that there is not a single member of the Australian Labor Party in this chamber or around this parliament who is prepared to wear the forest workers' badge—the one that I am wearing very proudly today. Why is it that a former official of the Timber Workers Union in my home state of Tasmania does not wear a badge which simply says `Forest workers care for forests'? He is not even prepared to identify in that small way with the cause that he used to earn his income from. He is now in Canberra. He is now in the Labor caucus; he can forget about the workers. That is what happens to the Australian Labor Party representatives when they come up here.

We and the Australian people need to realise one very simple thing in this debate: the Greens and the Democrats, who have now hijacked the Australian Labor Party, will continually say that the environment and nature need protection. So when a little beaver cuts down saplings and dams rivers, that is part of nature, that is okay; but when humans cut down trees and dam rivers, that is not part of nature, even when we replace the trees. The simple fact they have to realise is that we human beings are part of nature and part of this planet. The Labor Party, the Democrats and the Greens would do very well to get themselves back onto this planet, back into the real world and look out for the people that I am so very proud to represent.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too want to take note of the two answers by the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner), particularly the one to Senator Alston. It is a pity that we did not have more time to ask questions in question time today because I particularly wanted to ask the minister why the government has made such a bungle of this so-called hit list in Tasmania. We all know that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) did this just to appease the Greens.

PARA.TAB: In Tasmania's case, I would have asked why it is that, of those 72-odd compartments that form part of the 509 nationwide compartments that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has compromised on to try to end this row, two of the so-called coupes under the protection hit list have been clear-felled and another 50 on the same list have either been logged previously or are being logged now. It seemed quite strange to me that two-thirds of those compartments or coupes listed in Tasmania could not even make the National Estate list. What criteria is this minister using to lock up these areas and to put the jobs in the forest industry in Tasmania in jeopardy, because these coupes do not even meet the criteria of the National Estate?

My Senate colleagues from Tasmania—Senator Watson, Senator Abetz, Senator Newman and Senator Gibson, who was involved very closely in the timber industry as a former manager of ANM—have seen this happen in our state. All we have seen in our state are these so-called compromises. Every time there is a compromise, more forests are lost and more forestry workers lose their jobs.

We do not hear one word from Senator Shayne Murphy. The only time you get up is when there is a dispute at the mill. That is the only reason you are here—that is what put you into parliament. Why don't you get up and tell the forestry workers of Australia what you have done to help them and what you have said in the party room? Where are the other senators and members from Tasmania? Half of them did not even show up for question time today. Where are Dick Adams and Silvia Smith? They marched with us the other day in Launceston, but what are they going to do? Are they going to resign? Are they going to cross the floor?

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you ask them?

—We haven't heard anything from them. Enough is enough. The workers of Australia are fed up with this continual gradualism, with the taking away of their jobs. Senator Abetz made a very good point: in the short time available, how were these assessments made? We were told how some of them were made: people drove around in cars. They would not even get out of the car and walk through the trees to find that on the other side of the trees there were button grass plains and that type of thing in Tasmania. Some of the areas that were recommended in the original list were nothing but button grass plains. There was not even a tree on them. A lot of them had been logged three of four times.

PARA.TAB: I was pleased to hear Senator Harradine speak today and stand up for Tasmania, as he always has done. Today showed that the opposition and Senator Harradine stand up for Tasmanian workers. We are not going to stop here. We are going to support the forest workers in Tasmania. I can tell the minister for the environment that he certainly has not heard the last of this one.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unlike former speakers, I am a senator from Western Australia. Western Australia has a great forest industry, one which brings in millions of export dollars to that state and to this country. The experience I draw on in relation to this matter is gained from conversations I have had over the last couple of days with the people surrounding this building.

PARA.TAB: The other night I was walking home and I walked past a group of loggers and drivers. They said, `Mate, what sort of rig are you on?' and I joked, `I'm on Comcar.' That is a very easy joke for me to make, but it is a very serious matter. Here in Canberra we are not seeing what is happening at the coalface. This demonstration has brought the coalface to Canberra. I say to those people here today that their efforts are not going unnoticed and we are not treating their efforts lightly.

I made an estimation the other day that there must have been around 250 rigs out there and I reckon they are worth about $200,000 each. That is a conservative value. I was overawed by the amount of finance it would take to keep those rigs going and by the amount of money that would need to be earned to keep the income earning unit, that rig, going. That unit supports families—men, women and children. I say to the government that the livelihood of families is an essential fact to remember in this equation. We have here people who have come a long way to tell the government that they will be in desperate straits if these measures are continued with. They are not here for fun and games; they are not here for jokes. They are very serious and they are exercising a democratic right to be here and to get their point across. I say to the government that it will be at its own peril if it ignores the voice of average working Australians such as those who surround the building today.

We have seen in other parts of the world where people have finally had enough and they rise up together and make their views felt. It really does take, I believe, quite a lot to get the Australian public going. What impresses me with this demonstration is the fact that it must have been really something to have caused these people to down tools, stop work and drive thousands of kilometres to bring their problems to the capital.

I think we in this place often forget the struggles that are going on out there in the wider community with working men and women and the trouble they are having to meet their mortgage payments with rising interest rates, and to finance such things as fishing boats, trucks or whatever. The government has to take note that there is a wide section of the Australian community which has been placed in a desperate situation as a result of this. That is the feeling I have gained from speaking to people as I have walked to and from Parliament House over the last couple of days. I think it has been a worthwhile exercise. I say to those people that I think they are getting their message across.

We in the opposition can do only so much. We do not have the numbers and we can only keep on debating this point. I urge the government to not turn a deaf ear. I say to those in the government who were formerly involved in the trade union movement to listen to the calls of their fellow brothers in the union movement and not turn a deaf ear on them, as it seems is being done, but listen to their concerns. I say to the wider Australian community: this might only relate to the forest industry—

TALK.START.PARA: —Today.

—That is today, but do not forget that the day might come when the government arbitrarily interferes with an area which cuts off your income and you, too, might have to come to Canberra. You, too, might have to stage such a demonstration.

—I do not particularly want to take up too much of the Senate's time with this issue. One thing I do know for sure is that the people who are in the gallery and the people who are outside want a solution to a problem that exists. There is an issue at hand and it is in dispute. But what they do not want and what is worthless is to come in here and listen to the rhetoric, the rubbish and the political opportunism that exists on that side of the chamber, because that is of no value. Those opposite have nothing constructive to add to this debate.

PARA.TAB: Let me tell those opposite about workers and how opposition members stand up for workers, because I know for a fact that none of you on that side know that. You would have wanted to pay them $3 an hour wages when it came round to industrial relations issues. That is what you would have wanted to have done. When one talks about representing workers, it means that one represents them in all issues. When you are in a union you stand up beside one another and you represent workers in all of the issues. You do not come in here and try and make political mileage out of a single issue. That is the pathetic operation of the opposition.

Again, opposition members talk about asking questions, but let us look at the order in which they sought to ask the questions about this particular industry. I acknowledge there is a problem. There are some people up there and outside who know that there are people who are working through this very difficult issue. This government has a responsibility not only to the industry but also to the environment. We will work through those processes.

As I said, a group of people in this industry are seeking a solution. All I can say is that there will be a solution. They did not come to hear, and I am sure they do not want to hear, the stupid rhetoric that is coming from the other side.

TALK.START.PARA: —In contributing to this debate, I must agree with Senator Murphy that the worst thing that can result here is a theatre of unbounded rhetoric. That is why I must respond to the direct accusations by Senator Abetz that the Democrats have denied themselves the opportunity to question the government on this matter. In fact, I led the charge. I questioned the government months before you even thought of—
—Months?

—Last June—months before you even thought of there being a fault in this process. We started the critical appraisal of the Minister for Resources (Mr Beddall), and we want to continue it. My personal questions of Senators Faulkner and Collins representing the minister on this have revealed several breaches of the process. I want to reveal more. I want to correct that process.
—Why didn't you ask a question today?

—I asked that question yesterday. Senator Abetz and company have only recently and theatrically joined the queue behind us. My questioning outnumbers Senator Abetz's on this matter by at least 10 to one. When the cameras whirl and the gallery fills, out you come. But when it counts, when the matter should have been addressed, where were you? You did not even understand the issue. But at the beginning of question time, what were the first questions that came out of this mob? They wasted time so that after a sufficient time had expired, after they had rammed this ploy, we had this theatrical stunt. That is all it was—a stunt that cannot stand any scrutiny whatsoever.

PARA.TAB: The scrutiny with which I am happy to oblige you is that we will support and have already foreshadowed support for Senator Ian Macdonald's proposal to obtain the very information that Senator Alston wanted. That is the level of your cooperation internally. You did not even know what the left hand was doing. One person wanted one thing and that same thing was on the Notice Paper. We have foreshadowed support of that and we will do so. You should be supporting the Democrat's inquiry which was proposed yesterday and which asked for exactly what you are asking for. It will be delivered and in greater quantity and with greater accuracy. What are you doing, you hypocrite?

TALK.START.PARA: —Is this theatrical?
—No, it is not theatrical; it is from the heart, boyo!

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)—Order! I have heard that remark. I think it was addressed to an individual. If that is the case, I do not think it is appropriate and ask you to withdraw, Senator Bell.

TALK.START.PARA: —I withdraw whatever was offensive to whomever. I am offended by the hypocrisy that goes on in this place when we have the opportunity to inquire fully, to seek the answers to the mistakes, the incompetencies, of the minister, to reveal them for all to see—and what do we see? We see this limp little ploy to extend question time. You already know that question time will not reveal what you ask.

PARA.TAB: What is really required is a full inquiry into the process—not an inquiry into the timber industry, not into the woodchipping industry, not into the National Estate and not the dozens of other inquiries that have already been contested ad nauseam, but an inquiry that should reveal the inadequacy and the incompetency of the minister who has delivered this chaos. But, no, those opposite do not want to do that. They just want to play their games here. I will not be part of that. I will persist in pursuing the minister in the most effective way.

We think it is of utmost importance to challenge the faulty process and to reveal its inadequacies. We do not want to see a repeat of the mistakes that have already been made here. I want to reveal them and I want to correct them. I do not think the stunt that has been proposed by the coalition today would achieve anything. We have already seen a non-answer from the minister. Why do you want to repeat that?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to the motion moved by Senator Watson that the answer given in question time be noted. The only reason I rise to speak arises from the astounding performance of some members of the opposition during this debate in the Senate and in question time when they proclaimed that they are defenders of workers' rights.

PARA.TAB: I find it particularly offensive when three years ago Senator Abetz, the then president of the Liberal Party in Tasmania, lined up with the bosses, aided and abetted by the ideologues in the Liberal Party, to crush the union movement and the workers at the Burnie paper mill in the most awful dispute, cheering all the way. It is rank hypocrisy for Senator Abetz now to come in here and claim he defends the workers and wears the badge, when three years ago he was in there, as a member of the HR Nicholls Society and supported by all the ideologues on the far right, trying to crush the union and crush the workers' rights at Burnie.

It is also hypocritical for Senator Kemp to shout out in question time `defending workers' and to stand up in here playing to the gallery of the workers saying, `We are looking after you' when he is a long-term member of the HR Nicholls Society and a member of the IPA—all those right wing groups that have opposed workers' rights in every way in this country. Every chance they get, those opposite want to reduce wages and conditions that have been fought for by those workers over 100 years. They will take every right off the workers.

It is an astonishing hypocrisy for those opposite, particularly for those from the right wing of the Liberal Party, those identified with the HR Nicholls Society. There are some moderate Liberals—very few now left—who do not have that view. Most of them have been chased out of the Liberal Party and chased out of this chamber. Peter Baume got kicked out. He was forced out because he could not stomach the right wing views that are now represented by people like Senator Abetz. So we now have this charade in this place from the members of the opposition saying that they defend the workers.

I say to the unions and the independent workers out there in the blockade and the demonstration, which they have every right to participate in, that of course this is a democracy. I remind them that on every occasion when the crunch has come, those from the Liberal Party who are now shouting that they are there to defend workers have opposed their getting any conditions, any improvement in living standards.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's absolute rubbish.

—Every time the ACTU, on behalf of those workers, has gone for a wage increase in the Industrial Commission, John Howard, in particular, has always opposed it. It is astonishing hypocrisy for those opposite now to claim that they represent those workers.

PARA.TAB: I hope that we can resolve this difficult issue—and no-one can deny that it is a difficult issue with very hot views and passions on both sides of the argument—but we will not resolve it by means of the hypocrisy coming from those opposite. I hope that people out in the community, particularly the workers, who have every right to complain, to express their view and to demonstrate—and no-one on this side has objected to that at all; we have all made arrangements, as we have tried to resolve this issue, to listen to their view—will not be misled by the grandstanding, particularly of Tasmanian senators like Senator Abetz, who is a member of the New Right that particularly hates workers and trade unions.
Therefore, it is not with great pleasure that I have had to raise these issues. I believe that what is going on here, with the grandstanding of senators opposite, cannot be left without comment.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's offensive.

—Earlier Senator Newman spoke in here and addressed her remarks to the crowd. Three years ago, when the Burnie dispute was on, I did not see Senator Newman in here defending the rights of the workers when they were about to be crossed by right wing ideologues in her own party; I never heard a word from her, not a word. I did not hear a word from Senator Kemp. I did not hear a word from Senator Macdonald.

PARA.TAB: Senator Newman interjecting—
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)—Order! Senator Newman!

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I did—(Time expired)
