DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts References Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to give a notice of motion in relation to an alteration in the terms of reference of the Senate committee inquiring into soccer.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the resolution of the Senate of 8 December 1994 referring a matter to the Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts References Committee be modified to read as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts References Committee inquire into the role of coaches, players, agents, clubs, officials, and others in the transfer of Australian sportspeople, and into any other matters relating to corruption, conflicts of interest, tax evasion, and improper financial transactions, with particular reference to the sport of soccer, and review the report by the Hon. D G Stewart to the Australian Soccer Federation.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)—Order! I inform the Senate that the President has received the following letter, dated 1 February 1995, from Senator Ian Macdonald:

PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr President,

PARA.TAB: Pursuant to Standing Order 75, I give notice that today I propose to move:
That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The need to condemn the Government for demeaning the high conservation evaluation process for forest areas and for walking away from the obligations and responsibilities of the National Forest Policy Statement as agreed between the Commonwealth and the mainland States.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Yours Sincerely
Ian MacDonald
Is the proposal supported?

PARA.TAB: More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The need to condemn the Government for demeaning the high conservation evaluation process for forest areas and for walking away from the obligations and responsibilities of the National Forest Policy Statement as agreed between the Commonwealth and the mainland States.

SPEECH.PARA: Question time today and the contribution by the minister Senator Schacht just now give clear evidence, if clear evidence is needed, of just what a bunch of incompetent fools run this country at the present time—a bunch of incompetent fools. The way this forest policy issue has been handled just demonstrates that yet again.Over 800,000 workers cannot get a job because of the incompetence and bungling of the people who occupy the front benches here. We have a foreign debt that is approaching $200 billion; a current account deficit that is running wild; and now a forest policy, or lack of a policy, lack of implementation of a policy, that will cause untold damage to small business and workers and unionists around Australia.

PARA.TAB: All we get from the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, Senator Faulkner, is more and more equivocation. Senator Faulkner, fresh from his humiliation over Oyster Point—where, by his own panel of experts, he was proved to be completely wrong; where, by his action, he cost the jobs of 200 or 300 other workers around Australia—appears here today with this ridiculous stupidity of the handling of the forest policy.

A news article earlier this week had a headline titling the Labor Party's handling of this issue as `pulp fiction'. But I think it would be more apt to title Senator Faulkner, the minister responsible, as a `Forrest Gump'. The only difference between Senator Faulkner and Forrest Gump is that Forrest Gump is willing to admit he is an idiot. The way this government has handled this issue is just nothing short of a disgrace. Senator Faulkner relies upon advice from consultants—advice which will indirectly affect the jobs of 75,000 Australians and which will directly affect Australia's annually received income of $420 million. He relies on the advice of Natalie and others.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is Natalie?

—When we ask who Natalie is, what her qualifications are, where she comes from and what she knows about the forest industry, we get absolute silence from the minister. The minister has accepted her advice but cannot tell us why he has done so. He cannot tell us the sorts of criteria that Natalie and others were dealing with.

PARA.TAB: I want to help Senator Faulkner in trying to resolve this absolute shambles, so I will ask him another couple of questions. I refer him to forest coupe 83 on the banks of the Picton River, south of Hobart. I ask him: what was the high conservation value of that particular coupe—a coupe that was clear felled three months ago, a coupe that has a road running right through the middle of it and does not have one tree on it?

TALK.START.PARA: —Did they inspect it?

—And did they inspect it? Senator Faulkner is taking part in this debate, so I ask him to answer that question during his response. I also ask Senator Faulkner to give us his definition of `high conservation value'. Here is his opportunity. He is going to take 15 minutes in this debate, and during that time I invite him to tell us what his definition is.

PARA.TAB: I do not want Senator Faulkner to go on with the rubbish that he went on with in question time yesterday because the Resource Assessment Commission has said, in an exhaustive study, that no evidence exists that any plant or animal species has been threatened with extinction because of forest industries. Many of the forests in the coupes that Senator Faulkner has mentioned have been logged for over 100 years, yet they still show high conservation values, according to Senator Faulkner—and that clearly demonstrates the resilience of our forests.
As Senator Gibson pointed out earlier, what sort of a fool running this government would claim in a letter:

SPEECH.PARA: In addition the Hensleigh Creek catchment has a number of values which add to its conservation significance, including the presence of a nationally rare plant, Eucalyptus denticulata and the presence of rainforest.

That is what Senator Faulkner said in his letter—`including the presence of a nationally rare plant.' As Senator Gibson pointed out in his question, this nationally rare plant to which Senator Faulkner—or Forrest Gump—referred was formerly known by another name. In fact, it is colloquially known as `shining gum'. It is a major timber species in the area. There are thousands of hectares of forest containing this species in a park adjoining this coupe and in other areas in East Gippsland. The species is also present in the central highlands and in many areas of state forests in Victoria, which are harvested and regenerated with seed of the same species from the same locality.

PARA.TAB: There are literally hundreds and thousands of acres of this plant which Senator Faulkner refers to as `a nationally rare plant'. Perhaps Senator Faulkner, who is going to follow me in this debate, could explain why the shining gum—which covers thousands of hectares—is a nationally rare plant. I want to again ask Senator Faulkner to help me by identifying why he has taken advice from the Conservation Council in Western Australia, when he has completely ignored the Conservation and Land Management Department and the Australian Heritage Commission, which have done a lot of work in this area.

There are other issues which I am not going to have time to raise completely, but which I want to put to Senator Faulkner. Can he tell the Senate why a logging compartment in the McPherson State Forest in central New South Wales was chosen when it has a plantation of young gum trees dotted all over a sandy scar of a neglected airstrip that closed a decade ago? What is the high conservation value about that one? Can he also refer to the Wild Cattle Creek State Forest in New South Wales, which he said has high conservation values? I ask Senator Faulkner to confirm that this is partly cleared ex-dairy farms which now have regrowth. Even Senator Faulkner's own department indicated that it had not been assessed as having old-growth or endangered species values.

Senator Faulkner—along with his colleagues in the Labor Party cabinet—has completely mishandled this. I think Peter Walsh was perhaps correct when he referred to this whole fiasco in this way—(Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —The whole basis of Senator Ian Macdonald's urgency motion is nonsense. The Commonwealth is absolutely committed to the implementation of the national forest policy statement. At a COAG meeting in Perth in December 1992, the first ministers of every mainland state and territory committed themselves to the NFPS, too.

PARA.TAB: It is important to understand that the NFPS is a state and Commonwealth agreement. That means that it requires not just a commitment from the Commonwealth but state cooperation in order to be effectively implemented. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) recognised this in his statement of 22 December last year when he announced that he put in place some very important measures to break the impasse on the implementation of the NFPS.

As Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories—and as I have said time and time again in this chamber—the conservation elements of the national forest policy statement are obviously my central responsibility. A central conservation objective of the NFPS is the commitment to the establishment of a comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system for our forests.

The NFPS also sets out a process to comprehensively assess the full range of environmental and heritage obligations. These include assessment of national estate values, World Heritage values, environmental impacts, Aboriginal heritage values and obligations relating to international conventions, including those to protect endangered species and biodiversity.

Importantly, the NFPS also contains an agreement that, until the assessments of the full range of environment and heritage values are completed and the reserve system is established, activities that may significantly affect those areas of old-growth forest or wilderness that are likely to have high conservation value should be avoided. That is, of course, commonly known as the moratorium clause of the NFPS. The NFPS also makes it clear that the Commonwealth has certain responsibilities with regard to the protection of forests. These include World Heritage, biodiversity, endangered species, Aboriginal heritage and national estate values.

In December 1993, the cabinet decided that, in future, the minister for the environment would be required to provide the minister responsible for resources with advice on the applicability of the national forest policy statement to the granting of export woodchip licences.

Let me speak now on the processes that were followed in developing my advice for Minister Beddall last year. In July 1994, the Department of Primary Industries and Energy wrote to state forest agencies seeking a complete list of places to be logged and from which woodchips would be obtained. DPIE also sought information from state agencies on what they were doing to implement the moratorium clause of the NFPS. The information to be provided was specified in a grants agreement between DEST and the conservation organisations because, in August 1994, my department funded conservation organisations to allow them to participate in the process. I spoke in question time about these grants agreements.

The conservation organisations were required to provide substantiated evidence against specified criteria. The criteria relate directly to the Commonwealth government's obligations and interests under international conventions, Commonwealth legislation or the requirements of the national forest policy statement. That includes old-growth forest and wilderness, national estate, World Heritage, endangered species and biodiversity values.

Also in August, the acting environment minister, Senator Bolkus, wrote to state ministers and to industry informing them of this initiative and inviting them to comment and advise the department on the advice received from conservation organisations. Similar letters were sent from myself to relevant trade unions and the Forest Protection Society. Contact was made at officials level also between governments.

The New South Wales and Tasmanian governments responded that they would not cooperate in the assessment process. One of the biggest problems with this exercise was that, by mid-September, little advice on the proposed logging plans of state agencies and the ways in which states were implementing the moratorium clause had been received by my portfolio to enable the portfolio and conservation groups to determine priority areas for assessment.

The states' advice was received from DPIE by the forest branch in the environment strategies directorate in my department. It was forwarded to the Environment Protection Agency, the Australian Heritage Commission, the Australian Nature Conservation Agency and the World Heritage and biodiversity branch and the environment resources information network in the environment strategies directorate.

These areas undertook the analysis of the state logging plans and incorporated the information the conservation groups supplied as it became available in early November. The Australian Heritage Commission concurrently undertook its section 30 analysis, as required under the Australian Heritage Commission Act. Upon receipt of the reports from the conservation groups in early November, they were forwarded to state governments, including New South Wales and Tasmania, even though they had said they were not going to cooperate, to NAFI, the Forest Protection Society and the union, the CFMEU, for comment to enable them to advise my department of any errors in the information. Only Western Australia commented on the areas the conservation groups had listed. Victoria provided a strategic approach to the protection of conservation values.

The portfolio undertook its assessment of the conservation significance of the areas planned to be logged in a variety of ways, depending on the level and detail of information known about the regions. The portfolio checked the geographic location of the coupes in order to determine obvious errors. That identification process did pick up a number of errors. For example, Forestry Tasmania had, in the original plans, misspecified the location of quite a number of coupes which we found to be located in the middle of Bass Strait.

The Australian Heritage Commission checked coupes against information held on the register of the National Estate. ERIN mapped the location of coupes against information it holds on nationally threatened species and rare species of plants that it obtained from the records of museums, herbaria and botanical gardens around Australia. ANCA plotted the location of coupes against information it holds on the distribution of national, state and regional rare and threatened species and communities. It undertook an analysis of the significance of places for the conservation of biological diversity. This included an analysis of the significance of regions and the importance of particular locations in the protection of biodiversity at a regional level.

The conservation status of forest communities was checked by the portfolio against all the available information. Where it was considered an area was poorly reserved, it was listed as likely to be of high conservation value. An analysis was also undertaken on the habitat requirements and strategies that are needed to be put in place to protect species listed in the Endangered Species Protection Act.

An analysis of coupes was undertaken by the Heritage Commission against the national wilderness inventory for those regions where it had been completed. Where the national wilderness inventory was several years old, an assessment was made, frequently in consultation with conservation groups, of the level of impact that logging operations had on that wilderness area. In places where the national wilderness inventory had not been completed—in New South Wales and the south-west of Western Australia—other assessments were used, notably the New South Wales parks and wildlife assessment of wilderness areas and the joint AHC-CALM assessment used in the southern forest region of Western Australia.

The portfolio also carefully assessed the values of coupes against documents and published information held in the portfolio and against previous assessments undertaken in cooperation with state agencies where Commonwealth officials had participated or where assessments were undertaken by the Commonwealth. The portfolio applied the NFPS definition of old-growth forest in undertaking its assessment and it relied on the existing mapping of old-growth forests, which was undertaken by state agencies, to support its analysis.

DEST relied on the Tasmanian forest and forest industry strategy old-growth assessment to determine the old-growth status of forests in many parts of that state. Consistent with the NFPS, the portfolio would not accept that the occurrence of some past logging for sawlogs in itself prevents an area from being an old-growth forest. That view is reinforced by the outcomes of the study by the Victorian Department of Conservation and Natural Resources of old-growth forests in East Gippsland which is recognised as being the best methodology for the identification of old-growth forest yet developed in Australia.

The New South Wales and Tasmanian governments' rebuttal of the department's analysis of old-growth forests has generally been on the basis of the presence of old logging tracks in the vicinity indicating that the area was likely to have been logged for sawlogs without an explanation of when. It could have been up to 100 years ago when they used selective logging with bullocks and it does not take into account the current age and appearance of the forest. Where a state agency commented on the outputs of the conservation organisation, this was assessed and incorporated into the analysis. This is reflected in the assessment of areas likely to be of high conservation value in Western Australia and which incorporates that infor mation.

Most people contributing to this debate say that the national forest policy statement is the way forward. I certainly agree with that. But the NFPS will not stand up if we ignore or do not give proper consideration to its conservation elements. The interim protection of areas likely to have high conservation value is an integral and important part of the national forest policy statement. It is central to the conservation objectives of the NFPS.

This is what the government is trying to achieve. That is why I undertook the process that I have outlined to the Senate. It will be interesting to see whether the states are willing to take the next step and fulfil their conservation responsibilities under the NFPS. I have said—and I believe this to be the case—that the statements of the Prime Minister on 22 December last year and 27 January represent a very balanced outcome. They represent a good outcome in a debate where invariably passions and passionate views run very highly. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no doubt that the matter outlined in Senator Ian Macdonald's letter qualifies as a matter of urgency. The Democrats are tempted to agree with the coalition that the government should be condemned—and I refer to the letter:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . for demeaning the high conservation evaluation process for forest areas and for walking away from the obligations and responsibilities of the National Forest Policy Statement as agreed between the Commonwealth and the mainland states.

We are seriously concerned about what it is that has been agreed between the Commonwealth and the mainland states. We do not necessarily support all that has been agreed. However, it is a fact that important aspects of the national forest policy, which have been signed and should be enforced, have not been enforced. The mainland states are even moving away from that with which they have already agreed. The Tasmanian Premier has today, and in the past week or so, been trying to negotiate the NFPS down by applying his own constrictions and constraints. The other states would soon seek to follow suit and bring about the lowest common denominator. In a speech I made in this place on 10 November last year about the national forest policy statement—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not quoting your own speeches, are you?

—Yes, I certainly am. I criticised the government's inability or unwillingness to implement its own policy. I remind Senator Macdonald that, at that stage, I agreed with his matter of urgency. I remind the Senate of the importance of what was said then. I thought it was important enough to say it then, but obviously certain people here did not realise that I was criticising the government at that time. I said:

SPEECH.PARA: The federal government has a policy that it is not implementing. It is called the national forest policy but, like many of this government's promises, it exists on paper only.

TALK.START.PARA: —The pain will not continue for long, Senator Abetz, but I am sure it is necessary to prove this point. I went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The government has taken the jargon, used the rhetoric and hoodwinked us into believing that it might do something to protect our forests. Thanks to Senator Collins's recent information, we now know that there are still no adequate comprehensive and representative areas protected by the policy.

PARA.TAB: The government has had about two years in which to implement it.

SPEECH.PARA: I reminded the government at the time that it had only one year to go before all was supposed to be finished. Time was running out very quickly. I continued with the concern I expressed by participating in the court challenge which successfully proved that the minister was incapable of following the processes that are set out in the law of the land and that the minister was incompetent. I demonstrated that incompetence.

PARA.TAB: It is important to return to the debate on the passage of the Environmental Protection (Impact of Proposals) Amendment Bill 1986. The second reading speech given by the minister at the time, Mr Cohen, is a pertinent illustration of the intent of the government at the time in establishing this process. I remind the Senate that these comments were made on 17 April 1986. We were told that the object of the act, which originally came into force in 1974 and was being amended here, was `to ensure that to the greatest extent practicable matters affecting the environment to a significant extent are fully examined and taken into account in relation to actions and decisions of the Commonwealth government and its authorities'. We were further told:

SPEECH.PARA: The Act is a cornerstone of the Government's environment protection legislation. Under its provisions the environmental implications of a wide range of proposals have been examined.
This has only recently been brought to our attention, but it was said in 1986. The minister continued:
These include airports, railways, ports, highways, buildings, and coal, iron ore, uranium and woodchip export projects.
We were also told that the government took into account two important procedures with this act. He said:

The first is that memoranda of understanding to be agreed between the environment Department and other Commonwealth departments and authorities. These memoranda will provide a clear basis for identifying proposals that are environmentally significant. The second is that, in the rare event that there is a difference of opinion between Ministers on the environmental significance of a particular proposal, the matter would be resolved by the normal process of referral to the Prime Minister and Cabinet.
The minister said:
Amendments will provide . . . for the preparation of public environment reports—PERs—for proposals with less complex or less important environmental implications.
Before he concluded, the minister said:

The Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 is a major piece of legislation which, since its introduction, has significantly assisted Ministers in taking environmental implications properly into account in Government decision making. The amendments to the Act and administrative procedures which the Government intends to make will further improve the effectiveness of the process.
The bill was commended to the house. Before it received passage, Senator Collard, the then Leader of the National Party of Australia, said:
This is a Bill that we will not be opposing, as it makes a fair bit of sense.

He said that it was the result of the benefits of several reports and that therefore it was a wonderful thing. It received support from that speaker. I remind the Senate that, at the time, the Australian Democrats said that we thought the balance was wrong, that the ministers in contention would not deliver a proper result and that the EIS should be under the control of the Minister for the Arts, Heritage and the Environment who would then, perhaps in consultation with the action minister, achieve a result.

PARA.TAB: We criticised it then. We said that the process was faulty. At the time we said that the results that would be delivered were not satisfactory. We are vindicated by this very mess that we see before us today. What we want to do is to examine, carefully evaluate and correct that process. We are not particularly interested in the excuses that the government offers. We are interested in what it has actually done. We agree that that is worthy of criticism. That is why we will be supporting this motion before us. It is consistent with the criticism that we have levelled at the process over the past several months. It is consistent with our original criticism that the process was not properly balanced and that it would deliver a result which was not satisfactory.

Senator Macdonald's letter accuses the government of walking away from the obligations and responsibilities of the national forest policy statement. The Democrats agree with that accusation; it is accurate. While we do not necessarily agree with all aspects of the national forest policy statement, we believe in accountability. When there is a law, we will seek to ensure that this government follows it. That is our purpose in pursuing the minister on this matter. If the law of the land is good enough to be passed and supported in this place, then it should be enforced.

TALK.START.PARA: —You support our motion.

—Certainly. I have said that three times and I do not think I need to repeat it. What I need to do is to illustrate some of the faulty evidence which has been put forward in some of the arguments that have been put here. On page 15 of yesterday's Daily Hansard Senator Panizza accused the Democrats of pushing a lie. When talking about the process of what goes in for woodchipping, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The logs do not go in as a whole. The Democrats are not bad at pushing this lie . . .

I refer to the publication sent to shareholders by North Forest Products. I do not think anybody would disagree with the illustration which is part of that publication. It notes that the woodchips of North Forest Products come from low-grade diseased or defective logs from native forests. That is what the issue is fundamentally about—the definition of what is low-grade and what is defective.

PARA.TAB: We really are not so much arguing about whether or not logs go into woodchip factories. The fact is that this place is ringed by machinery attached to prime movers and triaxles. That is what they are there for. They are there to carry logs. We know it; they know it. Anybody who says, as Senator Panizza has, that logs do not go in is talking nonsense. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think anybody ignores the fact that this is a difficult issue. There is a diversity of views. Senator Macdonald's urgency motion condemns the government for demeaning the high conservation evaluation process. The process may not have been the best with regard to how you identify certain things, but sometimes it is very difficult, particularly when you consider the constitutional arrangements of this country where the states essentially have control over the forests. They make the land use management decisions. Sometimes they are reticent or are uncooperative with the supply of information. At the end of the day, if they supply accurate information, then it makes this whole process much easier. It makes it a much more valuable process. At the end of the day, we would get a result that serves the interests of both the conservation of forests of this country and the industry. In terms of your condemnation or the fact that you try to claim that we have walked away from the national forest policy statement—
—Exactly right!
—It is not exactly right. In fact, it is quite the contrary.
—What have you done about it?

—If Senator Macdonald read it—I seriously doubt that he has—he would understand that it is a joint agreement which requires joint implementation. They are the fundamental things with regard to a national forest policy statement.

PARA.TAB: Our state would initially not sign up to the process, but it has now agreed to. It took a long time to do so. I will give some examples of why there should be such concern about the environment. I know that all of the people who are present are also concerned about the environment because it is in their interests to do so. I will give some examples as to why there ought to be serious concern. It also relates to another senator sitting in the chamber, Senator Gibson, who was the managing director of a company called Australian Newsprint Mills. That company had a concessional right in Tasmania. That concessional right for many years allowed it to misuse and abuse a resource that had not only an environmental value but also a significant value in terms of social and economic return to this country that was unbelievable.

In 1989, I got in the boot of a car because the general public was denied access to the Florentine concession in Tasmania. I got in the boot of a car so that I could get in with a video camera. I videoed some of the most shocking abuse of forests that one could ever believe. I know that there are a lot of sawmill industry workers here. Let me tell them that there was a pile of tagged blackwood sawlogs that would not fit in this chamber. They could have provided a significant amount of jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: —What year was that, Shayne?
—What year?

—It was 1989, if you were not listening. I had to take that video to the then minister for forests and now Tasmanian premier, Ray Groom. I said, `Minister, you need to do something about this.' This was public land. Do you know what? The state forestry commission had no right of access to it unless it was granted by the company. This is an example of the sort of problems that we have had in the past. It is 100 per cent correct.

PARA.TAB: I also took some film of a coupe of eucalyptus regnans that was felled. Much of it was very valuable timber. Do you know where it all ended up? It was turned into newsprint. It could have provided hundreds of jobs had it been properly managed and harvested in a way that was environmentally sound, socially sound and economically sound, but it was not. So there are some problems.

I have always ensured, and will continue to ensure, within this government that we look after the environment. In terms of the forest industry and the national forest policy statement, I will continue to work to ensure that we do more downstream processing of our forest woods in this country to provide more jobs for Australians and to give a better economic return to this country. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are talking about a crisis in the forest industry. Woodchipping has been a clever political diversion. The real argument is not about woodchips; the real argument is about the use of the native forests of Australia. The extreme Greens have been pushing for many years to try to lock up all the native forests of Australia. Such groups, including the Australian Conservation Foundation and the Wilderness Society, have compiled public written, long-term objectives about it all. There is no argument that that is what they are on about. They have been peddling apparent scientific nonsense to the community, which is gullible about these issues, and trying to assert that the forests of Australia are being desecrated. What nonsense!

PARA.TAB: We have been through many inquiries. In 1988, then Prime Minister Hawke said, `We've had enough of all these arguments. We should have a huge inquiry into what is going on and establish the scientific credibility of what is going on.' A Resource Assessment Commission hearing under Justice Stewart from 1989 to 1992 cost many millions of dollars. Everyone had a chance to put their views about what was going on. What arose out of that? The Resource Assessment Commission said that there was no ecological reason why, provided that there are adequate reserves throughout Australia, a large proportion of the native forests could not have multiple uses, including of wood.

The real argument is really about how much park is locked up and how much multiple use forest is used. Woodchipping is the diversion that is being used in this argument. So the Hawke government, arising out that RAC inquiry, ended up negotiating with the states and establishing the national forest policy statement, which was signed by most of the premiers in December 1993.

What has happened since then? All the states complain that this government's Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories, which is supposed to be establishing the criteria for the assessment of all these forests, has not provided the criteria. It will not cooperate or agree. The latest Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) is a prime example of that. By not establishing that criteria, we do not have the agreements between the Commonwealth and the states that should be in place.

Most of the states have been through this process many times. My own state of Tasmania has been through very extensive examinations of the forests, but we have not reached agreement with the Commonwealth. Because the Commonwealth has not cooperated in helping to solve this problem once and for all, it is no wonder that some of the states have not wanted to cooperate with Senator Faulkner and his department as they went off on a political exercise. The federal government has been on a political exercise, using this matter to try to get encouragement and votes for itself in suburban Melbourne and Sydney, where people are ignorant about the true matters and how forests work. That is what it is really all about.

Senator Faulkner has made considerable effort to stress that he is implementing the so-called moratorium clause of the national forest policy statement. This clause, which is on page 11 of the statement, reads:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . forest management agencies will avoid activities that may significantly affect those areas of old-growth forest or wilderness that are likely to have high conservation value.

The statement goes on to say that the primary means of protecting these values is through a comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system. It does not suggest that all old-growth forests or wilderness areas are likely to have conservation value. Quite the contrary. It says:

Australia will continue to use old-growth timber for many years. It will come from disturbed forests containing some old-growth trees and from old-growth forests that are not required for the nature conservation reserve system.
It is the definition of the reserve system that really needs to be decided. The Commonwealth is to blame for not organising it.

PARA.TAB: By soliciting the advice of the environmental lobby groups in this latest round and then failing to scientifically scrutinise the advice, the minister and his department are derelict in their duty and have undermined the goodwill that is required to implement the national forest policy statement. In providing his advice to the Minister for Resources (Mr Beddall), Senator Faulkner paid scant regard to the evidence provided by the state management agencies that the compartments identified by the environment lobby did not have high conservation value.

The list provided by Senator Faulkner included plantations established for timber production, previously cleared farm land and many forests that had been logged at least once. Surely these areas cannot, by any stretch of the imagination, be considered old-growth forests or wilderness. In order to show how shonky the process was, I will quote from a letter from the Victorian department to the Commonwealth department of late last year:

SPEECH.PARA: Victoria's view of the process that has been established with the conservation groups is that it has no scientific credibility.

In Victoria's case, all that the groups have done is to take our own data, adjust some threshold levels to suit themselves . . . and present it in mostly tabular form. There is no scientific analysis . . .

What absolute nonsense. They also claim that some wilderness areas exist in the central highlands, which the state government's agency in Victoria claims do not exist at all. In Victoria, about 60 per cent of the old growth is locked up in parks of one sort or another. Many examples have been quoted, so let me quote a couple of Tasmanian examples. The conservation group that assessed Ringarooma coupes 107A, 108A and 108B claimed they were old growth forests and part of the undisturbed upper catchment of the Forester river. It just so happens that they do not belong to the Forester river; they are part of the Ringarooma river. The forests in these coupes have been heavily cut over for sawlog and are now mainly regrowth. Part of one of these coupes is abandoned, formerly cleared farmland. The forest in each of these coupes does not meet the national forest definition of `whole growth forests'.

PARA.TAB: Another example is Koonya 1A, again in Tasmania. There is a claim from a conservation group that this is important habitat for the swift parrot, a valuable species. The actual facts are that logging in the coupe was completed last year. The coupe contains E. Regnans, E. Obliqua and E. Delegatensi forest communities. This forest is not significant for swift parrots. The swift parrots' habitat is eucalyptus globulus forest on the dry coastal zones—quite different. They have got it all wrong. They are good examples of what is actually going on.

So by doing this Senator Faulkner has demeaned the whole process of true environmental assessment. He must get on with the process and reach agreement with the states using proper scientific criteria and not mess around trying to play politics between Sydney and Melbourne and the forest communities. It really is a shambles. I commend Senator Macdonald's urgency motion to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government deserves to be condemned for its recent decisions in regard to woodchip exports for not meeting its obligations and responsibilities to the forests of Australia, the community, both conservationists and timber workers, and its obligations under its own legislation, the Endangered Species Protection Act, and the International Covenant on Biological Diversity. It deserves to be condemned for not taking this opportunity to put in place the long-term measures necessary to ensure a future for the forests and the timber industry.

PARA.TAB: However, we will not encourage support for the national forest policy statement. It is reprehensible that the government has signed an agreement and then not fulfilled its obligations. The national forest policy statement was roundly condemned by the conservation movement when it was first introduced. It is a backdoor way to provide resource security to an industry that takes far more from Australia and the community than it returns, and it is a far cry from the expressed wishes of people across this country.

Ecologically sustainable forestry, according to the national forest policy statement, involves identifying representative examples of forest and the minimum forest necessary to provide habitat for part of the population of each species of Australian fauna. This is then defined as high conservation value and, hopefully, secured in reserves. The remainder of the forest is then considered available for logging. By this system we are creating museum forests, or zoo forests, small reminders of the magnificent heritage entrusted to us by previous generations to pass on to the next generation. The community has made it clear that it does not want old growth forest destroyed for woodchips.

In identifying 509 areas but not providing for their adequate protection, the federal government has condemned some of those very areas along with the other 800 identified by the environment minister. There is nothing to protect these areas from logging for sawlogs or the devastation caused by the building of roads. It is highly likely that these areas will be targeted by state agencies so that the values are destroyed or diminished by the time the government gets around to placing them into reserves.

I would like to take this opportunity to address the claims that areas without high conservation value were included in Senator Faulkner's advice to Mr Beddall. This is clearly designed to discredit the conservation movement, the eminent scientists, Senator Faulkner and the many government agencies involved in preparing the advice. Some of the forest blocs nominated in Western Australia include clear-felled areas and the WA advice made it quite clear that these areas were to be excluded. This illustrates that state forests and forestry departments have got in so quickly and it shows the fundamental problem for conservationists in that by highlighting areas for protection it makes them vulnerable to logging.

The Greens have real concerns for the future of our precious forest ecosystems and the forestry industry. The people employed in the industry have real concerns when they see the forest set aside for them being reduced. The only way forward for the government is to devise funds and implement a transition strategy away from the export woodchipping and the woodchipping of old growth and high conservation value forest and onto other sources of wood products. This may well cost the government in terms of subsidies and tax relief. However, the industry is already subsidised in a variety of ways. These subsidies would be far better directed towards a transition out of old growth logging. Unless we act now, our native forests outside of conservation reserves will soon be gone. The issues that we are facing now will inevitably have to be faced one day. The government has completely failed to resolve this issue. Greens, workers and the community at large will continue to be frustrated and angry. Old growth forests will continue to be destroyed and workers will be condemned to job losses unless the government acts now to put in place a comprehensive scientific, economic and consultative based process to resolve the forestry issue once and for all.

SPEECH.PARA: I quote from a media release from the Friends of Jane Forest:

The recently formed `Friends of Jane Forest', made up of local people from the Northcliffe community and led by a pioneer farming family, the Daubney's, today held up the construction of a logging highway through Jane forest.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

TALK.START.PARA: —May I request the incorporation in Hansard of the last two paragraphs by leave?

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: Robert Daubney, who owns a dairy farm adjoining Jane forest, said that the magnificence of the old growth karri forest juxtaposed with the devastation caused by the logging road has hardened the resolve of local people to protect one of Northcliffe's greatest natural assets.

"No studies have ever been done in this area", said Mr Daubney, a descendent of Northcliffe's first European settlers. "Surely we must have learnt something since the thirties. They don't even know what is being destroyed."

TALK.START.PARA: —Since Senator Chamarette has had that document incorporated in Hansard, she might also like to table the facsimile transmission from which she was reading throughout her speech.
—I will put the request to Senator Chamarette. Is it your wish, Senator Chamarette, to table the facsimile from which you were quoting?

—I am quite happy to, but I cannot understand the reason for the request. They are my speech notes. They have scribble all over them. I cannot see what will be assisted in the process. So I decline unless it is the wish of the Senate, in which case, of course, I will comply.
—Senator Chamarette has declined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This government is the mastermind of an unparalleled environmental fraud. It has undermined not only the industry but has made a sham of the assessment process. The mess by which the Minister for the Environment, Senator Faulkner, has put at risk the lives and security of over 22,000 decent and hardworking families, mostly in rural and regional Australia, should be exposed and condemned. In a letter to the Minister for Resources regarding the 1995 woodchip export licences, Senator Faulkner said:

SPEECH.PARA: In preparing my advice I have been rigorous in identifying forests of high conservation value.

This is utter rubbish. Senator Faulkner based his whole assessment of the 1,300 compartments set aside for protection on flawed information prepared by groups with a vested interest. The lack of scientific scrutiny and objective assessment in the process of his recommendation is entirely indefensible. To have the environmental lobby advising the minister on areas set aside for logging is like allowing animal liberationists to advise on our meat export industry. It is no wonder timber workers feel once again they have been duped and deceived by this government.

PARA.TAB: Senator Faulkner has used stooges in an attempt to undermine this vital industry. This whole process has been the great forest lotto of the century. The trouble for this minister and the government is that he has not been able to hide the evidence. It is really sloppy stuff from a tired government trapped into trying to pacify a vocal minority—a minority which is propagating deliberate lies by portraying woodchipping as public enemy No. 1—and the whole timber industry suffers as a result.

Over its chequered history the timber industry has had to undergo the most stringent scrutiny of any industry in Australia's history. Hundreds of timber studies have been carried out—by scientists and qualified professionals, I might add. The misinformation and plain lies regarding woodchipping that have received headlines in recent weeks need to be addressed. It was heartening to read the article in the Australian last Saturday. This article told the true story of the whole sorry and farcical episode.

If every picture tells a story, it is the front page of today's Australian. Forest evaluation is a complicated issue but the facts speak for themselves. What needs to be done is to have the public correctly and honestly informed. Senator Faulkner has fostered the grossly distorted image portrayed by the radical environmentalists of the timber and forest industries. They would have the public believe all timber is for woodchip processing. We need to repeatedly point out and put on the record that woodchips are produced from sawmill waste, silvicultural thinnings or low grade logs from normal harvesting. Woodchips are a by-product of the sawlog industry used for building and furniture. This by-product earns Australia around $450 million each year in export income.

With the current trade figures released today, with the current account blowing out to a record $2.4 billion, we should be supporting our export industries that bring much needed export dollars to our shores. If this waste was not turned into woodchip most of it would be burnt or left on the ground of the forests, thereby inhibiting future regrowth.

I turn to Mr Keating's decision. Undermining his resources minister's assessment and decision, the Prime Minister decided to step in and pluck 511—not 509, Mr Keating cannot count; we all know that—compartments out of Senator Faulkner's hit list in the hope of appeasing the Greens. But didn't the Prime Minister realise that this would not make the Greens happy?

Nothing will make the Greens happy until the whole industry is shut down. Your own backbench realises that—Mr Barry Cunningham, Mrs Smith and Mr Graeme Campbell realise that—and I should imagine that Senator Collins, the minister responsible for agriculture, realises that. The radical Green agenda is to completely close down the logging of native forests.

Let us take a further look at the so-called high conservation areas that are being set aside for further assessment. My state of New South Wales has 249 forest compartments listed out of the 511 Australia wide. New South Wales state forest records show that some 196 of the 249 compartments have a history of logging.

Let me take an example of one of these compartments. I bring to the minister's attention compartment 2329 in the Glenbog state forest near Eden. The first half of this compartment was logged in 1977, a part was selectively logged in 1984, several selective loggings for sawlogs were made from the 1920s to the late 1970s and the 1968 and 1977 regrowth was thinned in 1994—and this was after part clearing for highway construction. I would call this a predominantly regrowth forest, and I am sure that everybody else would too.

But not our Prime Minister. No, Mr Keating set this compartment aside. He set it aside as being of high conservation value. This government is selling out an industry on fundamentally flawed information and just plain lies. This government is selling out the livelihood of thousands of hardworking Australians in rural and regional Australia. This government is selling out on the Australian principle of a fair go for all. This government is selling out on much needed and important export dollars.

In 1992 the national forest policy statement was agreed to and signed by the Prime Minister and all state governments. It is an agreement, a contract. But only the states are playing by the rules. The industry is still awaiting the federal government's criteria in regard to the moratorium clause on old growth forests that are likely to have high conservation value. It is the Commonwealth that is dragging the chain.

The aim of the national forest policy statement is to end controversy and achieve uniformity and balance in the long-term interests of the timber industry and responsible conservation. I urge Senator Faulkner to get on track with the NFPS to end this controversy and achieve uniformity and balance in the long-term interests of the timber industry and responsible conservation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts Legislation Committee

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Devereux, I present the additional information received by the Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts Legislation Committee.
—I present the first report of 1995 of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. I also lay on the table the Scrutiny of Bills Alert Digest No. 1 1995, dated 1 February 1995.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Vanstone, and on behalf of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, I present a discussion paper by the committee entitled `Asian Organised Crime in Australia'. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.
Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are profound political changes happening on the other side of the Pacific. Those profound political changes will also, if they come to fruition, usher in profound economic changes, not just for the United States but for every government around the world that is faced with the prospect of borrowing money. The Republican Party in the United States is advocating a constitutional change that will require Congress and the President to present a balanced budget.

PARA.TAB: One may ask why that should be an issue of concern to us in Australia. The answer is very simple. We live in a world of complex and sophisticated global capital markets and the investors who lend their money to the United States government today may well be the investors who choose to lend their money to the Australian government tomorrow. It is simply a matter of fact that, if the United States federal government is forced by virtue of constitutional change to run a balanced budget, it then follows that countries like Australia—during the period which I have been in parliament, it has had a government, a Labor government, which has not once run a budgetary surplus or had a balanced budget but has, for every one of the last five years, run a budgetary deficit—which continue to live on the never-never will pay an increasingly exorbitant price for their borrowings.

An international investor faced with the prospect of lending to a country which exercises some sort of financial constraint, some sort of responsibility in fiscal terms, or lending to a country like Australia which is fiscally irresponsible, will always choose to lend to the responsible country at the same interest rate. Countries like Australia that are fiscally irresponsible—countries that live on the never-never; that is, they live on the national credit card, as the Keating Labor government would have us do—will have to pay a higher and higher interest rate as time goes on in order to seduce those investors to take the risk.

Those of us who live in Australia cannot turn our back on changes overseas. We must be aware that, if the United States Congress votes to implement constitutional change, if it votes to require a balanced US federal budget, it will have the effect of increasing borrowing costs for governments in Australia. There is a very real reason why this issue should be of foremost importance to this parliament. At this very moment almost $100 billion worth of Commonwealth securities are on issue. That is the level of the Commonwealth government's indebtedness as we sit here.

This year alone the Commonwealth government's public sector borrowing requirement—that is, the deficit plus the money that will mature that has to be rolled over—is some $20.4 billion. So that is the level of exposure to interest rate change this year. Ultimately, much of that $100 billion or thereabouts will have to be rolled over, refinanced, if we continue to run budgetary deficits, and of course it will be added to. That is the extent of our risk.

If you talk about a one per cent change in interest rates on $100 billion worth of debt, you are talking about an additional $1 billion of interest burden that not the government but the taxpayers have to meet. It is the taxpayers, not the government, who meet the costs. It is the ordinary Australians who bear the price when Labor and its administration is so financially irresponsible. That is the concern that this parliament should have.

But there is also a wider concern which should be shared by every single Australian voter and every Australian taxpayer: a decade in the 1980s of mainly Labor state administration has left many of our states which ought to be paragons of financial virtue in almost penury. We only have to look at the parlous state of the finances in Victoria to see exactly what Labor does when it is given a free hand with the public purse. It throws the money away and then begs the taxpayers to pick up the cost.

The electors of this country will be faced in the very near future with a number of state elections. There will be one in New South Wales this year, perhaps another one in Queensland this year or early next year and possibly a federal election in the next 12 to 18 months. The electors must ask themselves this question: do they trust Labor with the finances of their state and with the finances of their country? The answer must surely be that Labor is not worthy of trust because its track record has shown it to be financially irresponsible.

The cost of the government's financial irresponsibility we see in Victoria through lost jobs and lost opportunities. But the cost of its financial irresponsibility of the future, if these changes occur in the United States, will be far greater because the cost of paying for Labor's borrowings will be so much higher. That is why I say that we must have an end to the way Labor throws money out to its friends all over the place; we must have an end to the way Labor wastes the workers' dollar, the taxpayers' cheque; we must have a return to responsibility in fiscal matters; and we must have an end to the sorts of budgetary deficits that Labor has produced year after year but for what benefit? The answer is, for no benefit.

Where is the benefit to Australia of the billions and billions of dollars that Labor has wasted over the five years in which I have been in parliament, of the billions and billions of dollars that we have been forced to borrow? Has it been of benefit to the hundreds of thousands of unemployed? The answer is no—they are still unemployed. Is the benefit to the wellbeing of the future generations of Australians? Again the answer is no. Young Australians still grapple with the prospect of very difficult to obtain places in tertiary education and then, even after they have completed tertiary education, the struggle to find a job in the work force outside the university gates. That is the legacy of Labor—a legacy of despair. It is a legacy of despair which has cost this nation and this nation's taxpayers billions and billions of dollars.

This nation as a whole, in addition to the government's own debt, has been faced with crippling foreign debt. It is faced with hundreds of billions of dollars of foreign debt—a foreign debt some eight or nine times the foreign debt that this country had when Labor came to office in 1983. Yet, we had the macabre spectacle of Senator Gareth Evans leering over the table in question time, berating those of us on this side of the chamber and saying that we are scaremongers because we raise the fact that this nation's foreign debt is twice the foreign debt of Mexico—and Senator Evans says, `Don't worry about it.'

We raise the fact that our foreign debt is twice what it was in 1986 when the then Treasurer gave us the banana republic warning, and we are now told not to worry about it. If we should not worry about the foreign debt now, when it is twice what it was in 1986, why should it have been necessary to issue a warning in 1986 in the first place? There you see Labor's failure to grasp the reality of the financial quagmire in which this country finds itself: a total lack of reality, divorced from even the slightest semblance of the real world.

Foreign debt will cripple this country. Foreign debt at increasingly high rates of interest will cripple the future of my generation of Australians because it is my generation of Australians who will have to pay the price. It is my generation of Australians who suffer when this country pays an exorbitant interest bill overseas, because the money this nation pays away in interest is money that leaves these shores and it is money that could be creating jobs for young Australian men and women. But because that money has been sucked from our shores and sent overseas, the money that could have been spent in this country and that could have been creating jobs is lost to us forever.

Why do I say that this is important here today? It is important because we heard that the balance of payments deficit has blown out of all proportion—$2.4 billion seasonally adjusted for December. It is the highest balance of payments deficit on record, and the government is blissfully ignorant of the consequences. That is $2.4 billion further that this nation is in debt. That is $2.4 billion in just one month on which my generation of Australians will have to pay the debt. It is not right for Senator Evans and the government to come in here with the blithe excuses that we had today: `Well, it is just another lot of one-off transactions.' This month it is a liquid natural gas ship; last month it was a jumbo jet; the month before that it was two 737s. A series of one-off transactions month after month after month does not become a one-off trend; it becomes the norm. The norm is that this country is sinking further into debt.

The excuses you heard from Senator Evans were the same excuses you heard in the 1980s and the 1970s from every tin-pot dictator in Latin America, from every tin-pot dictator from Mexico to Argentina. I know that because, at the end of the 1980s, my job in London was to deal with the legacy of Latin American debt; to extract the price from Argentina, Chile, Mexico and Venezuela. Let me say that I do not want to see happen to this country what happened to Mexico, Argentina, Chile and Venezuela. If we follow the blithe excuses of the government, that is exactly what will happen. How can we hold our heads up high in the international community and say, `We are one of the greatest debtor nations on earth'? If the truth is told, that is the truth.

It is not good enough for Senator Evans to say it is a series of one-off transactions, nor is it good enough for Senator Evans to come into this chamber and say, `Look, we do not have to worry about the level of debt provided we can keep on paying it.' It is patently obvious that we cannot keep on paying the bill. If you or I went to the bank manager and said, `I know I have overdrawn by $60,000, but I can still keep on paying the interest,' that would not be an acceptable explanation. At the end of the day, somehow and at some time, you have to repay the principal, and the same applies to a company or to a country. It is not good enough to say, `I can pay the interest this month.' When are you going to repay the debt?

When is my generation going to be called upon to repay the debt which has been incurred by the folly of those who sit opposite? That is the question we should ask, and that is a question which fills me with trepidation. It may not fill Senator Evans with trepidation, but it fills me with trepidation. Those glib excuses were the excuses that were given in Latin America 20 years ago and the excuses that failed. Finally, on the issue of debt, I do not think it acceptable for Senator Evans to come up with one of the most ridiculous excuses of all time—the weather.

TALK.START.PARA: —He wouldn't blame it on the weather in 1982, though.

—Senator Panizza is right. In 1982 this country was beset with a crippling drought and the now government, the then opposition, was crying to heaven at what a dreadful bunch of people the coalition—the then government—was because of the weather. That mob that sit opposite are the same mob which earlier this year gave a niggardly sum to our farmers to try to overcome the weather, a niggardly sum compared with the amount that the coalition gave during the 1982-83 drought. Of course, recollection of history on that side of the chamber has always been a very selective affair. I am sure, given the twisted sense of morality that we see in this Labor government, it will remain a very selective affair.

PARA.TAB: This country is in parlous straits, and the Labor Party can hide its head under the desks, it can hide behind the lies and it can hide behind the untruths. At the end of the day, ordinary Australians pay the cost. My generation pays the cost, and this government ought to be condemned for what it is doing to this country.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)—Before calling Senator Crane, I note that earlier he spoke in the debate for five minutes and would ordinarily have another 15 minutes. I call Senator Crane to seek leave to speak again for up to 15 minutes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen A.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to continue my speech. I had to get leave, and I spoke to the minister on the other side, Senator Sherry, when he was here and he agreed to it.
—Leave is granted, but I was advised it was 10 minutes. It is now 15?

—It will be 10 minutes. I want to pick up on the matter that I had raised and also on the matter that Senator O'Chee has talked about. I compliment Senator O'Chee on his comments with regard to debt, because there is no doubt that the biggest single thing threatening the wellbeing of this nation, its community and its families is the current debt load that this country carries. Unless we take action ourselves, one day—and I would suggest not too far down the track—the international bankers are going to come along, tap us on the shoulder and say, `Hey, no more. You cannot continue in that vein.' It would be no different to what would happen to you, me or anyone else when dealing with a bank, whether it be the housing loan, the business loan or the farming loan. When it gets to a particular point, the bank manager says, `You have got to start paying it back, or no more.' Then the banks put you through certain processes. That is a very simple message that we need get across in this debate.

PARA.TAB: The biggest single failing of this government over the past 10 or 12 years is that it has allowed our national debt, through a conglomeration of policies and events, to blow out to the extent that it has. What the government has done is transfer what should have been part of our pain to our children and our grandchildren. That is the disappointment and the disgrace of it.

I want to deal with the matters relating to the problems we have in this country right now. I mentioned interest rates and debt. I will not go over them again. I go back to the one area that this government has not been prepared to address in a meaningful, proper way. I refer to industrial relations reform. In the debate just over 12 months ago I issued a couple of warnings about the legislation at that time. I want to repeat them. We have a piece of industrial legislation now in which we have a series of cases in the various courts around this land and a number of them in the High Court. At that time I said:

SPEECH.PARA: At that time there was no concern about the ILO conventions or the right of freedom of association from the opposite side of the chamber nor from the end of the chamber. Once again, much of this bill is based on the selective use of conventions and much of it will end up in the High Court.
I emphasise that point: much of it will end up in the High Court. I also said:

We must never forget that when we put up legislation we have a responsibility in this place to try to avoid the lengthy cases and the drawn out situations which arrive from things being taken to the High Court. There is no doubt that this legislation will end up in the High Court.
I further went on and said:

If they want a lawyer-led recovery, they are going the right way about it, not only in terms of this legislation but also the legislation that we will be dealing with either tomorrow or the next day—the Mabo legislation.

I want to re-emphasise that point because a series of legislation we have presented and dealt with in this place over the last 18 months—particularly those based on the use, or misuse, of ILO conventions—are ending up in the courts. They are going to cost hundreds of thousands, if not millions and millions of dollars to resolve.

PARA.TAB: This issue is about overriding the constitutional and sovereign rights of the states. It is about overriding the freedom of association—the right to choose to belong to an organisation or a union. This legislation—and I will deal with a couple of cases in relation to this in a moment—overrode the freedoms which we should expect to exist in a democratic country such as Australia. This is highlighted by the fact that we see a number of the state governments, including my state of Western Australia, taking the legislation to the High Court because it overrides the constitutional responsibilities of Western Australia and other states. It interferes with their freedoms under our constitution.

There are other cases that relate to this issue. The Asahi case has had a lot of publicity in recent times. A commissioner ordered the people there to have a union involved in their activities, even though they chose as individuals not to belong to a union and even though they chose as individuals—collectively, as I understand it—not to have union representation in terms of negotiating their particular agreements. They were forced to do it. Their freedom was taken away.

That interferes dramatically with the capacity to reform because people will not allow themselves to be put in a position where they are dictated to by third parties—whether it be an organisation of employers, an organisation in the form of a union or an industrial tribunal. That is the nature of the beast. Australians are very independent people. Until such time as the government realises that and removes the impediments which currently exist in the act, cases like Asahi will continue—make no mistake about it. I issued that warning at that time.

There is also the Bay Bell situation in Tasmania. Bay Bell is a subsidiary of CRA. What do we find there? The company negotiated with sits employees, or the employees negotiated with the company—whichever way you want to put it. What happened? The Industrial Relations Commission stepped in and introduced a paid rates award. That case is now being appealed in the High Court. It has caused an enormous amount of insecurity in terms of employment. But it is worse than that.

Once again, it takes away the freedom of individuals to determine their own destiny in a fair and democratic country. That situation is covered by another part of the act and is once again administered through the commission. That power in the act is totally inappropriate. If the employees and the employers at Bay Bell wish to negotiate between themselves and come to a conclusion, that should be their right. If they wish to use the appropriate union, that should be their right. If they wish to use the local doctor to negotiate on their behalf, that should be their right. But they must have that freedom of association. Once again I emphasise that particular point: until that impediment, that restriction, that interference with liberty is removed from the Industrial Relations Act, we will not get proper industrial reform in this country. It will not happen.

Lastly, I want to deal with the situation of the hospital workers in Western Australia. They have been forced, once again through this Industrial Relations Act, to move out of the workplace contracts which they agreed would operate in Western Australia—to their benefit and to make the system more efficient. They have been forced to come in under a federal award. That is nothing short of a disgrace. The first four cases I have mentioned are all back in the Industrial Relations Court and three of them will end up in the High Court.

You cannot run a country with legislation that is going to end up in the High Court. As Senator O'Chee and other speakers have said here today, you cannot address the national debt and become truly productive in an internationally competitive sense. It is no good saying that we are productive just because we have improved from where we were before. It is like a cricket match where one side makes 200 runs in the first innings and the other side makes 150 runs, and then the first side makes 200 runs in the second innings and the second side makes 160 runs. You have still lost the game. That is what is happening to our productivity in terms of international competition. This government must recognise the mistakes, the faults, which exist in the act. It needs to make sure that the rhetoric in industrial relations policy in this country matches the legislation and that the legislation in fact addresses what we need to do to overcome our particular problem—our boom-bust scenario.

So there are many challenges currently in Australia. But, in my view, the key challenge, the most important one, is to address the impediments which exist in the workplace to create a more harmonious, productive, competitive workplace which will allow us to outperform those countries that we compete with, because we continue to be left behind.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not going to take the time of the Senate. An amendment has been moved and, of course, the government will be opposing that. As I understand, we will not be dividing on it. I would particularly like to thank all the senators who have made a contribution to this debate. As I understand, there has been a request that the debate not be finalised until the estimates hearings are concluded. The government and I certainly give an undertaking to schedule the third reading of this legislation after the supplementary estimates hearings. I hope that meets with the approval of senators.
