PARA.TAB: "SCHEDULE 3Section 4

SPEECH.PARA: RESOLUTION 955 (1994)

PARA.TAB: Adopted by the Security Council at its 3453rd meeting on 8 November 1994
The Security Council,
Reaffirming all its previous resolutions on the situation in Rwanda,

Having considered the reports of the Secretary-General pursuant to paragraph 3 of resolution 935 (1994) of 1 July 1994 (S/1994/879 and S/1994/906), and having taken note of the reports of the Special Rapporteur for Rwanda of the United Nations Commission on Human Rights (S/1994/1157, annex I and annex II),

Expressing appreciation for the work of the Commission of Experts established pursuant to resolution 935 (1994), in particular its preliminary report on violations of international humanitarian law in Rwanda transmitted by the Secretary-General's letter of 1 October 1994 (S/1994/1125),

Expressing once again its grave concern at the reports indicating that genocide and other systematic, widespread and flagrant violations of international humanitarian law have been committed in Rwanda,
Determining that this situation continues to constitute a threat to international peace and security,
Determined to put an end to such crimes and to take effective measures to bring to justice the persons who are responsible for them,

Convinced that in the particular circumstances of Rwanda, the prosecution of persons responsible for serious violations of international humanitarian law would enable this aim to be achieved and would contribute to the process of national reconciliation and to the restoration and maintenance of peace,

Believing that the establishment of an international tribunal for the prosecution of persons responsible for genocide and the other above-mentioned violations of international humanitarian law will contribute to ensuring that such violations are halted and effectively redressed,

Stressing also the need for international cooperation to strengthen the courts and judicial system of Rwanda, having regard in particular to the necessity for those courts to deal with large numbers of suspects,

Considering that the Commission of Experts established pursuant to resolution 935 (1994) should continue on an urgent basis the collection of information relating to evidence of grave violations of international humanitarian law committed in the territory of Rwanda and should submit its final report to the Secretary-General by 30 November 1994,
Acting under Chapter VII of the Charter of the United Nations,

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Decides hereby, having received the request of the Government of Rwanda (S/1994/1115), to establish an international tribunal for the sole purpose of prosecuting persons responsible for genocide and other serious violations of international humanitarian law committed in the territory of Rwanda and Rwandan citizens responsible for genocide and other such violations committed in the territory of neighbouring States, between 1 January 1994 and 31 December 1994 and to this end to adopt the Statute of the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda annexed hereto;

2.Decides that all States shall cooperate fully with the International Tribunal and its organs in accordance with the present resolution and the Statute of the International Tribunal and that consequently all States shall take any measures necessary under their domestic law to implement the provisions of the present resolution and the Statute, including the obligation of States to comply with requests for assistance or orders issued by a Trial Chamber under Article 28 of the Statute, and requests States to keep the Secretary-General informed of such measures;
3.Considers that the Government of Rwanda should be notified prior to the taking of decisions under articles 26 and 27 of the Statute;
4.Urges States and intergovernmental and non-governmental organizations to contribute funds, equipment and services to the International Tribunal, including the offer of expert personnel;

5.Requests the Secretary-General to implement this resolution urgently and in particular to make practical arrangements for the effective functioning of the International Tribunal, including recommendations to the Council as to possible locations for the seat of the International Tribunal at the earliest time and to report periodically to the Council;

6.Decides that the seat of the International Tribunal shall be determined by the Council having regard to considerations of justice and fairness as well as administrative efficiency, including access to witnesses, and economy, and subject to the conclusion of appropriate arrangements between the United Nations and the State of the seat, acceptable to the Council, having regard to the fact that the International Tribunal may meet away from its seat when it considers it necessary for the efficient exercise of its functions; and decides that an office will be established and proceedings will be conducted in Rwanda, where feasible and appropriate, subject to the conclusion of similar appropriate arrangements;
7.Decides to consider increasing the number of judges and Trial Chambers of the International Tribunal if it becomes necessary;
8.Decides to remain actively seized of the matter.

PARA.TAB: "SCHEDULE 4Section 4

SPEECH.PARA: STATUTE OF THE RWANDA TRIBUNAL

PARA.TAB: Having been established by the Security Council acting under Chapter VII of the Charter of the United Nations, the International Criminal Tribunal for the Prosecution of Persons Responsible for Genocide and Other Serious Violations of International Humanitarian Law Committed in the Territory of Rwanda and Rwandan citizens responsible for genocide and other such violations committed in the territory of neighbouring States, between 1 January 1994 and 31 December 1994 (hereinafter referred to as "the International Tribunal for Rwanda") shall function in accordance with the provisions of the present Statute.

SPEECH.PARA: Article 1
Competence of the International Tribunal for Rwanda

The International Tribunal for Rwanda shall have the power to prosecute persons responsible for serious violations of international humanitarian law committed in the territory of Rwanda and Rwandan citizens responsible for such violations committed in the territory of neighbouring States, between 1 January 1994 and 31 December 1994, in accordance with the provisions of the present Statute.
Article 2
Genocide

1.The International Tribunal for Rwanda shall have the power to prosecute persons committing genocide as defined in paragraph 2 of this article or of committing any of the other acts enumerated in paragraph 3 of this article.
2.Genocide means any of the following acts committed with intent to destroy, in whole or in part, a national, ethnical, racial or religious group, as such:
(a)Killing members of the group;
(b)Causing serious bodily or mental harm to members of the group;
(c)Deliberately inflicting on the group conditions of life calculated to bring about its physical destruction in whole or in part;
(d)Imposing measures intended to prevent births within the group;
(e)Forcibly transferring children of the group to another group.
3.The following acts shall be punishable:
(a)Genocide;
(b)Conspiracy to commit genocide;
(c)Direct and public incitement to commit genocide;
(d)Attempt to commit genocide;
(e)Complicity in genocide.
Article 3
Crimes against humanity

PARA.TAB: The International Tribunal for Rwanda shall have the power to prosecute persons responsible for the following crimes when committed as part of a widespread or systematic attack against any civilian population on national, political, ethnic, racial or religious grounds:
(a)Murder;
(b)Extermination;
(c)Enslavement;
(d)Deportation;
(e)Imprisonment;
(f)Torture;
(g)Rape;
(h)Persecutions on political, racial and religious grounds;
(i)Other inhumane acts.

SPEECH.PARA: Article 4
Violations of Article 3 common to the Geneva Conventions and of Additional Protocol II

PARA.TAB: The International Tribunal for Rwanda shall have the power to prosecute persons committing or ordering to be committed serious violations of Article 3 common to the Geneva Conventions of 12 August 1949 for the Protection of War Victims, and of Additional Protocol II thereto of 8 June 1977. These violations shall include, but shall not be limited to:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)Violence to life, health and physical or mental well-being of persons, in particular murder as well as cruel treatment such as torture, mutilation or any form of corporal punishment;
(b)Collective punishments;
(c)Taking of hostages;
(d)Acts of terrorism;
(e)Outrages upon personal dignity, in particular humiliating and degrading treatment, rape, enforced prostitution and any form of indecent assault;
(f)Pillage;

(g)The passing of sentences and the carrying out of executions without previous judgement pronounced by a regularly constituted court, affording all the judicial guarantees which are recognized as indispensable by civilized peoples;
(h)Threats to commit any of the foregoing acts.
Article 5
Personal jurisdiction

PARA.TAB: The International Tribunal for Rwanda shall have jurisdiction over natural persons pursuant to the provisions of the present Statute.

SPEECH.PARA: Article 6
Individual criminal responsibility

1.A person who planned, instigated, ordered, committed or otherwise aided and abetted in the planning, preparation or execution of a crime referred to in articles 2 to 4 of the present Statute, shall be individually responsible for the crime.

2.The official position of any accused person, whether as Head of State or Government or as a responsible Government official, shall not relieve such person of criminal responsibility nor mitigate punishment.

3.The fact that any of the acts referred to in articles 2 to 4 of the present Statute was committed by a subordinate does not relieve his or her superior of criminal responsibility if he or she knew or had reason to know that the subordinate was about to commit such acts or had done so and the superior failed to take the necessary and reasonable measures to prevent such acts or to punish the perpetrators thereof.

4.The fact that an accused person acted pursuant to an order of a Government or of a superior shall not relieve him or her of criminal responsibility, but may be considered in mitigation of punishment if the International Tribunal for Rwanda determines that justice so requires.
Article 7
Territorial and temporal jurisdiction

PARA.TAB: The territorial jurisdiction of the International Tribunal for Rwanda shall extend to the territory of Rwanda including its land surface and airspace as well as to the territory of neighbouring States in respect of serious violations of international humanitarian law committed by Rwandan citizens. The temporal jurisdiction of the International Tribunal for Rwanda shall extend to a period beginning on 1 January 1994 and ending on 31 December 1994.

SPEECH.PARA: Article 8
Concurrent jurisdiction

1.The International Tribunal for Rwanda and national courts shall have concurrent jurisdiction to prosecute persons for serious violations of international humanitarian law committed in the territory of Rwanda and Rwandan citizens for such violations committed in the territory of neighbouring States, between 1 January 1994 and 31 December 1994.

2.The International Tribunal for Rwanda shall have primacy over the national courts of all States. At any stage of the procedure, the International Tribunal for Rwanda may formally request national courts to defer to its competence in accordance with the present Statute and the Rules of Procedure and Evidence of the International Tribunal for Rwanda.
Article 9
Non bis in idem

1.No person shall be tried before a national court for acts constituting serious violations of international humanitarian law under the present Statute, for which he or she has already been tried by the International Tribunal for Rwanda.

2.A person who has been tried by a national court for acts constituting serious violations of international humanitarian law may be subsequently tried by the International Tribunal for Rwanda only if:
(a)The act for which he or she was tried was characterized as an ordinary crime; or
(b)The national court proceedings were not impartial or independent, were designed to shield the accused from international criminal responsibility, or the case was not diligently prosecuted.

3.In considering the penalty to be imposed on a person convicted of a crime under the present Statute, the International Tribunal for Rwanda shall take into account the extent to which any penalty imposed by a national court on the same person for the same act has already been served.
Article 10
Organization of the International Tribunal for Rwanda
The International Tribunal for Rwanda shall consist of the following organs:

PARA.TAB: (a)The Chambers, comprising two Trial Chambers and an Appeals Chamber;
(b)The Prosecutor; and
(c)A Registry.

SPEECH.PARA: Article 11
Composition of the Chambers

PARA.TAB: The Chambers shall be composed of eleven independent judges, no two of whom may be nationals of the same State, who shall serve as follows:
(a)Three judges shall serve in each of the Trial Chambers;
(b)Five judges shall serve in the Appeals Chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: Article 12
Qualification and election of judges

1.The judges shall be persons of high moral character, impartiality and integrity who possess the qualifications required in their respective countries for appointment to the highest judicial offices. In the overall composition of the Chambers due account shall be taken of the experience of the judges in criminal law, international law, including international humanitarian law and human rights law.

2.The members of the Appeals Chamber of the International Tribunal for the Prosecution of Persons Responsible for Serious Violations of International Law Committed in the Territory of the Former Yugoslavia since 1991 (hereinafter referred to as "the International Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia") shall also serve as the members of the Appeals Chamber of the International Tribunal for Rwanda.
3.The judges of the Trial Chambers of the International Tribunal for Rwanda shall be elected by the General Assembly from a list submitted by the Security Council, in the following manner:

(a)The Secretary-General shall invite nominations for judges of the Trial Chambers from States Members of the United Nations and non-member States maintaining permanent observer missions at United Nations Headquarters;

(b)Within thirty days of the date of the invitation of the Secretary-General, each State may nominate up to two candidates meeting the qualifications set out in paragraph 1 above, no two of whom shall be of the same nationality and neither of whom shall be of the same nationality as any judge on the Appeals Chamber;

(c)The Secretary-General shall forward the nominations received to the Security Council. From the nominations received the Security Council shall establish a list of not less than twelve and not more that eighteen candidates, taking due account of adequate representation on the International Tribunal for Rwanda of the principal legal systems of the world;

(d)The President of the Security Council shall transmit the list of candidates to the President of the General Assembly. From that list the General Assembly shall elect the six judges of the Trial Chambers. The candidates who receive an absolute majority of the votes of the States Members of the United Nations and of the non-Member States maintaining permanent observer missions at United Nations Headquarters, shall be declared elected. Should two candidates of the same nationality obtain the required majority vote, the one who received the higher number of votes shall be considered elected.

4.In the event of a vacancy in the Trial Chambers, after consultation with the Presidents of the Security Council and of the General Assembly, the Secretary-General shall appoint a person meeting the qualifications of paragraph 1 above, for the remainder of the term of office concerned.

5.The judges of the Trial Chambers shall be elected for a term of four years. The terms and conditions of service shall be those of the judges of the International Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia. They shall be eligible for re-election.
Article 13
Officers and members of the Chambers
1.The judges of the International Tribunal for Rwanda shall elect a President.

2.After consultation with the judges of the International Tribunal for Rwanda, the President shall assign the judges to the Trial Chambers. A judge shall serve only in the Chamber to which he or she was assigned.
3.The judges of each Trial Chamber shall elect a Presiding Judge, who shall conduct all of the proceedings of that Trial Chamber as a whole.
Article 14
Rules of procedure and evidence

PARA.TAB: The judges of the International Tribunal for Rwanda shall adopt, for the purpose of proceedings before the International Tribunal for Rwanda, the rules of procedure and evidence for the conduct of the pre-trial phase of the proceedings, trials and appeals, the admission of evidence, the protection of victims and witnesses and other appropriate matters of the International Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia with such changes as they deem necessary.

SPEECH.PARA: Article 15
The Prosecutor

1.The Prosecutor shall be responsible for the investigation and prosecution of persons responsible for serious violations of international humanitarian law committed in the territory of Rwanda and Rwandan citizens responsible for such violations committed in the territory of neighbouring States, between 1 January 1994 and 31 December 1994.
2.The Prosecutor shall act independently as a separate organ of the International Tribunal for Rwanda. He or she shall not seek or receive instructions from any Government or from any other source.

3.The Prosecutor of the International Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia shall also serve as the Prosecutor of the International Tribunal for Rwanda. He or she shall have additional staff, including an additional Deputy Prosecutor, to assist with the prosecutions before the International Tribunal for Rwanda. Such staff shall be appointed by the Secretary-General on the recommendation of the Prosecutor.
Article 16
The Registry
1.The Registry shall be responsible for the administration and servicing of the International Tribunal for Rwanda.
2.The Registry shall consist of a Registrar and such other staff as may be required.

3.The Registrar shall be appointed by the Secretary-General after consultation with the President of the International Tribunal for Rwanda. He or she shall serve for a four-year term and be eligible for reappointment. The terms and conditions of service of the Registrar shall be those of an Assistant Secretary-General of the United Nations.
4.The staff of the Registry shall be appointed by the Secretary-General on the recommendation of the Registrar.
Article 17
Investigation and preparation of indictment

1.The Prosecutor shall initiate investigations ex-officio or on the basis of information obtained from any source, particularly from Governments, United Nations organs, intergovernmental and non-governmental organizations. The Prosecutor shall assess the information received or obtained and decide whether there is sufficient basis to proceed.

2.The Prosecutor shall have the power to question suspects, victims and witnesses, to collect evidence and to conduct on-site investigations. In carrying out these tasks, the Prosecutor may, as appropriate, seek the assistance of the State authorities concerned.

3.If questioned, the suspect shall be entitled to be assisted by counsel of his or her own choice, including the right to have legal assistance assigned to the suspect without payment by him or her in any such case if he or she does not have sufficient means to pay for it, as well as to necessary translation into and from a language he or she speaks and understands.

4.Upon a determination that a prima facie case exists, the Prosecutor shall prepare an indictment containing a concise statement of the facts and the crime or crimes with which the accused is charged under the Statute. The indictment shall be transmitted to a judge of the Trial Chamber.
Article 18
Review of the indictment

1.The judge of the Trial Chamber to whom the indictment has been transmitted shall review it. If satisfied that a prima facie case has been established by the Prosecutor, he or she shall confirm the indictment. If not so satisfied, the indictment shall be dismissed.

2.Upon confirmation of an indictment, the judge may, at the request of the Prosecutor, issue such orders and warrants for the arrest, detention, surrender or transfer of persons, and any other orders as may be required for the conduct of the trial.
Article 19
Commencement and conduct of trial proceedings

1.The Trial Chambers shall ensure that a trial is fair and expeditious and that proceedings are conducted in accordance with the rules of procedure and evidence, with full respect for the rights of the accused and due regard for the protection of victims and witnesses.

2.A person against whom an indictment has been confirmed shall, pursuant to an order or an arrest warrant of the International Tribunal for Rwanda, be taken into custody, immediately informed of the charges against him or her and transferred to the International Tribunal for Rwanda.

3.The Trial Chamber shall read the indictment, satisfy itself that the rights of the accused are respected, confirm that the accused understands the indictment, and instruct the accused to enter a plea. The Trial Chamber shall then set the date for trial.
4.The hearings shall be public unless the Trial Chamber decides to close the proceedings in accordance with its rules of procedure and evidence.
Article 20
Rights of the accused
1.All persons shall be equal before the International Tribunal for Rwanda.
2.In the determination of charges against him or her, the accused shall be entitled to a fair and public hearing, subject to article 21 of the Statute.
3.The accused shall be presumed innocent until proved guilty according to the provisions of the present Statute.
4.In the determination of any charge against the accused pursuant to the present Statute, the accused shall be entitled to the following minimum guarantees, in full equality:
(a)To be informed promptly and in detail in a language which he or she understands of the nature and cause of the charge against him or her;
(b)To have adequate time and facilities for the preparation of his or her defence and to communicate with counsel of his or her own choosing;
(c)To be tried without undue delay;

(d)To be tried in his or her presence, and to defend himself or herself in person or through legal assistance of his or her own choosing; to be informed, if he or she does not have legal assistance, of this right; and to have legal assistance assigned to him or her, in any case where the interests of justice so require, and without payment by him or her in any such case if he or she does not have sufficient means to pay for it;

(e)To examine, or have examined, the witnesses against him or her and to obtain the attendance and examination of witnesses on his or her behalf under the same conditions as witnesses against him or her;
(f)To have the free assistance of an interpreter if he or she cannot understand or speak the language used in the International Tribunal for Rwanda;
(g)Not to be compelled to testify against himself or herself or to confess guilt.
Article 21
Protection of victims and witnesses

PARA.TAB: The International Tribunal for Rwanda shall provide in its rules of procedure and evidence for the protection of victims and witnesses. Such protection measures shall include, but shall not be limited to, the conduct of in camera proceedings and the protection of the victim's identity.

SPEECH.PARA: Article 22
Judgement
1.The Trial Chambers shall pronounce judgements and impose sentences and penalties on persons convicted of serious violations of international humanitarian law.

2.The judgement shall be rendered by a majority of the judges of the Trial Chamber, and shall be delivered by the Trial Chamber in public. It shall be accompanied by a reasoned opinion in writing, to which separate or dissenting opinions may be appended.
Article 23
Penalties

1.The penalty imposed by the Trial Chamber shall be limited to imprisonment. In determining the terms of imprisonment, the Trial Chambers shall have recourse to the general practice regarding prison sentences in the courts of Rwanda.
2.In imposing the sentences, the Trial Chambers should take into account such factors as the gravity of the offence and the individual circumstances of the convicted person.
3.In addition to imprisonment, the Trial Chambers may order the return of any property and proceeds acquired by criminal conduct, including by means of duress, to their rightful owners.
Article 24
Appellate proceedings
1.The Appeals Chamber shall hear appeals from persons convicted by the Trial Chambers or from the Prosecutor on the following grounds:

PARA.TAB: (a)An error on a question of law invalidating the decision; or
(b)An error of fact which has occasioned a miscarriage of justice.

SPEECH.PARA: 2.The Appeals Chamber may affirm, reverse or revise the decisions taken by the Trial Chambers.
Article 25
Review proceedings

PARA.TAB: Where a new fact has been discovered which was not known at the time of the proceedings before the Trial Chambers or the Appeals Chamber and which could have been a decisive factor in reaching the decision, the convicted person or the Prosecutor may submit to the International Tribunal for Rwanda an application for review of the judgement.

SPEECH.PARA: Article 26
Enforcement of sentences

PARA.TAB: Imprisonment shall be served in Rwanda or any of the States on a list of States which have indicated to the Security Council their willingness to accept convicted persons, as designated by the International Tribunal for Rwanda. Such imprisonment shall be in accordance with the applicable law of the State concerned, subject to the supervision of the International Tribunal for Rwanda.

SPEECH.PARA: Article 27
Pardon or commutation of sentences

PARA.TAB: If, pursuant to the applicable law of the State in which the convicted person is imprisoned, he or she is eligible for pardon or commutation of sentence, the State concerned shall notify the International Tribunal for Rwanda accordingly. There shall only be pardon or commutation of sentence if the President of the International Tribunal for Rwanda, in consultation with the judges, so decides on the basis of the interests of justice and the general principles of law.

SPEECH.PARA: Article 28
Cooperation and judicial assistance
1.States shall cooperate with the International Tribunal for Rwanda in the investigation and prosecution of persons accused of committing serious violations of international humanitarian law.
2.States shall comply without undue delay with any request for assistance or an order issued by a Trial Chamber, including, but not limited to:

PARA.TAB: (a)The identification and location of persons;

SPEECH.PARA: (b)The taking of testimony and the production of evidence;
(c)The service of documents;
(d)The arrest or detention of persons;
(e)The surrender or the transfer of the accused to the International Tribunal for Rwanda.
Article 29
The status, privileges and immunities of the International Tribunal for Rwanda

1.The Convention on the Privileges and Immunities of the United Nations of 13 February 1946 shall apply to the International Tribunal for Rwanda, the judges, the Prosecutor and his or her staff, and the Registrar and his or her staff.
2.The judges, the Prosecutor and the Registrar shall enjoy the privileges and immunities, exemptions and facilities accorded to diplomatic envoys, in accordance with international law.

3.The staff of the Prosecutor and of the Registrar shall enjoy the privileges and immunities accorded to officials of the United Nations under articles V and VII of the Convention referred to in paragraph 1 of this article.

4.Other persons, including the accused, required at the seat or meeting place of the International Tribunal for Rwanda shall be accorded such treatment as is necessary for the proper functioning of the International Tribunal for Rwanda.
Article 30
Expenses of the International Tribunal for Rwanda

PARA.TAB: The expenses of the International Tribunal for Rwanda shall be expenses of the Organization in accordance with Article 17 of the Charter of the United Nations.

SPEECH.PARA: Article 31
Working languages

PARA.TAB: The working languages of the International Tribunal shall be English and French.

SPEECH.PARA: Article 32
Annual report

PARA.TAB: The President of the International Tribunal for Rwanda shall submit an annual report of the International Tribunal for Rwanda to the Security Council and to the General Assembly.

SPEECH.PARA: (60)Title, page 1, omit "Tribunal perform its", substitute "Tribunals perform their".

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an unusual process. I am having trouble identifying the new amendment that the government is wanting to introduce. The minister might just clarify this.

—Instead of moving that we agree to amendments Nos 1 to 27 made by the House of Representatives, I have moved that we agree to amendments Nos 1 to 23, 25 to 27 but disagree to amendment No. 24 and I have moved a new amendment in place thereof. So at this stage we are moving an amendment to replace amendment No. 24 which, I believe, has been the subject of some discussions. We have moved that the Committee agree to amendment Nos 1 to 23, 25 to 27 and disagree to the circulated amendment No. 24. We have moved an amendment in place of amendment No. 24; and have moved further amendments to the bill as circulated. The only difference is how we handle amendment No. 24.

PARA.TAB: In order that the Senate can understand what we are doing with amendment No. 24, we are changing the word `tribunal' to `tribunals'. That is the only difference there. That is to pick up the fact that the new set of amendments refers to the Rwanda tribunal as well as the one that we have already discussed. So there is only a one letter change to amendment No. 24 and that is to clarify that drafting error.

TALK.START.PARA: —`made available to tribunals'.
—Yes. Instead of saying `tribunal', say `tribunals'.
—I was going to ask the minister to specify what the change was, but he has done so.

—I have a document headed `Schedule of amendments made by the House of Representatives', which I think is the one to which he has just been referring. I understand that he is now seeking that we adopt those amendments except No. 24. There is a separate sheet that refers to amendment No. 24 in the following terms: Amendment to be moved on behalf of the Government in substitution for amendment No. 24 made by the House of Representatives. Then there is another document before us which is headed `International War Crimes Tribunal Bill 1994 (Amendments to be moved on behalf of the Government)'.
—There are two messages—No. 350 and No. 351.
—What is the other one that has been circulated which is headed `(Amendments to be moved on behalf of the Government)' and which contains amendments Nos 1 to 59?

—I was not in the chair but I understand that that document to which you refer contains further amendments which were circulated as a result of the suspension of standing orders prior to going into committee. So there are additional amendments which are now before us as a result of the suspension of standing orders.
—So we are adopting the amendments of the House of Representatives and then the minister is going to move another set of amendments.
—That is right.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the amendments to the bills agreed to in the House of Representatives and the further amendments that have been moved by the government. If you want me to explain what those further amendments are, I will do that.
—We can do that in a minute. I have some queries arising out of your new amendments, but I could not relate them to the House of Representatives procedure. I now understand what you are doing.

—The question is that the amendments Nos 1 to 23 and 25 to 27 made by the House of Representatives be agreed to; that further amendments as circulated be agreed to; and that the Senate disagrees with amendment No. 24 and agrees to the substituted amendment in place thereof.

—Would it not be easier to deal with these one by one? You are packing a lot in there into one question. May I suggest we deal with the ones from the House of Representatives first, then allow the minister to explain amendment No. 24—he does not need to explain much about the adding of an `s'—and then he can explain the subsequent amendments.
—I am happy with that. The question is that the Senate agrees to amendments Nos 1 to 23 and 25 to 27 made by the House of Representatives.

PARA.TAB: Amendments agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —The second question is that the Senate does not agree to amendment 24.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —The third question is that the Senate agrees to the substitute amendment.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —The final question is that the Senate agrees to the further amendments.

—This is the part that I am concerned about because really this is totally new subject matter. The first bill that was debated and dealt with in both chambers concerned Australia's relationship with an International War Crimes Tribunal that had been set up to deal with matters arising out of the conflict in former Yugoslavia. It now seems that by amendment at this stage in this place the government is seeking to engage Australia under similar terms and conditions in another tribunal—the International War Crimes Tribunal—which has been set up to look at matters arising out of the conflict in Rwanda.

PARA.TAB: My concern with this is in many ways procedural because I have not had time to consider the substance of the government's argument. As I understand it, it was only in the very recent past, perhaps yesterday, that the request that we include Rwanda and change the first bill to refer to `tribunals' instead of `tribunal' was brought to our attention. There may be matters that really do require separate consideration.

For example, on our side, within the last week or so, Senator MacGibbon, together with the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray), visited Rwanda and may have a viewpoint, that I would like to know of, as to whether Australia should engage with this tribunal under exactly the same terms and conditions. I would also very much like to know the view of my colleague Senator Herron who, assisting in a medical capacity, spent six weeks or longer—several months, I think it was—in Rwanda during the conflict. He may well have strong views on this.

I am also not sure whether the tribunal that has been set up to address abuses arising out of the Rwandan conflict is identical to that which was set up to deal with former Yugoslavia. I am aware that the Security Council has passed a resolution and set up a tribunal—and, as a good internationalist, I accept that there might be responsibilities arising from that resolution which Australia wants to assume.

But I am uncomfortable with dealing with this at this time without us having had the opportunity to consider it properly. I am worried; if we take that attitude, are we holding up something that is critically important? I do not know the answer to that. I would be much more comfortable, my chronology of parliamentary events being correct, if this amendment were dealt with next week, after our shadow ministry and our party room have had the opportunity to consider these amendments. However, in saying so, I would not like to be giving the slightest hint that we might oppose it; we just want to do the job properly.

So I will listen to what the minister's explanation is for this unusual process. But subject to his explanation and, of course, after listening to what the Democrats and other minorities have to say, I am of a mind at the moment to seek that the committee report progress in order that we can give proper consideration to the matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —While I appreciate the concerns that were expressed by Senator Hill, at this stage we are inclined to proceed with this bill. We feel that the general principles applying to the tribunal established in connection with former Yugoslavia also apply to the Rwandan situation. But, like Senator Hill, I will be interested to hear what the minister has to say, in particular on the point of the urgency of getting this bill through today and whether or not any harm will come if we defer it until next week.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a couple of things I can say in response to the concerns raised by Senator Hill and Senator Spindler. I ask the committee to keep in mind that what we are doing here is not bringing in a new structure, a new principal or a new regime. The proposed amendments in relation to the Rwandan bill overwhelmingly do one thing; that is, of course, to extend the operation, which has been developed in the amended legislation in this place and the House of Representatives, to the situation in Rwanda. So the structure will be the same. There are in that second bill some further amendments, but they are basically amendments to correct deficiencies in the drafting of the substantial bills. So we have the same structure.

PARA.TAB: The government feels that it is important to act in respect of the Rwandan tribunal. On 8 November 1994, the UN Security Council adopted resolution 955, which established the Rwandan tribunal. In fact, that resolution was in identical terms to the one which set up the tribunal for former Yugoslavia.

TALK.START.PARA: —When was that set up?

—I will have that found out whilst I am talking. So the genesis is the same. It is an identical resolution which establishes both. The resolutions in relation to both tribunals—and this is, in fact, the driving force for the government's actions here—create immediately binding obligations on member states of the United Nations, which include Australia, of course, to cooperate and comply with requests for assistance from the tribunal.

PARA.TAB: What can be said about it? We can say that we are setting up the same structure. We are setting that structure up to pursue war crimes in Rwanda. We are not introducing new principles, concepts or whatever. We are doing so in pursuance of our international obligations. The alternative to this, of course—were we not to be introducing this at the earliest stage possible this year—would be to bring in another bill; that is, another bill which would be doing what the second part of the government amendments are doing now.

To us, given the fact that there is no difference in the structures and mechanisms of the former Yugoslavia tribunal and the Rwanda tribunal which we are talking about, it makes good sense to be able to deal with them both at this particular stage. There is no conceivable, good reason as to why we would go through this twice when we could go through it once.

In terms of the motivation to do it earlier, firstly, there is that process; and, secondly, we do have, under the UN resolution, an immediately binding obligation as a member state. So we feel that it is best that we do this as soon as possible rather than let it drag on, particularly as there are no policy reasons to necessitate deferral.

It is not as if we were setting up a new structure or designing new legislation; it is not as though we have to go through a Senate committee process to develop a structure. The structure has been set up. All we are really doing is implanting the Rwandan situation into that structure. For those reasons, we feel that it is important that we go ahead now.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the minister's remarks, I am sure senators understand the point he makes that it is better to deal with it at once rather than in two lots. But that of course does not address the question—I think put by Senator Spindler—of: what is the problem with doing what we would otherwise do today next week or the week thereafter? In fact, the mere point that this bill has not yet passed in relation to former Yugoslavia is an indication of how urgent these matters are. It is not as though, I presume, the government has some list of alleged war criminals in Australia that the tribunal has made, which it is requesting from us. There is not that pressing urgency, and presumably there is an even less pressing urgency in relation to Rwanda. Unless the minister likes to tell us otherwise, we do not imagine that this tribunal that has been set up is about to give us a list of names that need to be dealt with.
—There are not too many Tutsis and Hutus in Australia.

—There are not too many Tutsis and Hutus in Australia, as Senator Hill says. I just make this point in relation to urgency: the bill has not been passed in relation to former Yugoslavia. That has been dealt with for months and months and, quite properly, undergone a fairly decent review by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs; parliament has been doing its job.

PARA.TAB: Senator Bolkus, you come in here and say—apropos of yesterday, which was when my office heard about this—that we should tack on another dispute. I understand what you are saying; you are saying to me that the machinery is the same and, therefore, there is no problem. But what you are doing, if you do insist on proceeding with this today, is asking the rest of the chamber to take it on word—unless you have speed readers—that, for example, the statute of the Rwandan tribunal is not the same as the statute of the tribunal with respect to Yugoslavia. Are we not to be entitled to the opportunity to compare the two and see whether there is a difference, and whether any differences that may be there require some other changes to be made, for example, dealing with different types of crimes?

Someone might think there is a higher requirement for an appeal that might have been passed up in the original legislation or whatever. If there is any difference, there surely is an obligation on us, and there should be an opportunity provided, to look at the differences and ask, `Does that require a change to what we now think is the principle bill, however small that may be?'

I do not think there is any bad will or desire to mess things up. I wonder how long the government has known that it has wanted to do this and whether Senator Spindler had notice earlier than I did. It just does not seem the way to handle this. There isn't any bad will here, Senator Bolkus; there is just a desire to do the job properly.

I can understand you, as a government minister, saying, `Well, you would be doing the job properly. Take it from me; it's all okay. Just accept these amendments, and Rwanda will be included.' But, like Senator Hill, I would like to hear what Senator MacGibbon and Senator Herron have to say. Is the conflict in Rwanda different? Are we going to move similar amendments every time there is another conflict overseas? Yugoslavia, Rwanda—what next? Are we setting a precedent so that you can just come in here and say, `Another tribunal has been set up. Let's just stick this on to this bill'?

I have no desire to delay it. In fact, I had it in my head that we had already dealt with this. It has been on the list so many times and then been called off for one or another reason. One hesitates to have that happen again, but the proper thing for you to do is to give us the opportunity to make the proper comparison and discuss it with our colleagues. You cannot just announce on Tuesday that on Wednesday you would like to make a change which you say is small but which might, in the end, be quite dramatic.

As I say, there is no bad will, but what is the problem with leaving it until week two or three so that we can consult our party colleagues? Senator Spindler finds it easy to consult his party because there are so few of them. On this side of the chamber it is a bit more difficult to give everybody the opportunity. You should not run a party by what the shadow minister and the leader say. You should have the opportunity to consult with your colleagues, and you should welcome that. Unless you can convince me that you have a list from the tribunal of people who are going to escape unless this is passed, I do not see why you do not do tomorrow, next week or the week after what you want to do today.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief in response. With respect to the operation in former Yugoslavia, we are talking about a process that has gone on for quite some time. The resolution was passed by the UN in May 1993. The bill was introduced here about a year ago. There has been a long gestation period. My understanding is that investigations internationally are at an advanced stage and there is a need to proceed with this legislation and to do so quickly.
—But are they with respect to Rwanda?

—In terms of Rwanda, the United Nations passed that resolution last November. There are two decisions that any party assessing this would have to make. The first is the decision in principle in respect to Rwanda; the second is the decision on the specifics of the legislation. The legislation has been before us, and that does not seem to be an issue now.

PARA.TAB: I know that those of you on the other side have been preoccupied for a few months, but at no time in the last few months have you said that you do not support a tribunal in respect of Rwanda. As Senator Hill said, it would be most unlikely that you would reject it. The issue of extending to Rwanda is a question of principle. It is one that you probably will not disagree with, and one that any other organisation could make a decision on, given the atrocities that have occurred in that country.

Having said that, let me put the question to you. Don't ask, `Why?' Ask, `Why not?' Why not go ahead with it now? You have had enough time as a party to tackle the issue of Rwanda and the tribunal. I am sure that you have not been totally obsessed over the last three months with other matters. Your responsibility has been to look at issues like this. In terms of the specifics, there is nothing new. Why not do it now? Why are you procrastinating? I know that you are doing this in good spirit, and I appreciate that. That is why I am responding in a—

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't think your response is particularly in good spirit.

—I am sorry, Senator Hill. I could really go over the top if you wanted me to, but I am not going to. I think we can address the issue quite constructively. My constructive response to you is to ask, `Why not do it now?'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —There do seem to be differences. The tribunal is obviously established subject to a different resolution. This parliament has to decide whether the domestic regime that has been set up to regulate Australia's contribution to the Yugoslav tribunal is the appropriate regime to regulate Australia's responsibilities and contribution towards the proper function of the Rwandan tribunal. I would have thought that the chances are that it probably is so.

PARA.TAB: The answer to Senator Bolkus's rhetorical question of `Why not?' is simply because this is the chamber of scrutiny. We should not be expected to vote on matters that we have not been given adequate opportunity to consider. Certainly, the resolution of the UN Security Council provides for certain obligations. In paragraph 2 it states—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not going to oppose it.
—I do not think we will oppose it, either. The resolution states:

PARA.TAB: The Council decides that all states shall cooperate fully with the international tribunal and its organs in accordance with the present resolution of the statute of the international tribunal and that consequently all states shall take any measures necessary under their domestic law to implement the provisions of the present resolution of the statute.

SPEECH.PARA: What this government is obliged to consider—and what the parliament is obviously subsequently obliged to consider—is: what are the appropriate measures that Australia is, therefore, committed to implement to further the international community's resolution in relation to a war crimes tribunal for Rwanda? We want to do that in a way in which we are fully informed of the consequences of what we are doing.

PARA.TAB: Therefore, we seek reasonable time to do that. This government has not given us reasonable time. It is, therefore, not permitting this chamber to carry out its function of scrutiny in a way that is expected of it by the Australian people. We should be able to give it that consideration through our due process early next week, and we will be quite happy to come back and conclude the debate on the Rwandan addition to the bill in the latter half of next week. That seems to be a sensible and reasonable request on our part. I move:
That progress be reported.
Question put.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Progress reported.

DEBATE.TITLE: LAW AND JUSTICE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (NO. 3) 1994

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 7 December 1994, on motion by Senator Faulkner:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill is the sort of bill that comes on every session. I am told by the Attorney-General's Department that it has so many amendments that it would like to make to particular bills that we can count on having one of these bills in every session almost for the rest of my parliamentary time. I plan on that being extensive, so there must be very substantial amendments to be made.

PARA.TAB: This bill deals with a number of things. It makes amendments to tidy up the messy Security Appeals Tribunal by shifting it into the AAT, and makes some subsequent changes. It contains some amendments to the Acts Interpretation Act, the Federal Court Act and a few others. The opposition has some concerns about a number of those amendments, not the least of which are the amendments to the Acts Interpretation Act 1901.

This bill inserts a reading down provision which provides that, if a statutory provision could be read as having a particular application which would exceed Commonwealth power and can be read as having a valid application, the parliament intended that the provision should only have the valid application. This comes about because of a series of cases, including one of the recent Migration Act cases.

Recently, the High Court found the invalid applications of such provisions to be inseverable and therefore has found the provisions wholly invalid. The new section will provide that if a provision in its application to a particular person, thing or circumstance would exceed Commonwealth power but would validly apply to another particular person, thing or circumstance, the parliament intended that the provision should not have the invalid application but should have the valid application.

One way to explain that—and this might come from one of the cases—is that the clause which says that a court will not order a release of someone in custody reads as `anyone in custody', including illegally detained people. That would be stupid and improper for a variety of reasons, so we must have meant that it meant that only illegally detained people could be allowed out, and the whole thing got messed up.

This just does not seem the right way to go about it. If ordinary Joe Blow, whom I hope we have not lost sight of, picks up the bill and says, `What does this mean? Does it mean XYZ?', we should not, because of messy drafting, be saying, `It doesn't mean XYZ; it means only X because Y and Z are outside Commonwealth power.' We should not be doing that. We should be trying to get the legislation to reflect what we want to do that is within Commonwealth power.

I understand that this will make it easier for everybody, especially for us. It will certainly make it easier for the drafters. We are not saying that in the end there is necessarily another way out of this. We are saying that we would like the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs to look at it and that we would like to hear from experts in drafting to see whether this is the lazy person's way out or whether there is a better way to fix this problem. That is the first point that we would like to raise as a matter of concern.

We would also like to mention the amendments to the Federal Court of Australia Act 1976. The bill amends that act to provide for a review on a question of law of awards made in arbitration. These amendments will allow for questions of law to be referred to the court where a matter has been referred to arbitration but there has not been an award made in respect of that arbitration. The arbitrator can apply.

When we consulted the Law Council about this matter, it had some concern. Let me add that, in principle, it supported the changes to the legislation, giving an arbitrator to whom a matter had been referred power to apply to the court for leave to refer to a question of law, but it did consider that this provision was unduly restrictive and that the litigant should be able to make such an application personally in the way that such applications are contemplated by the provisions of section 39 of the Commercial Arbitration Act 1984 of Victoria, which I understand is reasonably uniform legislation.

Some concern was also raised about the provisions of section 53AB because they are different from and out of step with that uniform legislation. The proposed legislation gives a right of appeal from an arbitrator's award to a party to an award. Uniform legislation does not give such a right but it allows an appeal with either the consent of all parties or the leave of a court. Furthermore, the court cannot give such leave unless it is satisfied that there is a manifest error of law on the face of the award or that there is strong evidence that the arbitrator made an error of law.

Consequently, we think the question of uniformity is worth looking at. There may be some good reasons why the Commonwealth has drafted it this way and why following the Law Council's suggestion is unacceptable. We are not in any retractable position here. We would simply like to hear what the government has to say about that.

The final point relates to changes to the Security Appeals Tribunal and in particular to section 39A(9)(b), which has been described by some as draconian and unnecessary. This provision purports to exclude a person representing an applicant when evidence is given or submissions are made which are the subject of a minister's certificate given under that section unless the responsible minister consents. The imposition of a criminal sanction on persons breaching confidentiality by 39A(10) should be a sufficient deterrent for wrongful disclosure. More particularly, the exclusion of representatives is considered to be an unwarranted impairment of procedural fairness.

That is a good and reasonable point to make. If the applicant can be there, why does the Commonwealth assume that you can trust the applicant any more than you can trust the representative? I do not want to waste time nitpicking with members on the other side, but we are familiar with the constant lawyer bashing on the other side by now Minister Schacht, Peter Walsh, et al. There seems to be this constant assumption that you have to keep lawyers out; that you cannot trust them. For what other reason would you exclude them? There may be good reasons, and we would like to hear them. For that reason, we support a request by the Democrats to the Selection of Bills Committee that this matter be referred to a Friday committee. They may have other or additional concerns that they want to look at, but they are the ones that we want to look it.

I conclude by saying that in principle we are not drastically opposed. There is not some wall that we want to go to in this respect. But the comments made, particularly those by the Law Council, deserve a decent answer delivered in such a way that gives us time to consider it. That is why proceeding and moving amendments here and there in the committee stage where we get hardly any time to consider whether the answer given by the minister is satisfactory is not satisfactory. We support the reference to the Friday com mittee.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3). That bill is an omnibus bill which aims to abolish the Security Appeals Tribunal currently established under the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Act 1979 and transfer its jurisdiction to a newly created division of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

PARA.TAB: It also seeks to insert a reading down provision into the Acts Interpretation Act 1901. It seeks to amend the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975 to give effect to the recommendations of the report of the review of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. It seeks to amend the Federal Court of Australia Act 1976 to provide for a review on a question of law of awards made in arbitration and it also seeks to make some other minor amendments to the Judiciary Act 1903.

The Australian Democrats support much of the bill. However, we believe that a number of areas which give us concern would benefit from a closer examination. We have therefore referred the bill to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs and are grateful for the support given to that move by the opposition parties.

In turning to some of the more significant features of the bill, I deal first of all with the Security Appeals Tribunal which is to be abolished. Instead, the bill creates a security appeals division in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The Security Appeals Tribunal was established under the ASIO Act 1979. Its function is to review adverse or qualified security assessments of a person made by the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation. Such assessments are those which contain `any opinion or advice or any information that is or could be prejudicial to the interests of the person'. Security assessments are made by ASIO, typically at the request of the Commonwealth agency heads, on individuals whose work involves access to information or areas to which access is controlled or limited on security grounds.

The number of security assessments undertaken by ASIO has decreased in recent times, perhaps partly as a result of the fact that Commonwealth agencies are increasingly relying on their own security guidelines and are not requesting assessments from ASIO. For example, we understand that the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade makes security assessments of its own. The weakness here, however, is that the Security Appeals Tribunal does not have jurisdiction to review departmental security assessments.

The Parliamentary Joint Committee on the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation suggested that the proposal to incorporate the Security Appeals Tribunal into a new security division of the AAT `could provide an opportunity for a re-examination of the basis on which decisions concerning access can be reviewed and suggested that the Security Appeals Tribunal or the new division of the AAT could be given jurisdiction to hear appeals for any person aggrieved by an access decision made by the head of an agency'.

However, the government rejected this suggestion on the grounds that avenues for review by the Merit Protection and Review Agency and the Ombudsman already existed under the Public Service regulations. However, the Australian Democrats are concerned that none of these avenues has the ability to vary or to set aside decisions and to substitute their own decisions for those of the decision maker.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)—Order! It being 6.50 p.m., in accordance with sessional orders, I now proceed to the consideration of documents tabled earlier this day pursuant to a standing order.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the great challenges for Australian primary industry is to ensure that our products, especially wool and cotton, are able to compete in a world market which is being continually inundated by synthetics. That is why the work of the Cotton Research and Development Corporation is so very important, especially now that a whole range of synthetic clothing brands and types is coming out which is claimed to have some environmental value. For example, one can even purchase something called `Ecofleece'. It is a synthetic which is supposed to be made out of recycled plastic bottles. I do not quite understand how, but I am told that that is the case.

PARA.TAB: However, nothing is really comparable with a natural product for so many purposes. That is why, in terms of cotton, we have a lot to offer the world. Certainly Australian cotton is of a standard that can compete with the very finest grown anywhere in the world. Classers of cotton who are honest will say that Australian cotton is as good as anything grown in, for example, the United States.

One of the problems for cotton producers is that, whilst we produce the cotton here, often the fabric is spun overseas. A frequent complaint one hears about cotton is that it shrinks with use and washing. There is a reason for that. Frequently, especially in the case of T-shirts, the fabric is stretched prior to being used in the manufacturing process. So naturally with a bit of wear and washing the cotton tends to shrink. Unfortunately, it can sometimes give cotton garments a bad reputation.

I will take this opportunity to highlight the fact that there are efforts being made by Australian industry to improve the end product from our cotton. I particularly take this opportunity to highlight some of the work that is being done by an Australian company called the Bushco Farming Company. It is a supplier of high quality cotton garments, such as cotton knitted sweaters. This year, I understand that it is producing the cotton knitted sweaters that go into Ralph Lauren's polo range. So it really shows that Australian garments are some of the finest in the world. That is something about which we should all be proud.

Mark Coulton and the Bushco Farming Company are trying to control the entire process. Their objective is to control the growing of the cotton right through to its becoming part of the finished product. So they will be able to say, `The cotton in these pullovers here came from this row on this farm.' That means that they will have total quality control and will not be dependent on people overseas. They will be able to control the whole manufacturing process and guarantee a uniformally high quality product.

Another thing they are doing when they are not producing cotton knitted sweaters is producing cotton tampons that are free from chemical residue so that those who use them know that they are absolutely safe. That is also testimony to a certain degree of lateral thinking, which will pay off for Australia.

The work of the Cotton Research and Development Corporation is important. The work of private industry in trying to capitalise on what comes out of the corporation is also important. We need creative people who are going to be involved in farming and processing and in using the fabric to ensure that there is a long-term viable future in cotton for every producer. That long-term viable future in cotton means long-term profitability for this country.

I will conclude by saying that we should all spare a thought for some of our dry land cotton producers who will not be getting a crop this year. I particularly refer to some on the Darling Downs, who are very fine people. I have picked cotton with them in previous seasons, which has been a great joy to me. I only hope that the next season for those dry land farmers will be better. They deserve a good go. The cotton they produce earns export dollars. We will all be better off for it.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—A reading of the Tobacco Research and Development Council annual report indicates that the tobacco industry is in decline. The 1993-94 allocation to research and development projects has been reduced 16 per cent on the previous year. Next year, there will be a further decline in R&D funding.

PARA.TAB: Tobacco research is carried out at the Southedge research station at Mareeba and at the Ovens research station near Myrtleford in Victoria. The paper indicates that 45 per cent of tobacco growing costs are in employment, with irrigation, fertiliser and pest and disease control forming a further 13 per cent.

The tobacco industry has been a large employer of people in the Mareeba district, where it has poured something like $55 million into the town on a yearly basis. The decline of the industry has caused massive problems in Mareeba and, no doubt, Myrtleford, although I do not represent that area. Suffice it to say that the tobacco industry is one of the smaller primary industries that have been badly affected by the Uruguay Round and the subsequent reorganisation of the World Trade Organisation that occurred from 1 January this year.

The quotas were erroneously worked out. Even Senator McMullan is prepared to concede that the reductions of imports were worked out on the very high 1986-88 levels. Even Senator McMullan concedes that they were wrong. The consequence of that decision is that 11,184 tonnes of tobacco will come into Australia, which represents 70 to 80 per cent of Australia's total production. Therefore, it will be almost impossible to sustain the current number of farms.

In Queensland 50 per cent of tobacco farmers will be lost to the industry. Fortunately for the ones who remain an agreement has been worked out with the tobacco industry that it will maintain and enter into long-term contracts with the remaining tobacco farmers. The new tobacco plan involves all imports being duty free from 1 January 1995. That was the concession the government made to the tobacco industry for supporting the tobacco farmers. The local leaf content scheme and the tobacco industry stabilisation scheme will cease from 1 January 1995 and funding from manufacturers and state governments will cease. Australian manufacturers will contribute $10.8 million to a continuation of local supply and the state governments of Queensland, New South Wales and Victoria will also assist some of the manufacturers. Longer term agreements between growers and manufacturers will come into place.

It is sad to see an industry in demise. Nevertheless one has to face reality. The government has gone some way in removing tariffs that will assist the local cigarette manufacturing industry. Many people will benefit from GATT but it also has to be recognised that there is a down side for some of the smaller primary industries. Citrus is one and tobacco is another.
