SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to use the opportunity of this adjournment debate to address a controversial section of the Income Tax Assessment Act, namely section 264A. This deals with information notices. Honourable senators may recall that that section was inserted into the Income Tax Assessment Act during 1991. However, I again remind the Senate that its insertion was the subject at the time of some controversy and was not without some resistance from the coalition. There were serious concerns at the time about its constitutionality and the delegation of powers to the Commissioner of Taxation.

PARA.TAB: For example, the section allows the commissioner to issue an offshore information notice requesting a taxpayer to provide information held outside Australia relevant to the taxpayer's income tax assessment. It enables the commissioner to request information or documents where there is reason to believe that they are held outside Australia and are relevant. The consequence of a taxpayer refusing or failing to comply with such a notice is that the information or documents are not admissible in proceedings disputing the taxpayer's assessment unless the commissioner consents to their admission.
During the debate of Taxation Laws Amendment (Foreign Income) Bill 1990, which inserted a section, I expressed great concern about that provision. I think those comments are worth repeating tonight:

Another objectionable aspect of the bill is its evidentiary rule regarding offshore information notices. The coalition sought to remove this provision because it believed that there were other adequate provisions in the act to cope with section 264A situations. The opposition does not believe in giving draconian powers to government when there are adequate measures elsewhere in the act, especially in view of the constitutional and other issues that proposed section 264A raises.

Given that the onus of proof is already heavily on the taxpayer in dispute over tax assessment, why should the courts be prevented from examining all the evidence? Parliament has in fact amended the Acts Interpretation Act to enable courts to look at extrinsic aids interpretation of legislation. Why should we now seek to prevent the courts from reading all the relevant information? The doctrine of the separation of legislative and judicial powers does appear in this legislation to be going at something of a discount.

SPEECH.PARA: Recently the constitutionality of section 264A has been under scrutiny by the Federal Court of Australia. I feel somewhat vilified in this since I predicted that there were provisions including constitutionality. I remind the Senate that from my perspective I do not raise concerns about provisions in the bills just as debating points. My contribution is expressed in the hope that the government will listen and rectify the problems that the coalition raised. In the recent F. H. Faulding versus Federal Commissioner decision, the Federal Court held that the provisions of section 264A were not invalid under the constitution. But the court did set aside a section 264A notice on the basis that the notice was beyond the commissioner's power and invalid for uncertainty. In doing so, the court considers certain requests in the notice were beyond the commissioner's authority because they were either not relevant to the assessment or too widely drafted to actually be certain. Further, the court held that the request for Fauldings to require a third party to make a statement to the Australian Taxation Office was beyond the commissioner's power under section 264A.

PARA.TAB: While that decision can be appealed by the government, both the government and the Tax Office must take careful notice of what the Federal Court actually said. While the court upheld the constitutional validity of the section, which from my perspective was somewhat disappointing, the decision shows that the commissioner must be very careful in drafting section 264A notices. One can only take solace in the fact that the courts will not allow the section to be used carte blanche by the Commissioner of Taxation without reference to the specific powers given. However, I remind the Senate of a comment made by Simon Crean MP in a second reading speech in the House of Representatives:

SPEECH.PARA: The bill will authorise the Commissioner of Taxation to issue an offshore information notice in respect of information or documents held offshore. Where the information or documents are not supplied, there is no provision for a penalty or prosecution. Rather, the information or documents may not be used by a taxpayer as evidence to a dispute in an assessment. The approach adopted in this provision is similar to that taken in the United States and Canadian tax laws and is aimed at ensuring the timely provision of all the information and documents needed by the commissioner to get the full and correct picture of the transaction being examined. In view of the significance of such a provision, the operation of the proposed section 264A will be kept under review—
They are the operative words to which I am addressing my comments tonight because that review, I believe, is necessary—
. . . to ensure that its objectives are met and the rights of affected taxpayers are adequately protected.

Given that final statement, I strongly recommend that both the Treasurer and the Commissioner of Taxation take serious interest in the substance of the finding of the Faulding decision before the Federal Court. We must all be concerned when the commissioner is able to demand information from taxpayers where there are other options available to obtain this information. The Faulding decision is unlikely to be the last time that the courts will be required to examine section 264A. That section is likely to be the subject of further challenges in the future—on unconstitutional, mode of service, administrative law and privilege, such as privilege against self-incrimination and legal professional privilege—grounds.

PARA.TAB: It is opportune to remind the Senate that recently the Law Council of Australia raised concern about the potential erosion of legal professional privilege in a bill which is familiar to the minister at the table, the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley)—the Health and Other Services (Compensation) Bill 1994. Fortunately, the courts have repeatedly upheld on public policy grounds the concept of legal professional privilege as a very vital element in our justice system.

Therefore, I use the opportunity of this adjournment debate tonight to suggest to the government and the Commissioner of Taxation that they give further consideration to the necessity of having this at times repulsive or draconian section which has such a serious bearing on taxpayers' rights. I cannot miss this opportunity to again draw the attention of the Senate to the need to have this charter of taxpayers' rights not as an administrative document to adorn the walls of the Taxation Office but to be enshrined in legislation to give the full impact of the intent of an appropriate taxpayers' right the full legislative force that it really requires. I thank the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to speak on the appalling mess that this government has created in the forest industries. It has been very difficult today to find an opportunity to speak on this matter because so many people on this side of the chamber want to speak on it. Today question time was dominated by this matter, we had an urgency motion on the subject following question time, motions to take note of answers were taken up totally by the matter and then we had an MPI on it. A total of about three hours was taken up by the question of the future of Australia's forests.

PARA.TAB: We should not really be surprised that we now have a situation that is dominating the parliament, with the parliament now ringed by trucks and angry protesters. This is just another example, after 12 years, of incompetent government by the ALP.

Our parliament now resembles a medieval castle under siege as the various interest groups vie for space to protest about the actions of this government. It is basically focusing on the environment and the resources area. Out the front there are transport workers and forest workers. The Greens are coming, I hear, in big numbers. The airport noise protesters have come in and, of course, the farmers have been here for quite some time. It is a great tribute to Australian democracy that these people are so restrained because what is at stake is their very livelihood, the way of life that has gone on for many generations in many families.

I was born on the south coast of New South Wales and spent my first nine years in the town of Eden. Eden is a timber town. Some of my earliest memories are of being out on camps with forest workers as they chopped trees down and helped create our massive forest industries. All of that is now under threat by the way in which this government has managed the crisis.

Why has this come about? It is not a recent matter. Debate over the use of forests—what we protect, what we develop as a renewable resource—has been going on for decades in this country. You would have thought that after 12 years a government would have a plan worked out, a regional resource management plan that would keep environmentalists and people in the timber industry happy. But it does not, and now it is into crisis management.

Who is going to lead us out of this mess? We have Mr Beddall, who would have to be one of the most incompetent ministers in the lower house. Here in the Senate we have `Forrest Gump Faulkner', who is probably the most incompetent minister here, but he has a lot of competition. The ALP government stands guilty tonight of destroying the Australian timber industry as it reneges on agreements and promises made to the forest industry. Directly, there are 10,000 jobs at stake and, indirectly, far more, as the livelihood of many towns is totally dependent on this type of industry.

Forest and transport workers feel quite betrayed by this Labor government. They expressed that to me this morning as I was coming in. Recently I had an accident which has created great pain in my back. I mentioned to them on the way in that it was very difficult for people in pain coming into the parliament and we perhaps might take a jaundiced view of their issue if they kept making us do it. One of the workers replied to me, `Senator, your pain is temporary. In a few weeks time that will be gone. If we lose our jobs and our way of life our pain will be permanent.'

We have a blockade of this parliament. It is escalating as more people arrive. The anger can be seen on TV at night right around the nation. There are people terribly concerned by this failure of government. Not only are they ringing the parliament but they are in the parliament in big numbers at question time trying to focus this government's attention on this problem and trying to get it to come up with some sort of answer.

Mainstream opinion in Australia supports the view that old growth forests with environmental beauty and significance must be protected and preserved. No-one really argues with that proposition. We are all, as someone once coined it, light green. But what the dark greens, or the loony greens, must realise is that in a country that is very dependent on its primary resources we must allow an industry that works in a very responsible manner, as the timber industry does, on a renewable resource and on only a very small section of Australia's forests to flourish.

I think a lot of people in the cities have a misconception about the forests of Australia. One of the advantages we have as Mps is that we fly over a lot of Australia. As someone who used to teach geography, I look down on the forests of Australia from the air. As you fly from the Queensland border to the Victorian border down the spine of New South Wales and the Great Divide there is a massive forest all the way down and from the air it is almost untouched. People just do not realise that there is so much forest out there. There are small areas that are being logged and they are being logged in a responsible way.

I went back to my home town of Eden in 1986 and I went out to some of these areas that have been logged. Despite the greenie propaganda where you see all this desolate area, this area had a sign up that said `logged in 1972'. You looked up and you saw these tall trees that were about 60 to 70 feet high, and this was the regenerated growth. That area had been harvested, the country had earned wealth from it and now it is there ready to be cut again. There is a lot of propaganda around at the moment on what is being logged and what is not being logged.

We need not only to log the timber in these sorts of forests which are constantly being harvested every 20 years or so. This is an industry which can grow and expand. We can actually develop value added industries on top of this that create greater wealth in the country. But that will not happen if we lock up all the forests, which some people in this country want to do.

They do this with a very deceptive campaign. They try to make out—a lot of people in the country believe this—that what is being woodchipped is really good timber. Any person in the timber industry who woodchips good timber has to be mad because it is worth a lot more if you mill it and turn it into housing or furniture. What is being milled is the waste, the offcuts. I will put it to the greenies what happens to this stuff if you do not turn it into woodchip. You build it up in a great big heap and you set it on fire. Then a lot of pollution goes up into the air. I thought these people were concerned about the environment. The sorts of policies they want will create greater problems for the environment.

It will also create greater problems for the economy if they go ahead with what they do. Even though we have a lot of timber in this country and we log it and mill it, we are still importing $2.7 billion worth of timber. Mr Keating today had enormous trouble with his balance of payments. Part of this could be solved if he allowed this to go ahead and allowed this industry to expand so we could cut down our imports of goods.

People in particular towns are very concerned about the effects on their future of the government's current stance. Anyone who would want to invest at this stage in this industry, with its annual renewable licence system, would be mad. You could put millions of dollars into an industry and maybe next year this Labor government will change its mind and say that you cannot do it any more. All investment would go down the drain. Who would invest in that sort of situation? If they do not invest, whole towns will disappear. We are trying to keep rural and regional Australia there. People who want to live out there want to work there. We want them to stay there. These sorts of policies of the government will force these people into the cities because there is no work out there for them.

About two years ago the terrible case of Ivanhoe came up in this parliament. That town lost all its jobs because of what was done in that area. What did the people in that town do? They all went on the dole. They lost their viable industry, they lost their self-respect and they lost their way of life and their jobs. That was a disgrace.

The people in the town of Orbost have a great concern that this will happen to them. They are coming here. The whole town is coming to this parliament to demonstrate. What do we have to do to convince this government that its policies are wrong? The protest is there. People are angry. This government should change this policy immediately.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all I compliment Senator Tierney for an excellent contribution to the adjournment debate and for having highlighted some of the misinformation and propaganda in relation to the forestry issue. It started off as though the Minister for Resources, Mr Beddall, was looking somewhat sick and not really on top of his portfolio. As every day goes by, it becomes more clear that it is now Senator Faulkner and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) who are not on top of the issue.

PARA.TAB: Nothing highlights that more than the front-page photograph of today's Australian and the headline which states `Treeless hill, airstrip, saved from woodchipping'. What absolute nonsense. A coupe in my state of Tasmania which had been logged three months ago all of a sudden has been declared as having some important heritage value that the Prime Minister says needs to be protected. We also have an airstrip that needs to be protected. It is quite clear that the government has been relying on the propaganda of the extreme Green movement.

Tonight I want to comment on the very real effects that this sort of policy making has on the people of Australia. It is absolutely devastating to the families and the communities in regional Australia. I believe that the people of Australia are now learning with this forestry debate that the propaganda peddled by the environmentalists is not to be relied upon, is not truthful, contains misinformation and in fact is downright lacking in credit, as witnessed by the front-page photograph of today's Australian.

In my home state of Tasmania there have been 17 inquiries into the forest industry as to what ought be happening within Tasmania's forest industry. As though those 17 inquiries are not enough, we have since had Senator Faulkner's inquiry into the coupes in Tasmania about which there has been a lot of debate today. It is unfortunate that the extremist environmentalists have the ear of the media. That is now slowly being eroded, and I think they have shot themselves in the foot over this forest industry debate that is being waged right around Australia today.

Similarly, there is the debate in my state which now has prominence on the mainland concerning the draining of Lake Pedder. Lake Pedder, as it currently stands, is 240 square kilometres of pure rain water. In this drought affected country, I would have thought the prospect of draining that lake would not have been something that people would embrace. I say to people all around Australia who are so concerned about this forest industry that they should not be mistaken. The forest industry is the first industry. Next is Lake Pedder. Next will be the lakes, then iron ore mining and coalmining. Everything will be targeted by this extremist Green movement, which has no fixed agenda, which always moves its goalpost and which, if an item on its agenda is fulfilled, will add another two or three items onto that agenda.

With the creation of the new Lake Pedder, more and more platypuses have found a habitat in which to live. It may be of interest to those who peddle the `drain Lake Pedder' slogan that the draining of Lake Pedder would be responsible for the deaths of literally hundreds of platypuses in southern Tasmania. The water resource would not be there. They would starve to death and drown in the mud. So, if you want to `save' Lake Pedder, consider what you are going to do to the hundreds of platypuses that have now found a habitat there.

People should consider the four million trout that live within that lake and consider what will happen to the other industries that have now grown. For example, the Huon River used to be subject to flood. Apple growers in that region have in recent times been planting the flood plains of the Huon River with apple trees because they are now convinced that this new dam stops the flooding of the Huon River. If you were to remove that dam, what would occur? The floods would return and the industry of those apple farmers would be endangered.

What about the aquaculture industry that is at the foot of the Huon River? The salmon industry is now very concerned about the `siltation' and other effects the draining of Lake Pedder will have on its industry. Once again we have something which started as a nice, warm inner glow in those who live in the suburbia of this great country and who have not been told of the real human impact these decisions will have, including the environmental impact and the slaughter of platypuses that would result. Something else that is interesting is that, if you were to drain Lake Pedder by using the valves that exist, it would take two years. The other method would be to demolish the dam. Of course, the dam would just allow flood waters to race down the Huon River and cause all sorts of problems.

Tasmania was promised that, if it did not dam the Franklin, there would be a huge boost in ecotourism. What is the situation now in Tasmania with the Franklin River? In 1993 we had the tremendous number of 203 rafters down that river. That was the great economic boom to Tasmania that was promised by the Greens. They promised thousands of jobs. We got 203 rafters down the river. What is interesting is considering where rafters now go if they want to raft in Tasmania. They go to the Hydro Electric Commission establishments which can control the flow of water. The Hydro Electric Commission, by agreement, releases sufficient waters for a sufficient period to allow the rafters to enjoy the rafting experience. So it is the Hydro Electric Commission that is combining with tourism to present and provide the rafting experience. That is the way we ought to be running our environment—by having sustainable developments, developments that are environmentally friendly.

One thing should be remembered in this debate, and that is the absolutely chronically sad thing the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) said today. He said that all he has to consider is the environmental issues. I would have thought that any minister in any government not only would be concerned about particular issues in their portfolio but also would introduce that most important of dynamics, the human element—that is, what the human effect would be of a certain decision. But the minister says, `No, I see it in only environmental terms.'

If the minister sees the administration of his portfolio only in environmental terms, clearly he is not fit for the job. He ought to resign. The task of the minister is to also take into account the human dynamic, and the human dynamic has not been considered by the minister for the environment; it has not been considered by the green movement in this absolute charade in this forestry debate; nor has it been considered by those who are peddling the draining of Lake Pedder. If the Greens, the Democrats and this minister for the environment want any credibility, they will have to start talking about linking in the human dynamic with the environmental dynamic. They ought to get the two together, get the proper balance, and then they will achieve credibility and respect. I am sure that Australia will then be a lot better placed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not normally speak on the adjournment, but this evening I am going to take a few minutes of the Senate's time. Today something happened that I never thought I would see in this place. Finally, something that I have been looking for for seven years has come about. During question time today, Senator Evans, in answering the first question, admitted that drought knocks around the economy of Australia. Over seven years I listened to Senator Button, when he was Leader of the Government in the Senate, blame the Fraser government every day for what he thought was the excessive foreign debt that was left when the Fraser government went out of government in 1983. That debt stood at $23.383 billion. Senator Bolkus can pretend to sleep as much as he likes.
—I am listening to you.
—Okay. There are plenty of times when I wish Senator Button was back here.
—So do we.
—I must acknowledge Senator Bolkus's interjection. No doubt he believes that former Senator Button should still be Leader of the Government in the Senate.
—No, not that.

—Too late, Senator Bolkus. You interjected and I have picked you up on it. Over those years, every time there was an economic question, Senator Button would finish up or start by blaming the Fraser government for the deficit of $23.383 billion. Time and again I would yell at him, `What about the eastern states drought?', but he would always turn a deaf ear to my interjections and not once did he take any notice of them. And so it went on.

PARA.TAB: Senator Evans, when he could not handle answering the economic question from Senator Hill today, called out, `And don't forget we have had a drought.' I certainly did not expect that to come, but it came all of a sudden today.
Let us look at what the Treasurer (Mr Willis) had to say on 31 August 1994 regarding the effects of the drought. Amongst other things, the journalist asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Do you still feel that there is no need to take special allowance in forecasting for the effects of the drought?
Mr Willis answered:

Obviously the drought now is clearly of more serious dimensions than it appeared it would have been at the time we made the budget forecast. So that certainly is a change. On the other hand, it is also true that the world economy has picked up. At least the prospects for growth in the world economy have picked up quite markedly from where they were just seven months ago, so those are offsetting factors in terms of growth forecasts and there is nothing in this and nothing that is happening currently that would want to make us change our budget forecasts in terms of the overall growth of 4 1/2 percent in 1994-95.
The journalist further asked:
Is there danger, Treasurer, that with the drought taking grip that we will be exporting too less, to pay not enough to pay for our imports. So they are coming in under investment.
Mr Willis replied:
Obviously there is going to be an impact on exports there. Of course, some of that was factored in anyway in the budget forecast—
I do not know how—

As I have just said, it is more serious now. On the other hand, the pick up in the world economy will give us better prices, better volumes perhaps and, therefore, recover some of that ground maybe. We do not know how that is going to pan out, but there is nothing that would lead one at this stage to make any changes in that forecast.
That was from a press release of 31 August 1994. The drought had already taken grip of eastern Australia; the writing was certainly on the wall.

PARA.TAB: The government having not recognised that the last budget of the Fraser government was interfered with by the drought, let me read you a few figures. The net foreign debt in 1982-83, as I have already quoted, was $23.383 billion. In 1992-93, under the Labor government, it had grown to $168.787 billion. In 1993-94, it had gone down to $162.727 billion. Looking at the quarterly figures, in September 1993 the figure stood at $172.9 billion; in June of that year, it stood at $162.727 billion; and in September of 1994-95—the latest figures available—it stood at $160.258 billion.

Senator Evans also claimed today—and I have not seen the Hansard—that the net foreign debt was reduced recently by $22 billion. I think he quoted that figure. These figures show that 12 months ago, if you take the last figure of September 1994, it has been reduced by only $12 billion. He did not claim that the government was responsible for that reduction. He led us to believe, or read into his answer, that the government did take responsibility for that. I know exactly how that $12 billion was reduced: by the appreciation of the Australian dollar—and, I am afraid, by nothing else. I would like Senator Evans tomorrow to explain better how that $22 billion was reduced—if I have got him right.

We are now at the situation where we will have a budget deficit of $28 billion. Of course, the government has said—or Senator Evans did, anyhow; whether he reflects the government's views in this place or not, I do not know—and after all Senator Bolkus said he would prefer Senator Button back in here—

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not. I wouldn't mind him back, I said, but not as leader.

—If you call out loud enough, Hansard may pick up your interjection. That was an interesting interjection. Senator Evans has finally admitted that the drought can affect the economy. That is something that we farmers know every day, but I did not think I would ever see the day that Senator Evans would admit it. You must admit, Mr President, that the drought does affect Australia and affects it very badly. Now that Senator Evans has claimed that that is what knocked the budget around for the government this year and caused the deficit to blow out the $28 billion, he can finally get around to admitting that the disastrous 1982 drought of the eastern states, unfortunately followed by a drought in the west in 1983, certainly knocked the last Fraser budget around. Perhaps even this government will admit to Mr Fraser leaving things in a better situation, as I have always claimed he had.

To provide local members of all Parties with details of Government programs.
To co-ordinate the distribution of detailed information on Government policies and programs from the information units of various departments to the local media.
To monitor local media to provide media summaries.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 10 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Minister aware of public concerns about explicit references to violent and/or sexual activity in recorded music available in Australia.
(2) Has the Minister investigated the need for, and feasibility of, a classification system for recorded music; if so, what conclusions were drawn; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) This issue has been monitored for the last five years by Commonwealth, State and Territory Ministers with responsibility for censorship. While there has been community concern about the easy accessibility of sexually explicit and violent lyrics to children, the overall level of complaint to Ministers has been small. The States and Territories have reported only a handful of complaints, while representations to the Minister (18) and the Office of Film and Literature Classification (10) in the last six months are also small.

(2) The possibility of a classification system for recorded audio music was once again considered by Ministers at their 3 November 1994 meeting. It was agreed that the number of complaints continued to be relatively small and that the matter should remain under review. It was also agreed that as classification of such material is a State matter, it was open for any jurisdiction to implement its own scheme, if it wished.

The recent representations received by the Attorney-General and the Office of Film and Literature Classification relate to concerns about the easy accessibility of sexually explicit and violent lyrics to children. The Australian Record Industry Association is reported to estimate that such material amounts to one-quarter of 1 per cent of the thousands of albums released in Australia each year.

I am advised that the larger distribution companies, with the support of the Australian Record Industry Association, label possibly offensive material to warn people about the contents of some audio recordings. I am further advised that the labels are applied to the one-quarter of 1 per cent which contain sexually explicit and violent lyrics. Retailers are considered to be generally responsible in the distribution of such material to children.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 5 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the number of families separated by postings that are incompatible for any reason. Can these be expressed in percentage of total military population, percentage by unit—specifically Cavalry units 2/14 Light Horse, 3/4 Cavalry Regt, 2 Cavalry Regt, School of Armour and Cavalry Regt at Puckapunyal—and the reasons for these separations, for example, compassionate, disabled child, education of children, spouse's career progress, etcetera.
(2) From the above data, please extrapolate the number of these separations that are condoned by the military and supported by the financial category of married—separated with full conditions.
(3) What are the processes of posting members of the Australian Defence Force (ADF), and what is the criteria which impact on specific postings for members.

(4) Please identify whether or not the military would post a member to join a spouse who has been transferred in the course of their employment being cognisant of the fact that the military often expects a spouse's employer to facilitate transfer, for example, public servants, serving ADF member.

(5) Are the guidelines for separated married ADF members congruent with conditions for other public servants in the Commonwealth Government in terms of allowances and conditions, for example, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, the Customs Department and the Taxation Department.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Unfortunately, it is not possible to identify from personnel databases the number of families separated by Service postings, and the reason for separation. Such statistics could only be obtained by conducting a survey, or census, of all military units. However, based upon information gained as part of the ADF Families Mobility and Dislocation Study, a survey of 1200 ADF members taken in March 1993 revealed that 7.8 percent of ADF parents were separated from their families for Service reasons. Of that number 49.1 percent (3.8 percent of all ADF parents) were currently on an unaccompanied posting, that is a posting of 12 months or longer. Altogether, during the entire course of their careers, 6.3 percent of the surveyed members reported having had at least one unaccompanied posting with one half of 1 percent having reported three or more. On average the surveyed members reported 1.12 separations per year of four weeks or longer in duration and, on average, two and a half months per year of Service-related separation.

(2) It is not possible to accurately provide the answer to this question for the reason stated previously. However, as a guide, during Financial Year 1993/94 the Navy averaged 2206 members in receipt of separation allowance each payday, Army has advised that on a randomly selected pay day, 452 Army members were in receipt of separation allowance and the Air Force has indicated that approximately 170 members are in receipt of separation allowance at any one time.

(3) Members of the Australian Defence Force (ADF) are posted to meet specific Service requirements. Those requirements can be generated by establishment changes, role and task changes, vacancies caused for a variety of reasons, changes in personnel circumstances, invalidity or death of members. Essentially, the posting process is one by which the Services allocate personnel to fulfil their assigned functions, roles and tasks. Overall guidance for the posting of members to vacancies is provided by the Chief of Defence Force's Policy Directive Number 19. The essential elements of that Directive (subject to Service exigencies) are that members are to receive six months notice of posting, three years in a post and where possible, six years in location. There are three prime considerations for the posting of personnel. Firstly, there is the Service requirement to allocate appropriately qualified members, in terms of rank, qualifications and motivation, to vacancies. Secondly, the development of members' careers to ensure their satisfactory progression to meet the future requirements of the Service. Thirdly, the reconciliation of Service requirements and career development with a member's personal aspirations and circumstances.

(4) With regard to the posting of members to facilitate a spouse's employment requirements, the Services endeavour to collocate spouses provided a vacancy exists in the area required and no other Service member will be disadvantaged. However, Service requirements will take priority.

(5) The entitlements of ADF married members who proceed on posting within Australia without their families are dependant on the length of posting and whether the member is categorised `married separated'. All members, irrespective of rank, are entitled to reunion travel every three months, and may receive subsidised housing in the location where the family resides. Members categorised `married separated' attract additional benefits: separation allowance and a waiver of rations and quarters charges. Furthermore, members posted for a period of at least six months are entitled to a limited removal which covers personal effects and a motor vehicle. In the Public Sector, for an unaccompanied Australian Public Service officer proceeding on temporary transfer, in addition to the normal entitlements and in recognition that the officer is required to maintain a second household, the officer's contribution towards rental or boarding accommodation is waived and meal allowances are paid. Non-Senior Executive Service officers are entitled to a reunion visit every three months with Senior Executive Service officers being entitled to a reunion visit every month (but certain conditions apply).

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, on notice, on 13 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the amendments made in recent years to the Corporations law to overcome the difficulties revealed by the use of off-balance sheet vehicles in corporate structures during the 1980s and the extended definition given to subsidiaries in the Corporations Law:

(1) In the proposed NRMA de-mutualisation, was a company NRMA Holdings Ltd formed by NRMA officers and a lawyer for the NRMA and introduced on 4 August as a member of the NRMA, pursuant to resolutions of the NRMA board.

(2) If NRMA Holdings Ltd is a subsidiary of NRMA Ltd, is not the proposed demutualisation whereby NRMA Holdings will acquire the interests of the members of the NRMA (its holding company) based on a breach of the prohibition in s.185 of the Corporations Law (which prohibits a subsidiary becoming a member of its holding company); if so, what action is the Australian Securities Commission proposing to take to enforce the law.

(3) If NRMA Holdings is not a subsidiary of NRMA Ltd and the NRMA officers holding shares in NRMA Holdings own their shares beneficially and not on trust for the NRMA, has that fact been disclosed to NRMA members in the prospectus for the demutualisation.

(4) If NRMA Holdings is not a subsidiary of NRMA Ltd, what is the point of the Government's corporate law reforms if they are so easily avoided, on a matter as fundamental as the definition of a subsidiary and s.185, simply by having company officers form a separate entity for corporation self-acquisition.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) I am advised that:-

(a) the prospectus for the NRMA float states that NRMA Holdings Ltd was admitted as a member of NRMA Ltd on 4 August 1994 and as a member of NRMA Insurance Ltd on 16 August 1994, by a resolution of the boards of each of those companies.

(b) the prospectus also states that the directors of NRMA Holdings Ltd are Don Mackay, Ray Kirby, Maree Callaghan, Peter Jack and Ray Willing all of whom are members of NRMA Ltd, and variously, directors or officers of certain NRMA companies.
(c) the prospectus further states that the subscriber members of NRMA Holdings Ltd are Don Mackay, Ray Kirby, Ray Willing, Helen Conway and Gregory Batemen.

(d) all of the above mentioned persons, except Mr Batemen, are also, variously, directors or officers of certain NRMA group companies. Mr Bateman is a partner with the Sydney law firm of Abbot Tout which is solicitor to NRMA Holdings Ltd.

(2) The question whether NRMA Holdings Ltd is to be properly characterised as a subsidiary ultimately rests upon the existence of various facts, particularly the matters dealt with in section 46 and 47 of the Corporations Law relating to the existence of actual `control' of the board of directors and the shares in NRMA Holdings Ltd. The mere existence of certain common directors between one company and another does not, of itself, necessarily imply control by the one over the other. Given that aspects of the NRMA float are currently before the Federal Court, it would not be appropriate for the Government to offer legal advice on the detailed legal and administrative arrangements for the NRMA demutualisation process. The honourable Senator's question has been drawn to the attention of the Australian Securities Commission which is continuing to monitor aspects of the NRMA float, and is assisting the Court in its deliberations. I would, therefore, expect that if any matters requiring further action come to the attention of the ASC, then that action will be taken.

(3) As to whether NRMA Holdings is a subsidiary of NRMA Ltd, see the answer to question (2) above. As to the possible existence of any trust relationship applying to shares held by NRMA officers in NRMA Holdings, I am advised that the prospectus does not disclose the existence of any trust arrangements involving the shares in NRMA Holdings held by the subscriber members.

(4) As to whether NRMA Holdings is a subsidiary of NRMA Ltd, see the answer to question (2) above. Generally, in regard to ownership by a company of its own shares I note that the Simplification Task Force established by the Attorney-General to review the Corporations Law has recently released for public comment a proposal to amend the share capital rules of that Law. One of the proposals involves replacing the present self ownership rules in section 185 with provisions that depend for their operation on actual control over the votes attaching to company shares. Specifically, the proposal would not permit an entity that is controlled by a company to acquire a `relevant interest', as defined under the Law, in a share in the controlling company. In addition, the proposal would require a company that acquired control of an entity that has a relevant interest in a share in that company to either end its control of the controlled entity within 12 months, or, within that same period, to cause the controlled entity to dispose of its relevant interest in a share in the controlling company. It is further proposed that during the period in which the self ownership exists the voting rights attaching to the shares in the controlling company will not be able to be exercised. The Task Force is seeking comments on these proposals from interested parties by 17 February 1995.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 18 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) What was the cost of computer hardware and software purchased by the department for the 1991-92, 1992-93 and 1993-94 financial years, and what is the breakdown of the projections for the 1994-95 financial year.
(2) What is the average lead time needed between the decision to purchase, the order and the installation of computer hardware and software.
(3) What is the average life of the department's computer hardware and software before it is considered obsolete or superseded by newer, more advanced models.

(4) What funds were returned to the department through selling obsolete computer hardware and software in the 1991-92, 1992-93 and 1993-94 financial years, and what is the breakdown of the projections for the 1994-95 financial year.

(5) What was the cost of facsimile machines purchased by the department for the 1991-92, 1992-93 and 1993-94 financial years, and what is the breakdown of the projections for the 1994-95 financial year.
(6) What is the average lead time needed between the decision to purchase, the order and the installation of facsimile machines.
(7) What is the average life of the department's facsimile machines before they are considered obsolete or superseded by newer, more advanced models.

(8) What funds were returned to the department through selling obsolete facsimile machines in the 1991-92, 1992-93 and 1993-94 financial years, and what is the breakdown of the projections for the 1994-95 financial year.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1)—(3) I am advised that the question is not in a form which would make the provision of meaningful replies possible. For example, computer hardware comes in a number of forms and the costs range from small to very large amounts, depending on the hardware in question. It would not be possible, without an expenditure of resources which could not be justified, to extract records of minor purchases.

Similarly, software may at one extreme be very inexpensive, and purchased over the counter, or at the other be very costly and acquired through major tendering processes. Much software may not be purchased at all, in the sense of legal ownership transferring from the producer to the Commonwealth, even though there is Commonwealth expenditure. Concepts like average lead times for decisions to purchase, and average life of hardware and software are imprecise and meaningless in this context.
In the circumstances, I am unable to authorise the expenditure of money and effort involved in trying to assemble the information.

(4), (8) The department disposes of equipment which it no longer needs in a variety of ways, including by tender, auction and by trade-in, in some instances by item, in other by lot. It is not possible, therefore, to answer this question in its current form.

(5) The department maintains its records in a form which would not enable it, without an expenditure of resources which would not be justified, to establish these particular figures for years before the most recent financial year with the necessary degree of reliability.
The figure for 1993-94, based on a survey of functional areas which undertake such purchasing in Canberra, State Regional Offices and overseas posts is $290,928.

(6) The department does not keep records in the form which would enable it to answer this question. Machines can be, and usually are, purchased and installed very quickly after the need is identified.

(7) The department does not keep records which would enable it to answer this question. Facsimile machines are usually either replaced when they cease to function adequately, or moved to an area of lower priority when their capacity becomes insufficient.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 7 November 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the Federal Court judgment that the NRMA prospectus for de-mutualisation was misleading or deceptive:
(1) Did the Treasurer (Mr Willis) state in Parliament on 23 August 1994 that de-mutualisation was a good thing.

(2) Did Mr Donald Gordon Mackay, a senior partner at Sly and Weigall and the NRMA President, state when interviewed for the 7.30 Report by ABC TV on 14 October 1994 that the prospectus for de-mutualisation had the support of the Government and the Australian Securities Commission (ASC).
(3) Does the Government accept the truth of Mr Mackay's claim.
(4) Is the Deputy Chairman of the ASC, Ms Lynn Susan Ralph, one of the NRMA directors involved in approving the prospectus found to be misleading or deceptive under the Trade Practices Act.
(5) Is Ms Anna Booth, a director of the Commonwealth Bank, one of the NRMA directors involved in approving the prospectus found to be misleading or deceptive under the Trade Practices Act.

(6) Is Mr Mark Douglas Irving Burrows, a solicitor and corporate adviser, and President of the Corporation and Securities Commission, one of the NRMA directors involved in approving the prospectus found to be misleading or deceptive under the Trade Practices Act.
(7) Is it also prohibited conduct under the Corporations Law to put out a prospectus which is misleading or deceptive.

(8) Was Ms Ralph correctly reported in the Sydney Morning Herald of 15 October 1994 as advising fellow NRMA board members on 13 October 1994 that the adverse Federal Court findings were just `technicalities' and that the board should press on with using the votes already cast under the misleading or deceptive prospectus.
(9) On 14 October 1994, did Mr Justice Gummow order that proxies cast under the misleading or deceptive prospectus could not be used for any purpose other than to adjourn the general meetings.

(10) Did the ASC consider the joint opinion of Mr John Garnsey QC and Mr Brian Camilleri in relation to the NRMA de-mutualisation which was provided to Ms Jane Singleton, Ms Dawn Fraser and Mr Richard Talbot and tabled in the House of Representatives on 21 September 1994; if so, could the Minister table documents relating to the ASC's consideration of that legal opinion.

(11)(a) Did the ASC receive and/or consider any representations from any Directors or Management of NRMA Ltd or NRMA Insurance Ltd concerning the proposed NRMA de-mutualisation or prospectus prior to the issue of the prospectus; (b) who made the representations, and what were they; and (c) what consideration and/or decision did the ASC give or make in respect of these representations.
(12) Why did the ASC take no independent action to investigate complaints by dissident NRMA directors and members.
(13) Will the Minister table all advisings to or by the ASC relating to the ASC's consideration of the NRMA de-mutualisation and the misleading or deceptive prospectus.

(14) Does the Government consider it appropriate that persons involved in approving a prospectus which was misleading or deceptive should continue to hold directorships in Commonwealth-owned companies or positions involved in corporate regulation.

(15) Is it an offence under the Corporations Law to make a false or misleading statement in a document required for the purposes of the law; if so, is any investigation being conducted by the ASC or consideration given by the Director of Public Prosecutions as to whether offences were committed in relation to the NRMA prospectus.

(16) Are directors under a duty to act honestly in their role as fiduciaries and are they under a liability to recompense their company for losses suffered through breach of that duty, if so, will the ASC be investigating whether there are grounds for seeking recovery from the sponsoring directors, on behalf of NRMA members, of the $15 million wasted on the misleading or deceptive NRMA prospectus.

(17) Given the recent disclosures about the retainer paid to Mr Tony Hartnell, by his former partners at Allen Allen and Hemsley, while he was serving as Chairman of the ASC and the conflicts of duty and interest disclosed by the NRMA situation, will the Government now introduce amending legislation to ensure there are no conflicts of duty or interest by requiring that no person may hold a position with the ASC while serving as a director of a company or be in receipt of any remuneration other than his or her official emoluments.
(18) Is it acceptable for dissenting members of mutual societies attempting to keep their management honest to have to put their homes on the line for legal costs.

(19) Given the apparent failure of the ASC to act of its own volition in the NRMA case, has the Government given consideration to transferring some funds from the ASC budget to earmarked legal aid to assist dissenting shareholders and directors in checking malpractice in corporate governance.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Acting Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.
(2) I have no knowledge of any statements that may have been made by Mr Mackay.

(3) No. It is not a matter for the Government to support a particular prospectus of a non-Government company. I am advised by the ASC that it has expressed no views either for or against demutualisation. The Corporations Law (the Law) does not provide a role for the ASC in supporting or failing to support any particular corporate activity as described in a prospectus. The prospectus for NRMA Holdings Limited (Holdings) specifically states, as required by paragraph 1021(14)(c) of the Law, that the ASC takes no responsibility as to the contents of the prospectus.
(4) I am advised that the prospectus was issued by Holdings and is signed by each director of that company as required by the Law. Ms Ralph is not a director of Holdings.
(5) As noted at (4), I am advised that the prospectus was issued by Holdings and is signed by each director of that company. I am also advised that Ms Booth is not a director of Holdings.

(6) As noted at (4), I am advised that the prospectus was issued by Holdings and is signed by each director of that company. I am also advised that Mr Burrows is not a director of Holdings. Mr Burrows is a former Convenor of the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee, having retired from that position on 30 July 1994.

(7) Section 995 of the Law provides that a person shall not, in or in connection with any dealing in securities, including any prospectus issued or notice published, in relation to securities, engage in conduct that is misleading or deceptive or likely to mislead or deceive.

Subsection 996(1) of the Law provides that a person must not authorise or cause the issue of a prospectus in relation to securities of a corporation: (a) in which there is a material statement that is false or misleading; or (b) from which there is a material omission.

It is a defence to a prosecution for a contravention of subsection 996(1) if it is proved that the defendant, after making such inquiries (if any) as were reasonable, had reasonable grounds to believe, and did until the time of issue of the prospectus believe that the statement was true and not misleading or the omission was not material; or where there was an omission from the prospectus that the omission was inadvertent.

(8) I am advised by Ms Ralph that the comments attributed to her in the article appearing in the Sydney Morning Herald on 15 October 1994 are inaccurate, have been cited out of context and draw an inaccurate sense of her attitude towards the Federal Court judgment.

I am advised that Ms Ralph has indicated that the comments attributed to her were not made in reference to the Court's judgment at all, but rather to whether the judgment had any substantial impact on the board's original decision that de-mutualisation is in the best interests of the members and the NRMA. In that respect I understand that Ms Ralph did assert her belief that the finding did not alter her support for the de-mutualisation of the Association. She does recall having used the word `technical'. This was not, however, in reference to the specific findings of the Court.
Ms Ralph has given her assurance that she has and will always have the highest respect for the Court.

(9) I am advised that on 13 October 1994 Mr Justice Gummow handed down his decision and made a number of orders. On 14 October 1994 the orders were amended, in part to deal with the proxy votes that had been cast. The amended orders provided that both NRMA Limited (the Association) and NRMA Insurance Limited (Insurance) were restrained without leave of the Court from proceeding with any business at the respective meetings of members to be held on 19 October 1994 and from relying upon any of the proxies obtained or given in respect of that meeting, other than by taking such steps as were necessary or appropriate to adjourn the respective meetings. The decision of Mr Justice Gummow is the subject of an application for leave to appeal to the Full Court of the Federal Court.

(10) I am advised that a copy of the opinion of Messrs Garnsey QC and Camilleri, Counsel for Mr Talbot and Ms Fraser, was first provided to the ASC on 22 September 1994. This was the same date on which the initial application was made to, and proceedings filed in, the Federal Court by those directors of the Association.

I am also advised that the matters raised in that opinion were the subject of oral advice only, which was to the effect that grounds had not been made out to support regulatory action by the ASC. Accordingly, there are no copies of advisings to be tabled.
(11)(a) I am advised that the ASC did receive and consider the said representations.

(b) I am also advised that the prospectus was registered on 23 August 1994. Prior to that date, senior executives of the NRMA and their solicitors sought discussions with, and provided background information to, officers of the ASC Regional Office in New South Wales. Formal applications for relief from various provisions of the Law were subsequently made by solicitors advising the issuers. The substantive effect of those applications was to permit the announcement of, and debate about, restructuring prior to registration of the prospectus. Relief was also sought to enable voting, election and application forms to be sent to persons at various stages of the restructuring which were not physically attached to the registered prospectus.
(c) As required by the Law, the ASC considered the applications. It granted the relief subject to conditions in formal instruments which are published in the Gazette and recorded in the ASC Digest.

(12) I am advised that the ASC has independently considered and assessed every complaint received from members of the Association and Insurance and from any director of either company. I am also advised that the ASC did not investigate those complaints because the ASC formed the opinion that they did not disclose reasonable grounds to suspect a breach of the Law.

(13) I am advised that the ASC did not consider the proposed de-mutualisation process in detail for the reason that there appeared to be no issue about its legality. Accordingly there are no legal advisings to or by the ASC on this matter. In relation to the prospectus, the ASC has acted only to register that document. It did so because it had not formed the view that there was anything in the prospectus that was false, misleading or omitted. Accordingly there are also no legal advisings to or by the ASC on this matter.

(14) The decision of Mr Justice Gummow is an interlocutory decision and I am advised that the Federal Court heard an application for leave to appeal against that decision on 6 December 1994 and that leave to appeal is reserved. I am also advised that the Court heard argument on the substantive grounds for appeal, should leave be allowed, and that the Court has reserved its decision on this matter also.

In these circumstances, the doctrine of sub judice dictates that I should refrain from making any comment on the correctness of the decision or the interpretation of it. For the same reason it would be inappropriate for the Government to speculate in the manner in which it has been invited to do so by this question.
(15) Subsection 995(3) provides that a breach of section 995 of the Corporations Law, which is the Corporations Law equivalent of section 52 of the Trade Practices Act, is not an offence.
However, it is an offence to breach the provisions of section 996 of the Corporations Law, which provides as follows:
"(1)A person must not authorise or cause the issue of a prospectus in relation to securities of a corporation:

TAB.TAB: (a)in which there is a material statement that is false or misleading; or
(b)from which there is a material omission

PARA.TAB: (2)It is a defence to a prosecution for a contravention of subsection (1) if it is proved:

TAB.TAB: (b)that the defendant, after making such inquiries (if any) as were reasonable, had reasonable grounds to believe, and did until the time of the issue of the prospectus believe, that the statement was true and not misleading or the omission was not material; or
(c)where there was an omission from the prospectus—that the omission was inadvertent."

PARA.TAB: As noted at (14), the doctrine of sub judice dictates that it would be inappropriate for me to make any comment on the correctness of the decision or the issue of whether offences were committed in relation to the NRMA prospectus.

(16) A director is under a duty, imposed by subsection 232(2) of the Corporations Law, to act honestly in the exercise of his or her powers and the discharge of the duties of his or her office. A director in breach of that duty may be subject to civil liability to recompense the company for losses suffered through that breach. However, as noted at (14), in relation to this particular matter, the doctrine of sub judice dictates that it would be inappropriate for me to make any comment on the correctness of the decision or the interpretation of it. For the same reason it would be inappropriate for the Government to speculate in the manner in which it has been invited to do so by this question.

(17) If Governments are going to be in a position to appoint appropriately qualified people to serve on its regulatory bodies, they need to be able to attract people with the right kind of experience. In the case of the corporate regulator, the ASC, that includes business people who are able to bring the hard edge of business experience to their role within the Commission. For this reason there are also advantages in such appointees continuing with their business role in some way.

Indeed that was clearly foreseen by the Parliament in enacting the disclosure provisions of Part 7 the Australian Securities Commission Act 1989. The effect of those provisions is that members of the ASC must disclose their interests to the Commission and abstain from participating in any of the deliberations of the Commission relating to those interests.
On the advice I have from the Chairman of the ASC, that is exactly what has happened in the case of the NRMA—Ms Ralph has not participated in any ASC deliberations on the float.

I note that the conflict of interest provisions of the Act that governed the activities of the predecessor of the ASC, namely the National Companies and Securities Commission Act, enacted by the Fraser Liberal Government in 1979, expressly contemplates that members of the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC) will continue to be directors of bodies corporate, notwithstanding their appointment to the NCSC.

The ASC is not the only current regulatory body, the members of which may retain their positions as directors of bodies corporate. As to State and Territory regulatory bodies, section 110 of the Independent Commission against Corruption Act 1988 of New South Wales, for example, expressly makes provision for officers of the Commission to continue to hold positions in corporations. In the case of the Securities and Investments Board of the United Kingdom, the UK securities regulator, almost all of its members retain public company directorships at the same time as their membership of the board.
Thus the ASC is not alone in the approach taken to the continued involvement of its members in the business community.

Nevertheless, a review is presently being conducted of the appropriateness and adequacy of the disclosure requirements presently applying to members and senior staff of the ASC for consideration by the Ministerial Council for Corporations.
(18) I am not aware of the means by which dissenting members of the Association financed their legal costs. I would expect that those members would have sought their own legal advice in this matter.

(19) No. As noted at (14), the doctrine of sub judice dictates that it would be inappropriate for me to make any comment on the correctness of Mr Justice Gummow's decision or the interpretation of it.

This is a detailed area of the Law, and its application is in a complicated factual situation. Exercises of judgement as to the adequacy of statements are involved, rather than straight assessments of the factual accuracy of asserted statements.
It is thus appropriate to await the outcome of the application for leave to appeal and, if leave is granted, the appeal, before assessing any alleged failure by the ASC.
The Government does not contemplate making any such budgetary transfer.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 7 November 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the procedure proposed to be adopted in the NRMA de-mutualisation:
(1) Was the NRMA de-mutualisation planned to proceed by a 75 per cent majority voting for a special resolution to deprive all members (bar one) of all their rights of corporate membership.
(2) Is the required majority under the takeovers code for compulsory acquisition of shares of a minority based on a majority vote in excess of 90 per cent.

(3) Does the NRMA procedure expose a loophole in the takeovers code whereby a company can be effectively taken over by a 75 per cent majority voting to strip existing shares of all voting rights and approving the issue of a new class of voting shares to the 75 per cent controlling majority.
(4) Will the Government consider amending the Corporations Law to require a 90 per cent majority before any minority members or shareholders are deprived of membership or voting rights.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Acting Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) No. I am advised that if the resolution were supported by 75 per cent of the members present and voting, members could retain corporate membership through shares in NRMA Holdings Limited (Holdings) if they chose to do so. Holdings would have controlled all the assets of NRMA Limited (the Association) and NRMA Insurance Limited (Insurance).

(2) No. Chapter 6 of the Corporations Law is the part of the current legislation that is often referred to as the `takeovers code'. Under the provisions of Chapter 6, a person who has served a Part A statement or who has caused a take-over announcement to be made can be required to purchase shares in the same class of shares subject to the takeover once the number of shares to which that person becomes entitled represents not less than 90% of the shares included in the class.

The compulsory acquisition provisions of Chapter 6 are triggered by the offeror's entitlement to shares reaching the requisite percentage, and not by a percentage vote of the shareholders of the target company.

(3) No. The Corporations Law provides for various mechanisms by which a change of control of a company may be effected. Chapter 6 is one such regime. Chapter 6, however, only governs the change of control of a company where the change is effected by way of acquisition of shares in that company. The proposed structure of the NRMA restructuring was not a `takeover' to which the provisions of Chapter 6 could apply.

The courts have recognised that other legislative measures including merger or amalgamation by scheme of arrangement, selective capital reductions and change to the constituent documents (being the memorandum and articles of association) of a company, may be alternative means of effecting a change of control.

However, in relation to each of these measures, a member has a statutory right to apply for relief under section 260 of the Corporations Law where the affairs of the company are being conducted in a manner that is oppressive or unfairly prejudicial to, or unfairly discriminatory against, a member or members, or contrary to the interests of the members as a whole.

(4) No. As stated above, there are various means whereby change of control of a company may occur, each of which serve different purposes. Members of companies who feel aggrieved about a particular circumstance have remedies available to them to seek relief.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 8 November 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the 1992 report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training entitled The Literacy Challenge which stated that the changes in the way in which reading and writing are taught have not achieved the `universal' literacy outcome for children that is required to participate effectively in society:
(1) What funds have been directed at Commonwealth and State levels since that report to address the literacy needs of kindergarten and primary school children?
(2) What funds have been allocated and what has actually been spent?
(3) Is data now available on literacy levels; if so, what is the current extent of the literacy problem in the primary and secondary sectors; if not, why not?
(4) What percentage of children will leave Australian primary schools in 1994 with literacy problems?
(5) Are all children being screened for difficulties in literacy learning on commencing school; if not, why not?
(6) What strategies have been put in place to help children identified as having literacy problems?
(7) Have funding arrangements for primary schools been increased to the level of the secondary school sector?
(8) Have staffing arrangements been changed to allow for specialisation in literacy?
(9) Does all primary teacher training now include an improved compulsory literacy and language component?

(10) As there is evidence that lack of phonic skills lies at the heart of the problem, and given that phonic skills are essential for the reading of many Koori words, is there specific data available on the percentage of children aged 9 and/or 12 who cannot read Koori place names; if not, will a study be funded?
(11) Has the visual attention span theory been supported by the Department; if so, in what way; if not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) & (2) The Commonwealth does not require the States to account for the expenditure of their own recurrent funding of literacy programs. Literacy is one of the Commonwealth's priorities for schooling and is supported through $3 billion in expenditure annually on Commonwealth schools programs. States, Territories and non-government school authorities provide educational accountability for most of these programs through the Annual National Report on Schooling. Literacy outcomes are included in State chapters of this Report. The Commonwealth does not require States to provide dollar amounts for expenditure on literacy as this would require estimation of expenditure of teacher salaries, support structures and curriculum materials in individual schools. Financial acquittals of these grants are required by 30 June of the year following the program year.
The professional development of teachers is a key area for literacy teaching. The following projects have been supported under the National Professional Development Program:

ANSWER.PARA: National PD Support Australian Reading Association Inc. $100,000
AATE English Discipline Renewal Australian Association for the
Literacy and Numeracy Practices English Teachers Association of
Koori English Literacy Project Goulburn Valley Aboriginal

PARA.TAB: Of these projects, a total of $739,800 was allocated in 1994 and $233,833 expended by 31 August 1994.

Parent involvement in schooling (particularly at the primary level) has also been identified as critical to ensuring effective literacy outcomes. Since 1992 the Australian Council of State School Organisations and the Australian Parents Council have been provided with grants under the Quality Schooling Program (QSP) totalling $160,000 and $110,000 respectively to support parent involvement in schooling. The Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training has also agreed to provide these organisations with a joint grant of $90,000 for 1994-95 for a project on student assessment and reporting.
A project based in South Australia studying the interaction between student literacy and attendance and participation has been funded under the QSP for a total of $300,000 since 1992-93.
The allocations to projects funded under the Quality Schooling Program and expenditure to date are shown below:

Funds have been provided for projects on the literacy needs of kindergarten and primary school children under the existing Literacy and Learning National Component (LLNC) and the new Early Literacy Component (ELC) of the National Equity Program for Schools.

Under the LLNC an amount of $5.5 million was allocated over the four program years 1992-95. Funding for the ELC was announced in the May 1994 Budget and $8.7 million has been allocated to the component for the 1995 program year.

(3) Reliable, nationally consistent data on the levels on English literacy attainment among school students are not currently available. However, in the White Paper on Employment, `Working Nation', the Commonwealth allocated approximately $2.6 million, to collect by the end of 1996, data at three significant stages of schooling. The aims of the National School Literacy Survey are as follows:
to obtain a clear view regarding English literacy levels among Australian school students, identifying those student characteristics associated with different levels of literacy;
to clarify any misconceptions that employers and the community may hold about the adequacy of the literacy skills of Australian school students;
to enable Governments to assess literacy needs so that resources can be targeted more effectively; and
to establish national benchmarks against which teachers, schools and systems can assess the effectiveness of current programs and can adjust their goals and programs to improve literacy levels.

The overall purpose of the Survey is to develop a strategy to improve literacy in Australian schools based on a consistent factual analysis of the existing situation. It is likely that data will be collected at both primary and secondary levels. At this stage, all States and Territories have agreed to participate in the planning stages for the Survey.

(4) Information presently available does not enable definitive conclusions to be drawn on this issue. There is inconsistency between studies as the varying outcomes reflect differences in test construction. By the end of 1996, the National School Literacy Survey is to collect data that may enable such conclusions to be drawn, provided all States and Territories agree to participate fully.

(5) and (6) Under the Constitution, primary responsibility for school education, including screening of children and literacy strategies, lies with the State and Territory Governments and non-government school authorities. The Commonwealth supports the development of strategies to help children with literacy problems in the early years of schooling (K-3) through the Literacy and Learning National Component and the new Early Literacy Component of the National Equity Program for Schools (NEPS).

(7) The Government is investigating this issue through a report by Dr Peter Hill `Review of Resource Levels for Government Primary Schools'. This report indicated that in terms of educational need, there may be a stronger rationale for differential funding rates for students at different stages of schooling than the two rates (one for primary and the other for secondary) that apply to the Commonwealth's General Recurrent Grants Program. The report is currently with the Schools Council of the National Board of Employment, Education and Training for public consultation and a report to the Government on options.
(8) Under the Constitution, primary responsibility for school education, including staffing arrangements lies with the State and Territory Governments and non-government school authorities.

(9) Higher education institutions are self-governing organisations and have responsibility for their own internal management, including the design, content and accreditation of courses. Determination of qualifications, employment and training of teachers are responsibilities of the State, Territory and non-government education authorities.

(10) My Department does not have any data on whether 9 and/or 12 year old children are unable to read Koori place names because of a lack of phonic skills. State, Territory and non-government education authorities have not raised this matter as being a major concern; no such study is proposed.

(11) Decisions over which theories are used in the teaching of literacy are matters for State, Territory and non-government education authorities. Commonwealth funds provided under the Literacy and Learning National Component and the Early Literacy Component may be used for promotion of visual attention span theory in literacy teaching practices.
