TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, upon notice, on 28 November 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Minister aware that
(a) an inner-city Brisbane building, formerly known as Ascot Chambers, has recently been placed on the interim list of the Register of the National Estate:

(b) this building is regarded as having outstanding cultural significance for the following reasons: (i) it is the first of a new generation of high rise buildings in Brisbane and marked the beginning of a new phase of urban development in Queensland, and (ii) it is the first building in Queensland and the oldest remaining example in Australia to introduce the steel-framed method of high-rise construction;
(c) the current owners of the building, the Advance Bank, intend to demolish the building and enter into an agreement with the Tattersall's Club to redevelop the site;
(d) the Queensland Heritage Council entered the building on the Queensland heritage register but the Advance Bank successfully appealed the decision in the Planning and Environment Court;

(e) the judgement in the case (Queensland Heritage Council v Advance Bank) exposed fundamental weaknesses in the Queensland Heritage Act which protects the State's heritage, to the extent that it makes it difficult for any buildings to be entered on the register; and
(f) almost 12 months have elapsed since this judgement and the Queensland Government has taken no action to amend the Act and safeguard the State's cultural heritage.
(2) Will the Minister urge the Queensland Minister for Environment and Heritage to amend the Queensland Heritage Act to ensure buildings such as Ascot Chambers can be protected.
(3) What action will be taken to ensure that this building is not demolished and to ensure that another part of Queensland's heritage is not destroyed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1)(a) Ascot Chambers was nominated to the Register of the National Estate by a committee of architects, assessed, and subsequently entered on the Interim List of the Register of the National Estate, 30/6/92.

(b) The Australian Heritage Commission has assessed Ascot Chambers as being of cultural significance for: demonstrating the course and pattern of history as the first Brisbane building to use steel-framed high rise construction, and for marking the beginning of the new generation of high-rise buildings in Queensland; for its technical innovation in accessing a tall building by Otis Electric lifts; and as a notable work of Queensland architects Hall & Prentice.

(c) The Commission has been informed that the current owner, the Advance Bank, intends to demolish the building and that there has been an agreement made for Tattersall's Club to redevelop the site when the demolition has been completed. Tattersall's Club is the national estate listed building next to the Advance Bank.

(d) I am aware of the Queensland listing and the subsequent appeal by the Advance Bank in the Planning and Environment Court. In addition, the Advance Bank lodged an objection against the listing on the Interim List of the National Estate. The Australian Heritage Commission engaged a heritage architect to conduct an assessment and on the recommendations of that report, and despite the decision of the Queensland Planning and Environment Court, the Commission dismissed the objection on 1 July 1994.
(e) I am aware that the case (Queensland Heritage Council v Advance Bank) exposed weaknesses in the Queensland Heritage Act, making it difficult for buildings to be protected under that Act.

(f) I am aware that almost 12 months have elapsed since the court case and also that the Queensland government has been examining the implications of the judgement. I have no doubt that the Queensland Government will act to deal with any weaknesses in the Queensland Heritage Act 1992 that may have been revealed.

(2) Yes, I will discuss the matter with the Queensland Minister for Environment and Heritage at the earliest opportunity and urge the Queensland Government to strengthen the state heritage legislation, to prevent the loss of other heritage places.

(3) The Commonwealth can take no other action to prevent Ascot Chambers from being demolished as the building is not owned by the Commonwealth and there is no Commonwealth action or money involved. The Australian Heritage Commission has written to the Tattersalls Club to inform its members that Ascot Chambers has been entered in the Register of the National Estate and that the Commission deplores the proposed action by the Advance Bank. I will urge the Queensland Minister for Environment and Heritage to explore other avenues to prevent the demolition of Ascot Chambers.

(2) How much have waiting times been reduced since the commencement of the program?
(3) What is the proportion of work under the scheme being carried out by private dentists on a State-by-State basis?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Human Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) & (2) The nature of the Commonwealth Dental Health Program (CDHP) is that it provides supplementary funding to the States and Territories to increase the availability of basic dental services and thereby increase access to those services by Health Card holders.

PARA.TAB: The rationale for the introduction of the CDHP was not based on specific waiting time information but rather on the National Health Survey research used by the National Health Strategy Unit which showed that financially disadvantaged people were not receiving the same access to dental services as those with higher levels of income, resulting in inferior dental health outcomes.
There are no waiting lists for emergency dental services under the State/Territory Programs. People requiring such services receive priority care.

In relation to the General Dental Scheme, the key performance measure will be the additional number of people who gain access to dental services by reason of the additional Commonwealth funds. Accordingly, the collection of data has concentrated on the number of additional services provided.
In the first nine months of the CDHP, over 200,000 Australians have received dental services they would not have otherwise received.
(3) On a State-by-State basis the proportion of work currently carried out under the CDHP General Dental Scheme by private practitioners is:
New South Wales—30%
Victoria—26%
Queensland—currently not using private practitioners on a private practice basis. A small number of private practitioners work on a sessional basis in public clinics.
Western Australia—70%
South Australia—70-75%
Tasmania—100%
Northern Territory—information unavailable
Australian Capital Territory—50-75%

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, upon notice, on 6 December 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) What are the costs and benefits of returning land to Aboriginal traditional owners.

(2) What effect does the return of land to Aboriginal traditional owners have on the provision of services in Aboriginal communities, especially with respect of health, education, social security and law and order.
(3) What are the costs and benefits of returning Kakadu and Uluru National Parks to the traditional owners, especially with respect to joint management.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission has provided the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs with the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Any costs associated with the return of land to traditional Aboriginal owners will vary not only from case to case but, in some instances, from State to State according to the particular legislation under which land is returned. Likewise, the benefits also will differ from case to case. In the Northern Territory, for example, the return of land to traditional Aboriginal owners allows them to control areas on which they might camp, fish, hunt and gather, as well as carry out ceremonial and ritual practices, with the privacy that all of these activities require. Control of sacred sites enables the custodians of the sites to better protect them.
(2) The services mentioned in the honourable senator's question continue to be provided in the same way that they were prior to the grant taking place.

(3) It is not practicable to quantify the cost of returning Kakadu and Uluru National Parks. However, management of the parks has been enhanced through the utilisation of comprehensive Aboriginal knowledge of these environments and how best to protect them, acquired over thousands of years.

Visitor numbers to these two Parks have increased significantly since they were granted to Aboriginal Land Trusts, and the experience of visitors has been enhanced by the provision of Aboriginal cultural information.
Recent surveys by the Australian Tourism Commission and the Northern Territory Tourism Commission have shown an increasing desire by visitors to visit places of Aboriginal cultural significance.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health, upon notice, on 7 December 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to proposals by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology to the United States National Cancer Institute that information on carcinogens be added to tar and nicotine content listing on cigarette labelling:
(1) Does Australian research back up United States findings that more than 2 000 chemicals are present in cigarette smoke.
(2) What chemicals have been found in cigarette smoke.
(3) What known carcinogens are among these chemicals.
(4) Is the Government considering adding information on carcinogens to cigarette labelling in Australia.
(5) What method of testing is used in Australia to test tar and nicotine content in cigarettes.

(6) Is the Government aware of concerns raised by the United States National Cancer Institute that the American machine method, which takes two puffs every minute with residue measured in the filter, may be unreliable.
(7) Has the Government taken any action to obtain details on these concerns raised by the United States National Cancer Institute.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Human Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: These answers have been prepared in conjunction with the Australian Government Analytical Laboratory who conduct the Commonwealth Government's Cigarette Testing Program.
(1) There are no significant Australian studies on the amount of chemicals that are present in cigarettes but New Zealand studies support the US findings.

(2) Some of the constituents of cigarette smoke include: nitrogen, oxygen, carbon dioxide, carbon monoxide, water, argon, hydrogen, ammonia, nitrogen oxides, hydrogen cyanide, hydrogen sulfide, methane, volatile alkanes and alkenes, isoprene, butadiene, acetylene, benzene, toluene, styrene, volatile aromatic hydrocarbons, formic acid, acetic acid, propionic acid, methyl formate, volatile acids, formaldehyde, acetaldehyde, acrolein, acetone, volatile ketones, methanol, volatile alcohols, acetonitrile, furan, pyridine, picolines, 3-vinylpyridine, pyrrole, pyrrolidine, N-methylpyrrolidine, volatile pyrazines, methyl amine, nicotine, nornicotine, anatabine, anabasine, alkaloids, bipyridyls, n-Hentriacontane, naphthalene, phenanthrenes, anthracenes, fluorenes, pyrenes, fluoranthenes, carcinogenic polynuclear aromatice hydrocarbons, phenols, catechols, dihydroxybenzenes, scopoletin, polyphenols, cyclotenes, quinones, solanesol, neophytadienes, limonene, terpenes, palmitic acid, stearic acid, oleic acid, linoleic acid, lactic acid, indoles, skatole, quinolines, N-heterocyclic hydrocarbons, stigmasterol, sitosterol, campesterol, aniline, toluidines, aromatic amines, tobacco specific N-nitrosamines and glycerol.

(3) The 1989 US Surgeon General's report stated that there are approximately 43 known carcinogens in tobacco smoke. Some of these include: benz(a)anthracene, benzo(b)fluoranthene, benzo(j)fluoranthene, benzo(k)fluoranthene, benzo(a)pyrene, chrysene, dibenz(a,h)anthracene, dibenzo(a,i)pyrene, dibenzo(a,l)pyrene, indeno(1,2,3-c,d)pyrene, 5-methylchrysene, quinoline, dibenz(a,h)acridine, dibenz(a,j)acridine, 7H-dibenzo(c,g)carbazole, N-nitrosodimethylamine, N-nitrosoethyl methylamine, N-nitrosodiethylamine, N-nitrosopyrrolidine, N-nitrosodiethanolamine, N'-nitrosonornicotine, 4-(methylnitrosamino)-1-(3-pyridyl)-1-butanone, N'nitrosoanabasine, N-nitrosomorpholine, 2-toluidine, 2-naphthylamine, 4-aminobiphenyl, formaldehyde, acetaldehyde, crotonaldehyde, benzene, acrylonitrile, 1,1-dimethylhydrazine, 2-nitropropane, ethylcarbamate, vinyl chloride, hydrazine, arsenic, nickel, chromium, cadmium, lead and polonium-210.
(5) The methods used in Australia to test tar, nicotine and carbon monoxide are the standard methods published by the International Standards Organisation:
tar—ISO 4387
nicotine—ISO 10315
carbon monoxide—ISO 8454

(6) The Government is aware of claims that the standard tests do not mimic real smoking behaviour and that variations in results can be obtained by blocking some or all of the ventilation holes, thus deceiving consumers. Such tests are designed to compare the tar, nicotine and carbon monoxide levels in various cigarettes. The tests are not designed to determine what dose of tar, nicotine and carbon monoxide an individual smoker receives when smoking.
(7) No additional details are being sought.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 15 December 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the recent incident where a group of 13 Vietnamese boat people arrived at a boat ramp in suburban Darwin early on 22 November 1994 and flagged down a passing motorist:
(1) Did the department provide intelligence about the vessel which landed in Darwin; if so, what part did it play; if not, why not.
(2) Were Defence elements on routine operations in the area briefed about the possibility of a landing.
(3) With reference to the persons who landed in Darwin: (a) have Defence personnel been involved in their debriefing; and (b) what is known of their prior knowledge of the country before they landed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) & (2) Responsibility for the management and coordination of the Civil Coastal Surveillance Program presently lies with Coastwatch, a sub-component of the Australian Customs Service.

Defence support for the program consists of a minimum of 1800 patrol boat days of patrol and response capability and 250 hours of P3C Orion air surveillance. Coastwatch also draws on Defence intelligence information and assistance with the planning and conduct of surveillance operations.

In addition to specific requests for Defence assistance in civil surveillance operations, military units routinely report sightings of significance to Coastwatch for dissemination to the relevant authorities. Similarly, information gained from civil surveillance operations, that is considered of significance to the military, is readily injected into the Defence intelligence network for appropriate action.

At the time of arrival of the boat containing 13 Vietnamese, a significant number of Coastwatch, Customs and Defence assets were already actively engaged in operations against a large number of illegal Indonesian fishing vessels and escorting another potential illegal immigrant vessel into Darwin.

At the time of the incident neither Defence, nor any other Government agency, had any intelligence that would have suggested a second vessel was on its way to Darwin. Therefore, no specific tasking relating to illegal immigration vessels had been issued to the three patrol boats on routine operations in the Timor Sea.
(3) (a) Defence personnel routinely assist in various aspects of the debriefing process but primary responsibility rests with officials from the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.

(b) Nothing is known as this particular group arrived from a United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR)-sponsored camp on Galang island in Indonesia. Under the terms of an agreement with the UNHCR, such persons are returned to Galang as soon as possible and only their names and their state of health are ascertained.
